<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">History of India</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Pre-1947 history of the Indian subcontinent</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">This article is about the pre-1947 history of the Indian subcontinent. For post-1947 history, see <a href="/wiki/History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)" title="History of India (1947–present)">History of India (1947–present)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>

</div></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">
<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title">Modern</div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content nowrap" style="text-align:left"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886050385" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="treeview">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Indian_Rebellion_of_1857" title="Indian Rebellion of 1857">The Great Rebellion</a>, 1857 – 1858 CE</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British Raj</a>, 1858 – 1947 CE
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Indian_independence_movement" title="Indian independence movement"> Independence Movement</a></li></ul></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)" title="History of India (1947–present)">Independent India</a>, 1947 CE – present
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Dominion_of_India" title="Dominion of India">Dominion of India</a>, 1947 – 1950 CE</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/India" title="India">Republic of India</a>, 1950 CE – present</li></ul></li></ul>
</div></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">

<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="background:transparent;text-align:left;padding-right:4em;"><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_South_Asian_history" title="Outline of South Asian history">Outline</a></div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1045330069" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="sidebar sidebar-collapse nomobile nowraplinks plainlist"><tbody><tr><td class="sidebar-content">
<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="background:transparent;text-align:left;padding-right:4em;"><a href="/wiki/South_Asian_Stone_Age" title="South Asian Stone Age">Palaeolithic</a> <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886047488">.mw-parser-output .nobold{font-weight:normal}</style><span class="nobold">(2,500,000–250,000 BC)</span></div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content"><table style="width:100%;border-collapse:collapse;border-spacing:0px 0px;border:none"><tbody><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Madrasian_culture" title="Madrasian culture">Madrasian culture</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"></td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Soanian" title="Soanian">Soanian culture</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">
<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="background:transparent;text-align:left;padding-right:4em;"><a href="/wiki/South_Asian_Stone_Age" title="South Asian Stone Age">Neolithic</a> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="nobold">(10,800–3300 BC)</span></div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content"><table style="width:100%;border-collapse:collapse;border-spacing:0px 0px;border:none"><tbody><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Bhirrana" title="Bhirrana">Bhirrana culture</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (7570–6200 BC)</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Mehrgarh" title="Mehrgarh">Mehrgarh culture</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (7000–3300 BC)</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Edakkal_Caves" title="Edakkal Caves">Edakkal culture</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (5000–3000 BC)</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">
<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="background:transparent;text-align:left;padding-right:4em;"><a href="/wiki/Chalcolithic" title="Chalcolithic">Chalcolithic</a> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="nobold">(3500–1500 BC)</span></div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content"><table style="width:100%;border-collapse:collapse;border-spacing:0px 0px;border:none"><tbody><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Anarta_tradition" title="Anarta tradition">Anarta tradition</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (c. 3950–1900 BC)</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Ahar%E2%80%93Banas_culture" title="Ahar–Banas culture">Ahar-Banas culture</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (3000–1500 BC)</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Pandu_Rajar_Dhibi" title="Pandu Rajar Dhibi">Pandu culture</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (1600–1500 BC)</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Malwa_culture" title="Malwa culture">Malwa culture</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (1600–1300 BC)</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Jorwe_culture" title="Jorwe culture">Jorwe culture</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (1400–700 BC)</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">
<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="background:transparent;text-align:left;padding-right:4em;"><a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age_India" title="Bronze </tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">

title="Indology">Indology</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/History_of_Indian_influence_on_Southeast_Asia" title="History of Indian influence on Southeast Asia">Influence on Southeast Asia</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Linguistic_history_of_India" title="Linguistic history of India">Language</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Indian_literature" title="Indian literature">Literature</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Indian_maritime_history" title="Indian maritime history">Maritime</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/History_of_metallurgy_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="History of metallurgy in the Indian subcontinent">Metallurgy</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_India" title="Military history of India">Military</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Partition_of_India" title="Partition of India">Partition of India</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Pakistan_studies" title="Pakistan studies">Pakistan studies</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Indian_philosophy" title="Indian philosophy">Philosophy</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Indian_religions#History" title="Indian religions">Religion</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/History_of_science_and_technology_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="History of science and technology in the Indian subcontinent">Science and technology</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Indian_history" title="Timeline of Indian history">Timeline</a></li></ul></div></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:History_of_South_Asia" title="Template:History of South Asia"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:History_of_South_Asia" title="Template talk:History of South Asia"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:History_of_South_Asia&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Indus_Valley_Civilization,_Mature_Phase_(2600-1900_BCE).png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="733" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="179" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Indus_Valley_Civilization%2C_Mature_Phase_%282600-1900_BCE%29.png/220px-Indus_Valley_Civilization%2C_Mature_Phase_%282600-1900_BCE%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Indus_Valley_Civilization%2C_Mature_Phase_%282600-1900_BCE%29.png/330px-Indus_Valley_Civilization%2C_Mature_Phase_%282600-1900_BCE%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Indus_Valley_Civilization%2C_Mature_Phase_%282600-1900_BCE%29.png/440px-Indus_Valley_Civilization%2C_Mature_Phase_%282600-1900_BCE%29.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Indus_Valley_Civilization,_Mature_Phase_(2600-1900_BCE).png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Indus Valley civilisation, mature phase (2600–1900 BCE)</div></div></div>
<p>According to consensus in modern genetics, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anatomically_modern_humans" title="Anatomically modern humans">anatomically modern humans</a> first arrived on the <a href="/wiki/Indian_subcontinent" title="Indian subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a> from <a href="/wiki/Africa" title="Africa">Africa</a> between 73,000 and 55,000 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PetragliaAllchin_1-0"><a href="#cite_note-PetragliaAllchin-1">[1]</a></sup> However, the earliest known human remains in South Asia date to 30,000 years ago. Settled life, which involves the transition from foraging to farming and pastoralism, began in South Asia around 7000 BCE. At the site of <a href="/wiki/Mehrgarh" title="Mehrgarh">Mehrgarh</a> presence can be documented of the domestication of wheat and barley, rapidly followed by that of goats, sheep, and cattle.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wright2009-p=44_2-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wright2009-p=44-2">[2]</a></sup> By 4500 BCE, settled life had spread more widely,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wright2009-p=44_2-1"><a href="#cite_note-Wright2009-p=44-2">[2]</a></sup> and began to gradually evolve into the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_civilisation" title="Indus Valley civilisation">Indus Valley civilisation</a>, an early civilisation of the <a href="/wiki/Old_World" title="Old World">Old World</a>, which was contemporaneous with <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">Ancient Egypt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamia" title="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a>. This civilisation flourished between 2500 BCE and 1900 BCE in what today is Pakistan and north-western India, and was noted for its urban planning, baked brick houses, elaborate drainage, and water supply.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wright2009-p=115_3-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wright2009-p=115-3">[3]</a></sup>
</p><p>Early on in the second millennium BCE, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/4.2_kiloyear_event" title="4.2 kiloyear event">persistent drought</a> caused the population of the Indus Valley to scatter from large urban centres to villages. Around the same time, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rigvedic_tribes" title="Rigvedic tribes">Indo-Aryan tribes</a> moved into the <a href="/wiki/Punjab" title="Punjab">Punjab</a> from <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a> in several <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_migration_theory" title="Indo-Aryan migration theory">waves of migration</a>. Their <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vedic_Period" title="Vedic Period">Vedic Period</a> (1500–500 BCE) was marked by the composition of the <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedas</a>, large collections of hymns of these tribes. Their <a href="/wiki/Varna_(Hinduism)" title="Varna (Hinduism)">varna system</a>, which evolved into the <a href="/wiki/Caste_system_in_India" title="Caste system in India">caste system</a>, consisted of a hierarchy of priests, warriors, and free peasants. The pastoral and nomadic Indo-Aryans spread from the Punjab into the Gangetic plain, large swaths of which they deforested for agriculture usage. The composition of Vedic texts ended around 600 BCE, when a new, interregional culture arose. Small chieftaincies, or <a href="/wiki/Janapada" title="Janapada">janapadas</a>, were consolidated into larger states, or <a href="/wiki/Mahajanapadas" title="Mahajanapadas">mahajanapadas</a>, and a second urbanisation took place. This urbanisation was accompanied by the rise of new <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Arama%E1%B9%87a" title="Śramaṇa">ascetic</a> movements in <a href="/wiki/Greater_Magadha" title="Greater Magadha">Greater Magadha</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a>, which opposed the growing influence of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brahmanism" title="Brahmanism">Brahmanism</a> and the primacy of rituals, presided by Brahmin priests, that had come to be associated with Vedic religion,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Flood_1996_82_4-0"><a href="#cite_note-Flood_1996_82-4">[4]</a></sup> and gave rise to new religious concepts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup> In response to the success of these movements, Vedic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brahmanism" title="Brahmanism">Brahmanism</a> was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu_synthesis" title="Hindu synthesis">synthesised</a> with the preexisting religious cultures of the subcontinent, giving rise to <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Indian_cultural_zone.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="423" data-file-width="940" decoding="async" height="99" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Indian_cultural_zone.svg/220px-Indian_cultural_zone.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Indian_cultural_zone.svg/330px-Indian_cultural_zone.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Indian_cultural_zone.svg/440px-Indian_cultural_zone.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Indian_cultural_zone.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Indian cultural influence (<a href="/wiki/Greater_India" title="Greater India">Greater India</a>)</div></div></div>
<p>Most of the Indian subcontinent was conquered by the <a href="/wiki/Maurya_Empire" title="Maurya Empire">Maurya Empire</a> during the 4th and 3rd centuries BCE. From the 3rd century BCE onwards, <a href="/wiki/Prakrit" title="Prakrit">Prakrit</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pali" title="Pali">Pali</a> literature in the north and <a href="/wiki/Tamil_language" title="Tamil language">Tamil</a> <a href="/wiki/Sangam_literature" title="Sangam literature">Sangam literature</a> in southern India started to flourish.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-6"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_7-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-7">[7]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Wootz_steel" title="Wootz steel">Wootz steel</a> originated in south India in the 3rd century BCE and was exported.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Menon_R.V.G_p.15_8-0"><a href="#cite_note-Menon_R.V.G_p.15-8">[8]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> The Maurya Empire would collapse in 185 BCE, on the assassination of the then-Emperor Brihadratha by his General <a href="/wiki/Pushyamitra_Shunga" title="Pushyamitra Shunga">Pushyamitra Shunga</a>. Shunga would go on to form the <a href="/wiki/Shunga_Empire" title="Shunga Empire">Shunga Empire</a> in the North and Northeast of the subcontinent, while the <a href="/wiki/Greco-Bactrian_Kingdom" title="Greco-Bactrian Kingdom">Greco-Bactrian Kingdom</a> would claim the Northwest, and found the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Greek_Kingdom" title="Indo-Greek Kingdom">Indo-Greek Kingdom</a>. During this <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Classical_India" title="Classical India">Classical period</a>, various parts of India were ruled by numerous dynasties, including the <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta Empire</a> in the 4-6th centuries CE. This period, witnessing a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a> religious and intellectual resurgence, is known as the classical or "<a href="/wiki/Golden_Age_of_India" title="Golden Age of India">Golden Age of India</a>". During this period, aspects of Indian civilisation, administration, culture, and religion (Hinduism and Buddhism) spread to much of Asia, while kingdoms in southern India had maritime business links with the Middle East and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mediterranean" title="Mediterranean">Mediterranean</a>. Indian cultural influence spread over many parts of <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>, which led to the establishment of Indianised kingdoms in Southeast Asia (<a href="/wiki/Greater_India" title="Greater India">Greater India</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Flood,_Gavin_2003._pg._273-4_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-Flood,_Gavin_2003._pg._273-4-12">[12]</a></sup>
</p><p>The most significant event between the 7th and 11th century was the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tripartite_struggle" title="Tripartite struggle">Tripartite struggle</a> centred on <a href="/wiki/Kannauj" title="Kannauj">Kannauj</a> that lasted for more than two centuries between the <a href="/wiki/Pala_Empire" title="Pala Empire">Pala Empire</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rashtrakuta_Empire" title="Rashtrakuta Empire">Rashtrakuta Empire</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gurjara-Pratihara_Empire" title="Gurjara-Pratihara Empire">Gurjara-Pratihara Empire</a>. <a href="/wiki/History_of_South_India" title="History of South India">Southern India</a> saw the rise of multiple imperial powers from the middle of the fifth century, most notably the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chalukya" title="Chalukya">Chalukya</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chola" title="Chola">Chola</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pallava" title="Pallava">Pallava</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chera" title="Chera">Chera</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pandyan" title="Pandyan">Pandyan</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_Chalukya" title="Western Chalukya">Western Chalukya</a> Empires. The <a href="/wiki/Chola_dynasty" title="Chola dynasty">Chola dynasty</a> conquered southern India and successfully invaded parts of Southeast Asia, <a href="/wiki/Sri_Lanka" title="Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Maldives" title="Maldives">Maldives</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bengal" title="Bengal">Bengal</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> in the 11th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup> In the early medieval period <a href="/wiki/Indian_mathematics" title="Indian mathematics">Indian mathematics</a>, including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu_numeral_system" title="Hindu numeral system">Hindu numerals</a>, influenced the development of mathematics and astronomy in the <a href="/wiki/Arab_world" title="Arab world">Arab world</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquests_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="Muslim conquests in the Indian subcontinent">Islamic conquests</a> made limited inroads into modern Afghanistan and <a href="/wiki/Sindh" title="Sindh">Sindh</a> as early as the 8th century,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> followed by the invasions of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mahmud_Ghazni" title="Mahmud Ghazni">Mahmud Ghazni</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMeri2005146_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMeri2005146-18">[18]</a></sup>
The <a href="/wiki/Delhi_Sultanate" title="Delhi Sultanate">Delhi Sultanate</a> was founded in 1206 CE by Central Asian <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkic_people" title="Turkic people">Turks</a> who ruled a major part of the northern Indian subcontinent in the early 14th century, but declined in the late 14th century,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> and saw the advent of the <a href="/wiki/Deccan_sultanates" title="Deccan sultanates">Deccan sultanates</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sohoni2018_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sohoni2018-20">[20]</a></sup> The wealthy <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Sultanate" title="Bengal Sultanate">Bengal Sultanate</a> also emerged as a major power, lasting over three centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Eaton1996_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-Eaton1996-21">[21]</a></sup>
This period also saw the emergence of several powerful Hindu states, notably <a href="/wiki/Vijayanagara_Empire" title="Vijayanagara Empire">Vijayanagara</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Rajput_dynasties_and_states" title="List of Rajput dynasties and states">Rajput states</a>, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mewar_Kingdom" title="Mewar Kingdom">Mewar</a>. The 15th century saw the advent of <a href="/wiki/History_of_Sikhism" title="History of Sikhism">Sikhism</a>. The early modern period began in the 16th century, when the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal Empire</a> conquered most of the Indian subcontinent,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-exeter_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-exeter-22">[22]</a></sup> signalling the <a href="/wiki/Proto-industrialization" title="Proto-industrialization">proto-industrialization</a>, becoming the biggest global economy and manufacturing power,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Parthasarathi38_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-Parthasarathi38-23">[23]</a></sup> with a nominal GDP that valued a quarter of world GDP, superior than the combination of <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>'s GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-harrison_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-harrison-25">[25]</a></sup> The Mughals suffered a gradual decline in the early 18th century, which provided opportunities for the <a href="/wiki/Maratha_Empire" title="Maratha Empire">Marathas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sikh_Empire" title="Sikh Empire">Sikhs</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mysore_Kingdom" title="Mysore Kingdom">Mysoreans</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nizams" title="Nizams">Nizams</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nawabs_of_Bengal" title="Nawabs of Bengal">Nawabs of Bengal</a> to exercise control over large regions of the Indian subcontinent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup>
</p><p>From the mid-18th century to the mid-19th century, large regions of India were gradually annexed by the <a href="/wiki/East_India_Company" title="East India Company">East India Company</a>, a chartered company acting as a sovereign power on behalf of the British government. Dissatisfaction with <a href="/wiki/Company_rule_in_India" title="Company rule in India">company rule in India</a> led to the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Rebellion_of_1857" title="Indian Rebellion of 1857">Indian Rebellion of 1857</a>, which rocked parts of north and central India, and led to the dissolution of the company. India was afterwards ruled directly by the <a href="/wiki/The_Crown" title="The Crown">British Crown</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British Raj</a>. After <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>, a nationwide struggle for independence was launched by the <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Congress" title="Indian National Congress">Indian National Congress</a>, led by <a href="/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi" title="Mahatma Gandhi">Mahatma Gandhi</a>, and noted for <a href="/wiki/Nonviolent_resistance" title="Nonviolent resistance">nonviolence</a>. Later, the <a href="/wiki/All-India_Muslim_League" title="All-India Muslim League">All-India Muslim League</a> would advocate for a separate Muslim-majority <a href="/wiki/Nation_state" title="Nation state">nation state</a>. The British Indian Empire was partitioned in August 1947 into the <a href="/wiki/Dominion_of_India" title="Dominion of India">Dominion of India</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dominion_of_Pakistan" title="Dominion of Pakistan">Dominion of Pakistan</a>, each gaining its independence.
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style><div class="toclimit-3"><div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-19"><a href="#Classical_period_(c._200_BCE_–_c._650_CE)"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Classical period (c. 200 BCE – c. 650 CE)</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-20"><a href="#Early_classical_period_(c._200_BCE_–_c._320_CE)"><span class="tocnumber">4.1</span> <span class="toctext">Early classical period (c. 200 BCE – c. 320 CE)</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-21"><a href="#Shunga_Empire"><span class="tocnumber">4.1.1</span> <span class="toctext">Shunga Empire</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-22"><a href="#Satavahana_Empire"><span class="tocnumber">4.1.2</span> <span class="toctext">Satavahana Empire</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-23"><a href="#Trade_and_travels_to_India"><span class="tocnumber">4.1.3</span> <span class="toctext">Trade and travels to India</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-24"><a href="#Kushan_Empire"><span class="tocnumber">4.1.4</span> <span class="toctext">Kushan Empire</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-25"><a href="#Classical_period_(c._320_–_650_CE)"><span class="tocnumber">4.2</span> <span class="toctext">Classical period (c. 320 – 650 CE)</span></a>

<h2><span id="Prehistoric_era_.28until_c._3300_BCE.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistoric_era_(until_c._3300_BCE)"><span class="anchor" id="Prehistory"></span> Prehistoric era (until c. 3300 BCE)</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1097763485">.mw-parser-output .ambox{border:1px solid #a2a9b1;border-left:10px solid #36c;background-color:#fbfbfb;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Mesolithic" title="Mesolithic">Mesolithic</a> rock art at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bhimbetka" title="Bhimbetka">Bhimbetka rock shelters</a>, <a href="/wiki/Madhya_Pradesh" title="Madhya Pradesh">Madhya Pradesh</a>, showing a wild animal, perhaps a mythical one, attacking human hunters. Although the rock art has not been directly dated,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DavidMcNiven2018_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-DavidMcNiven2018-28">[28]</a></sup> it has been argued on href="#cite_note-pathak-dubey-31">[31]</a></sup></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:144px;max-width:144px"><div class="thumbimage" India</a>.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:144px;max-width:144px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:106px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" title="Stone Age">Stone Age</a> (6,000 BCE) carvings of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Edakkal_Caves" title="Edakkal Caves">Edakkal Caves</a> in Kerala, India.</div></div></div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Paleolithic">Paleolithic</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/South_Asian_Stone_Age" title="South Asian Stone Age">South Asian Stone Age</a></div><p><a href="/wiki/Hominini" title="Hominini">Hominin</a> expansion from Africa is estimated to have reached the <a href="/wiki/Indian_subcontinent" title="Indian subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a> approximately two million years ago, and possibly as early as 2.2 million years before the present.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChauhan2010147_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChauhan2010147-32">[32]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPetragliaAllchin20075_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPetragliaAllchin20075-33">[33]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPetraglia2010167–170_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPetraglia2010167–170-34">[34]</a></sup> This dating is based on the known presence of <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_erectus" title="Homo erectus">Homo erectus</a></i> in <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a> by 1.8 million years before the present and in East Asia by 1.36 million years before present, as well as the discovery of stone tools at <a href="/wiki/Riwat" title="Riwat">Riwat</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Soan_River" title="Soan River">Soan River</a> valley of the Pabbi Hills region, <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPetragliaAllchin20075_33-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPetragliaAllchin20075-33">[33]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-murray_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-murray-35">[35]</a></sup> Although some older discoveries have been claimed, the suggested dates, based on the dating of <a href="/wiki/Fluvial_processes" title="Fluvial processes">fluvial sediments</a>, have not been independently verified.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPetraglia2010167–170_34-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPetraglia2010167–170-34">[34]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChauhan2010147–160_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChauhan2010147–160-36">[36]</a></sup>
</p><p>The oldest hominin fossil remains in the Indian subcontinent are those of <i>Homo erectus</i> or <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_heidelbergensis" title="Homo heidelbergensis">Homo heidelbergensis</a></i>, from the <a href="/wiki/Narmada_River" title="Narmada River">Narmada Valley</a> in central India, and are dated to approximately half a million years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPetragliaAllchin20075_33-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPetragliaAllchin20075-33">[33]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChauhan2010147–160_36-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChauhan2010147–160-36">[36]</a></sup> Older fossil finds have been claimed, but are considered unreliable.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChauhan2010147–160_36-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChauhan2010147–160-36">[36]</a></sup> Reviews of archaeological evidence have suggested that occupation of the Indian subcontinent by hominins was sporadic until approximately 700,000 years ago, and was geographically widespread by approximately 250,000 years before the present, from which point onward, archaeological evidence of proto-human presence is widely mentioned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChauhan2010147–160_36-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChauhan2010147–160-36">[36]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPetraglia2010167–170_34-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPetraglia2010167–170-34">[34]</a></sup>
</p><p>
According to a historical demographer of South Asia, Tim Dyson: </p><blockquote><p>Modern human beings—Homo sapiens—originated in Africa. Then, intermittently, sometime between 60,000 and 80,000 years ago, tiny groups of them began to enter the north-west of the Indian subcontinent. It seems likely that initially, they came by way of the coast. ... it is virtually certain that there were Homo sapiens in the subcontinent 55,000 years ago, even though the earliest fossils that have been found of them date to only about 30,000 years before the present.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dyson2018-1_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dyson2018-1-37">[37]</a></sup></p></blockquote><p>
According to Michael D. Petraglia and <a href="/wiki/Bridget_Allchin" title="Bridget Allchin">Bridget Allchin</a>: </p><blockquote><p>Y-Chromosome and Mt-DNA data support the colonization of South Asia by modern humans originating in Africa. ... Coalescence dates for most non-European populations average to between 73–55 ka.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPetragliaAllchin20076_38-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPetragliaAllchin20076-38">[38]</a></sup></p></blockquote><p>
And according to historian of South Asia, <a href="/wiki/Michael_H._Fisher" title="Michael H. Fisher">Michael H. Fisher</a>: </p><blockquote><p>Scholars estimate that the first successful expansion of the Homo sapiens range beyond Africa and across the Arabian Peninsula occurred from as early as 80,000 years ago to as late as 40,000 years ago, although there may have been prior unsuccessful emigrations. Some of their descendants extended the human range ever further in each generation, spreading into each habitable land they encountered. One human channel was along the warm and productive coastal lands of the Persian Gulf and northern Indian Ocean. Eventually, various bands entered India between 75,000 years ago and 35,000 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fisher2018-23_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fisher2018-23-39">[39]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>Archaeological evidence has been interpreted to suggest the presence of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anatomically_modern_humans" title="Anatomically modern humans">anatomically modern humans</a> in the Indian subcontinent 78,000–74,000 years ago,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TunizGillespie2016_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-TunizGillespie2016-40">[40]</a></sup> although this interpretation is disputed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> The occupation of South Asia by modern humans, over a long time, initially in varying forms of isolation as hunter-gatherers, has turned it into a highly diverse one, second only to Africa in human genetic diversity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dyson2018-28a_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dyson2018-28a-43">[43]</a></sup>
</p><p>
According to Tim Dyson: </p><blockquote><p>Genetic research has contributed to knowledge of the prehistory of the subcontinent's people in other respects. In particular, the level of genetic diversity in the region is extremely high. Indeed, only Africa's population is genetically more diverse. Related to this, there is strong evidence of ‘founder’ events in the subcontinent. By this is meant circumstances where a subgroup—such as a tribe—derives from a tiny number of ‘original’ individuals. Further, compared to most world regions, the subcontinent's people are relatively distinct in having practised comparatively high levels of endogamy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dyson2018-28a_43-1"><a href="#cite_note-Dyson2018-28a-43">[43]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Neolithic">Neolithic</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mehrgarh_ruins.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="654" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Mehrgarh_ruins.jpg/220px-Mehrgarh_ruins.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Mehrgarh_ruins.jpg/330px-Mehrgarh_ruins.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Mehrgarh_ruins.jpg/440px-Mehrgarh_ruins.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mehrgarh_ruins.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mehrgarh" title="Mehrgarh">Mehrgarh</a> site, in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beluchistan" title="Beluchistan">Beluchistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Settled life</a> emerged on the subcontinent in the western margins of the <a href="/wiki/Indus_River" title="Indus River">Indus River</a> alluvium approximately 9,000 years ago, evolving gradually into the <a href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilisation" title="Indus Valley Civilisation">Indus Valley Civilisation</a> of the third millennium BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wright2009-p=44_2-2"><a href="#cite_note-Wright2009-p=44-2">[2]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dyson2018-4-5_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dyson2018-4-5-44">[44]</a></sup> According to Tim Dyson: "By 7,000 years ago agriculture was firmly established in Baluchistan. And, over the next 2,000 years, the practice of farming slowly spread eastwards into the Indus valley." And according to Michael Fisher:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fisher2018-33_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fisher2018-33-45">[45]</a></sup> </p><blockquote><p> "The earliest discovered instance ... of well-established, settled agricultural society is at Mehrgarh in the hills between the Bolan Pass and the Indus plain (today in Pakistan) (see Map 3.1). From as early as 7000 BCE, communities there started investing increased labor in preparing the land and selecting, planting, tending, and harvesting particular grain-producing plants. They also domesticated animals, including sheep, goats, pigs, and oxen (both humped zebu [<i>Bos indicus</i>] and unhumped [<i>Bos taurus</i>]). Castrating oxen, for instance, turned them from mainly meat sources into domesticated draft-animals as well."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fisher2018-33_45-1"><a href="#cite_note-Fisher2018-33-45">[45]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<h2><span id="Bronze_Age_.28c._3300_.E2.80.93_c._1800_BCE.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Bronze_Age_(c._3300_–_c._1800_BCE)">Bronze Age (c. 3300 – c. 1800 BCE)</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Indus_Valley_Civilisation">Indus Valley Civilisation</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilisation" title="Indus Valley Civilisation">Indus Valley Civilisation</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Indus_Valley_civilisation_sites" title="List of Indus Valley civilisation sites">List of Indus Valley civilisation sites</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Indus_Valley_Civilization,_Mature_Phase_(2600-1900_BCE).png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="733" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="179" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Indus_Valley_Civilization%2C_Mature_Phase_%282600-1900_BCE%29.png/220px-Indus_Valley_Civilization%2C_Mature_Phase_%282600-1900_BCE%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Indus_Valley_Civilization%2C_Mature_Phase_%282600-1900_BCE%29.png/330px-Indus_Valley_Civilization%2C_Mature_Phase_%282600-1900_BCE%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Indus_Valley_Civilization%2C_Mature_Phase_%282600-1900_BCE%29.png/440px-Indus_Valley_Civilization%2C_Mature_Phase_%282600-1900_BCE%29.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Indus_Valley_Civilization,_Mature_Phase_(2600-1900_BCE).png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Mature Harappan Period, c. 2600 - 1900 BCE</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age_India" title="Bronze Age India">Bronze Age in the Indian subcontinent</a> began around 3300 BCE. Along with <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">Ancient Egypt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamia" title="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a>, the Indus Valley region was one of three early <a href="/wiki/Cradle_of_civilization" title="Cradle of civilization">cradles of civilization</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Old_World" title="Old World">Old World</a>. Of the three, the Indus Valley civilisation was the most expansive,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> and at its peak, may have had a population of over five million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup>
</p><p>The civilisation was primarily centered in modern-day Pakistan, in the Indus river basin, and secondarily in the <a href="/wiki/Ghaggar-Hakra_River" title="Ghaggar-Hakra River">Ghaggar-Hakra River</a> basin in eastern Pakistan and northwestern India. The mature Indus civilisation flourished from about 2600 to 1900 BCE, marking the beginning of urban civilisation on the Indian subcontinent. The civilisation included cities such as <a href="/wiki/Harappa" title="Harappa">Harappa</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ganeriwala" title="Ganeriwala">Ganeriwala</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mohenjo-daro" title="Mohenjo-daro">Mohenjo-daro</a> in modern-day Pakistan, and <a href="/wiki/Dholavira" title="Dholavira">Dholavira</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kalibangan" title="Kalibangan">Kalibangan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rakhigarhi" title="Rakhigarhi">Rakhigarhi</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lothal" title="Lothal">Lothal</a> in modern-day India.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mohenjo-daro.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2736" data-file-width="3648" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Mohenjo-daro.jpg/220px-Mohenjo-daro.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Mohenjo-daro.jpg/330px-Mohenjo-daro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Mohenjo-daro.jpg/440px-Mohenjo-daro.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mohenjo-daro.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mohenjo-daro" title="Mohenjo-daro">Mohenjo-daro</a>, one of the largest Indus cities. View of the site's <a href="/wiki/Great_Bath,_Mohenjo-daro" title="Great Bath, Mohenjo-daro">Great Bath</a>, showing the surrounding urban layout.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:DHOLAVIRA_SITE_(24).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2700" data-file-width="4050" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/DHOLAVIRA_SITE_%2824%29.jpg/220px-DHOLAVIRA_SITE_%2824%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/DHOLAVIRA_SITE_%2824%29.jpg/330px-DHOLAVIRA_SITE_%2824%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/DHOLAVIRA_SITE_%2824%29.jpg/440px-DHOLAVIRA_SITE_%2824%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:DHOLAVIRA_SITE_(24).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Dholavira" title="Dholavira">Dholavira</a>, a city of the Indus Valley civilisation, with <a href="/wiki/Stepwell" title="Stepwell">stepwell</a> steps to reach the water level in artificially constructed reservoirs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-news_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-news-48">[48]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_drainage_system_at_Lothal_2.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/The_drainage_system_at_Lothal_2.JPG/220px-The_drainage_system_at_Lothal_2.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/The_drainage_system_at_Lothal_2.JPG/330px-The_drainage_system_at_Lothal_2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/The_drainage_system_at_Lothal_2.JPG/440px-The_drainage_system_at_Lothal_2.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_drainage_system_at_Lothal_2.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Archaeological remains of washroom drainage system at <a href="/wiki/Lothal" title="Lothal">Lothal</a></div></div></div>
<p>Inhabitants of the ancient Indus river valley, the Harappans, developed new techniques in metallurgy and handicraft (carneol<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The text near this tag needs further explanation. (September 2022)">further explanation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> products, seal carving), and produced copper, bronze, lead, and tin. The civilisation is noted for its cities built of brick, roadside drainage system, and multi-storeyed houses and is thought to have had some kind of municipal organisation. Civilization also developed a <a href="/wiki/Indus_script" title="Indus script">Indus script</a>, which is presently undeciphered.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> This is the reason why <a href="/wiki/Harappan_language" title="Harappan language">Harappan language</a> is not directly attested, and its affiliation uncertain. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> A relationship or membership of the <a href="/wiki/Dravidian_languages" title="Dravidian languages">Dravidian</a> or <a href="/wiki/Elamo-Dravidian_languages" title="Elamo-Dravidian languages">Elamo-Dravidian</a> language family is proposed by some scholars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERatnagar2006a25_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERatnagar2006a25-51">[51]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Indus_script.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="624" data-file-width="985" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Indus_script.jpg/260px-Indus_script.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Indus_script.jpg/390px-Indus_script.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Indus_script.jpg/520px-Indus_script.jpg 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Indus_script.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Three <a href="/wiki/Stamp_seal" title="Stamp seal">stamp seals</a> and their impressions bearing Indus script characters alongside animals: "unicorn" (left), bull (center), and elephant (right); <a href="/wiki/Guimet_Museum" title="Guimet Museum">Guimet Museum</a></div></div></div>
<p>After the collapse of Indus Valley civilisation, the inhabitants of the Indus Valley civilisation migrated from the river valleys of Indus and Ghaggar-Hakra, towards the Himalayan foothills of Ganga-Yamuna basin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ochre_Coloured_Pottery_culture">Ochre Coloured Pottery culture</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sinauli_chariot_ASI.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1052" data-file-width="1712" decoding="async" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Sinauli_chariot_ASI.jpg/220px-Sinauli_chariot_ASI.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Sinauli_chariot_ASI.jpg/330px-Sinauli_chariot_ASI.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Sinauli_chariot_ASI.jpg/440px-Sinauli_chariot_ASI.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sinauli_chariot_ASI.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sinauli_excavation_site" title="Sinauli excavation site">Sinauli</a> "<i>chariot"</i>, photograph of the <a href="/wiki/Archaeological_Survey_of_India" title="Archaeological Survey of India">Archaeological Survey of India</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>During 2nd millennium BCE, <a href="/wiki/Ochre_Coloured_Pottery_culture" title="Ochre Coloured Pottery culture">Ochre Coloured Pottery culture</a> was in Ganga Yamuna Doab region. These were rural settlement with agriculture and hunting. They were using copper tools such as axes, spears, arrows, and swords. The people had domesticated cattle, goats, sheep, horses, pigs and dogs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> The site gained attention for its <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Age</a> solid-disk wheel carts, found in 2018,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> which were interpreted by some as horse-pulled "<a href="/wiki/Chariot" title="Chariot">chariots</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chariot_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-chariot-60">[note 1]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Iron_Age_.28c._1800_.E2.80.93_200_BCE.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Iron_Age_(c._1800_–_200_BCE)">Iron Age (c. 1800 – 200 BCE)</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age_in_India" title="Iron Age in India">Iron Age in India</a></div>
<h3><span id="Vedic_period_.28c._1500_.E2.80.93_600_BCE.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Vedic_period_(c._1500_–_600_BCE)">Vedic period (c. 1500 – 600 BCE)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Vedic_period" title="Vedic period">Vedic period</a>, <a href="/wiki/Historical_Vedic_religion" title="Historical Vedic religion">Historical Vedic religion</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedas</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_peoples" title="Indo-Aryan peoples">Indo-Aryan peoples</a> and <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_migrations" title="Indo-Aryan migrations">Indo-Aryan migrations</a></div>
<p>Starting ca. 1900 BCE, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rigvedic_tribes" title="Rigvedic tribes">Indo-Aryan tribes</a> moved into the <a href="/wiki/Punjab" title="Punjab">Punjab</a> from <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a> in several <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_migration_theory" title="Indo-Aryan migration theory">waves of migration</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[60]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200431_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200431-62">[61]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Vedic_period" title="Vedic period">Vedic period</a> is the period when the Vedas were composed, the liturgical hymns from the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_peoples" title="Indo-Aryan peoples">Indo-Aryan</a> people. The Vedic culture was located in part of north-west India, while other parts of India had a distinct cultural identity during this period. Many regions of the Indian subcontinent transitioned from the <a href="/wiki/Chalcolithic" title="Chalcolithic">Chalcolithic</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">Iron Age</a> in this period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUpinder_Singh2008255_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUpinder_Singh2008255-63">[62]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Vedic culture is described in the texts of <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedas</a>, still sacred to Hindus, which were orally composed and transmitted in <a href="/wiki/Vedic_Sanskrit" title="Vedic Sanskrit">Vedic Sanskrit</a>. The Vedas are some of the oldest extant texts in India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAntonovaBongard-LevinKotovsky197951_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAntonovaBongard-LevinKotovsky197951-64">[63]</a></sup> The Vedic period, lasting from about 1500 to 500 BCE,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[64]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[65]</a></sup> contributed the foundations of several cultural aspects of the Indian subcontinent.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Vedic_society">Vedic society</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rigveda_MS2097.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1056" data-file-width="1100" decoding="async" height="211" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Rigveda_MS2097.jpg/220px-Rigveda_MS2097.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Rigveda_MS2097.jpg/330px-Rigveda_MS2097.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Rigveda_MS2097.jpg/440px-Rigveda_MS2097.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Rigveda_MS2097.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An early 19th century manuscript in the <a href="/wiki/Devanagari" title="Devanagari">Devanagari</a> script of the <a href="/wiki/Rigveda" title="Rigveda">Rigveda</a>, originally transmitted orally with fidelity<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[66]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Historians have analysed the Vedas to posit a Vedic culture in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Punjab_region" title="Punjab region">Punjab region</a> and the upper <a href="/wiki/Indo-Gangetic_Plain" title="Indo-Gangetic Plain">Gangetic Plain</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUpinder_Singh2008255_63-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUpinder_Singh2008255-63">[62]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Peepal" title="Peepal">peepal</a> tree and cow were sanctified by the time of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atharva_Veda" title="Atharva Veda">Atharva Veda</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[67]</a></sup> Many of the concepts of <a href="/wiki/Indian_philosophy" title="Indian philosophy">Indian philosophy</a> espoused later, like <a href="/wiki/Dharma" title="Dharma">dharma</a>, trace their roots to Vedic antecedents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[68]</a></sup>
</p><p>Early Vedic society is described in the <a href="/wiki/Rigveda" title="Rigveda">Rigveda</a>, the oldest Vedic text, believed to have been compiled during 2nd millennium BCE,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[69]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[70]</a></sup> in the northwestern region of the Indian subcontinent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[71]</a></sup> At this time, Aryan society consisted of largely tribal and pastoral groups, distinct from the Harappan urbanisation which had been abandoned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[72]</a></sup> The early Indo-Aryan presence probably corresponds, in part, to the <a href="/wiki/Ochre_Coloured_Pottery_culture" title="Ochre Coloured Pottery culture">Ochre Coloured Pottery culture</a> in archaeological contexts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReddy2003A11_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReddy2003A11-74">[73]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Witzel1989_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-Witzel1989-75">[74]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the end of the Rigvedic period, the Aryan society began to expand from the northwestern region of the Indian subcontinent, into the western <a href="/wiki/Ganges" title="Ganges">Ganges</a> plain. It became increasingly agricultural and was socially organised around the hierarchy of the four <i><a href="/wiki/Varna_(Hinduism)" title="Varna (Hinduism)">varnas</a></i>, or social classes. This social structure was characterized both by syncretising with the native cultures of northern India,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201048–51,_61–93_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201048–51,_61–93-76">[75]</a></sup> but also eventually by the excluding of some indigenous peoples by labeling their occupations impure.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200441–43_77-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200441–43-77">[76]</a></sup> During this period, many of the previous small tribal units and chiefdoms began to coalesce into <a href="/wiki/Janapada" title="Janapada">Janapadas</a> (monarchical, state-level polities).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUpinder_Singh2008200_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUpinder_Singh2008200-78">[77]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Janapadas">Janapadas</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Janapada" title="Janapada">Janapada</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Ten_Kings" title="Battle of the Ten Kings">Battle of the Ten Kings</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_ancient_Indo-Aryan_peoples_and_tribes" title="List of ancient Indo-Aryan peoples and tribes">List of ancient Indo-Aryan peoples and tribes</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Late_Vedic_Culture_(1100-500_BCE).png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="767" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Late_Vedic_Culture_%281100-500_BCE%29.png/220px-Late_Vedic_Culture_%281100-500_BCE%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Late_Vedic_Culture_%281100-500_BCE%29.png/330px-Late_Vedic_Culture_%281100-500_BCE%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Late_Vedic_Culture_%281100-500_BCE%29.png/440px-Late_Vedic_Culture_%281100-500_BCE%29.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Late_Vedic_Culture_(1100-500_BCE).png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Late Vedic era map showing the boundaries of <a href="/wiki/%C4%80ry%C4%81varta" title="Āryāvarta">Āryāvarta</a> with Janapadas in northern India, beginning of Iron Age kingdoms in India – <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kuru_(kingdom)" title="Kuru (kingdom)">Kuru</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Panchala" title="Panchala">Panchala</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kosala" title="Kosala">Kosala</a>, <a href="/wiki/Videha" title="Videha">Videha</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iron_Age_India" title="Iron Age India">Iron Age</a> in the Indian subcontinent from about 1200 BCE to the 6th century BCE is defined by the rise of <a href="/wiki/Janapada" title="Janapada">Janapadas</a>, which are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Realms" title="Realms">realms</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republics" title="Republics">republics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Monarchy" title="Monarchy">kingdoms</a>—notably the Iron Age Kingdoms of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kuru_(kingdom)" title="Kuru (kingdom)">Kuru</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Panchala" title="Panchala">Panchala</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kosala" title="Kosala">Kosala</a>, <a href="/wiki/Videha" title="Videha">Videha</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lanman1912_79-0"><a href="#cite_note-lanman1912-79">[78]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-potter1974_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-potter1974-80">[79]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Kuru_Kingdom" title="Kuru Kingdom">Kuru Kingdom</a> (c. 1200–450 BCE) was the first state-level society of the Vedic period, corresponding to the beginning of the Iron Age in northwestern India, around 1200–800 BCE,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[80]</a></sup> as well as with the composition of the <a href="/wiki/Atharvaveda" title="Atharvaveda">Atharvaveda</a> (the first Indian text to mention iron, as <span title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration"><i lang="sa-Latn">śyāma ayas</i></span>, literally "black metal").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Witzel_1995_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-Witzel_1995-82">[81]</a></sup> The Kuru state organised the Vedic hymns into collections, and developed the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Srauta" title="Srauta">srauta</a> ritual to uphold the social order.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Witzel_1995_82-1"><a href="#cite_note-Witzel_1995-82">[81]</a></sup> Two key figures of the Kuru state were king <a href="/wiki/Parikshit" title="Parikshit">Parikshit</a> and his successor <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Janamejaya_II" title="Janamejaya II">Janamejaya</a>, transforming this realm into the dominant political, social, and cultural power of northern Iron Age India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Witzel_1995_82-2"><a href="#cite_note-Witzel_1995-82">[81]</a></sup> When the Kuru kingdom declined, the centre of Vedic culture shifted to their eastern neighbours, the Panchala kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Witzel_1995_82-3"><a href="#cite_note-Witzel_1995-82">[81]</a></sup> The archaeological <a href="/wiki/Painted_Grey_Ware_culture" title="Painted Grey Ware culture">PGW</a> (Painted Grey Ware) culture, which flourished in the <a href="/wiki/Haryana" title="Haryana">Haryana</a> and western <a href="/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh" title="Uttar Pradesh">Uttar Pradesh</a> regions of northern India from about 1100 to 600 BCE,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReddy2003A11_74-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReddy2003A11-74">[73]</a></sup> is believed to correspond to the <a href="/wiki/Kuru_Kingdom" title="Kuru Kingdom">Kuru</a> and Panchala kingdoms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Witzel_1995_82-4"><a href="#cite_note-Witzel_1995-82">[81]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201045–51_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201045–51-83">[82]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the Late Vedic Period, the kingdom of <a href="/wiki/Videha" title="Videha">Videha</a> emerged as a new centre of Vedic culture, situated even farther to the East (in what is today Nepal and <a href="/wiki/Bihar" title="Bihar">Bihar</a> state in India);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Witzel1989_75-1"><a href="#cite_note-Witzel1989-75">[74]</a></sup> reaching its prominence under the king <a href="/wiki/Janaka" title="Janaka">Janaka</a>, whose court provided patronage for <a href="/wiki/Brahmin" title="Brahmin">Brahmin</a> sages and <a href="/wiki/Indian_philosophy" title="Indian philosophy">philosophers</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Yajnavalkya" title="Yajnavalkya">Yajnavalkya</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aruni" title="Aruni">Aruni</a>, and <a href="/wiki/G%C4%81rg%C4%AB_V%C4%81chaknav%C4%AB" title="Gārgī Vāchaknavī">Gārgī Vāchaknavī</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[83]</a></sup> The later part of this period corresponds with a consolidation of increasingly large states and kingdoms, called <i><a href="/wiki/Mahajanapadas" title="Mahajanapadas">Mahajanapadas</a></i>, all across Northern India.
</p>
<h3><span id="Second_urbanisation_.28c._600_.E2.80.93_200_BCE.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Second_urbanisation_(c._600_–_200_BCE)">Second urbanisation (c. 600 – 200 BCE)</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:City_of_Kushinagar_in_the_5th_century_BCE_according_to_a_1st_century_BCE_frieze_in_Sanchi_Stupa_1_Southern_Gate.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="805" data-file-width="1427" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/City_of_Kushinagar_in_the_5th_century_BCE_according_to_a_1st_century_BCE_frieze_in_Sanchi_Stupa_1_Southern_Gate.jpg/220px-City_of_Kushinagar_in_the_5th_century_BCE_according_to_a_1st_century_BCE_frieze_in_Sanchi_Stupa_1_Southern_Gate.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/City_of_Kushinagar_in_the_5th_century_BCE_according_to_a_1st_century_BCE_frieze_in_Sanchi_Stupa_1_Southern_Gate.jpg/330px-City_of_Kushinagar_in_the_5th_century_BCE_according_to_a_1st_century_BCE_frieze_in_Sanchi_Stupa_1_Southern_Gate.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/City_of_Kushinagar_in_the_5th_century_BCE_according_to_a_1st_century_BCE_frieze_in_Sanchi_Stupa_1_Southern_Gate.jpg/440px-City_of_Kushinagar_in_the_5th_century_BCE_according_to_a_1st_century_BCE_frieze_in_Sanchi_Stupa_1_Southern_Gate.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:City_of_Kushinagar_in_the_5th_century_BCE_according_to_a_1st_century_BCE_frieze_in_Sanchi_Stupa_1_Southern_Gate.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>City of Kushinagar in the 5th century BCE according to a 1st-century BCE frieze in Sanchi Stupa 1 Southern Gate.</div></div></div>
<p>Sometime between 800 and 200 BCE the <i><a href="/wiki/%C5%9Arama%E1%B9%87a" title="Śramaṇa">Śramaṇa</a></i> movement formed, from which originated <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a>. In the same period, the first <a href="/wiki/Upanishads" title="Upanishads">Upanishads</a> were written. After 500 BCE, the so-called "second urbanisation" started, with new urban settlements arising at the Ganges plain, especially the Central Ganges plain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel2010_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel2010-85">[84]</a></sup> The foundations for the "second urbanisation" were laid prior to 600 BCE, in the <a href="/wiki/Painted_Grey_Ware_culture" title="Painted Grey Ware culture">Painted Grey Ware culture</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Ghaggar-Hakra_River" title="Ghaggar-Hakra River">Ghaggar-Hakra</a> and Upper Ganges Plain; although most <a href="/wiki/Painted_Grey_Ware_culture" title="Painted Grey Ware culture">PGW</a> sites were small farming villages, "several dozen" PGW sites eventually emerged as relatively large settlements that can be characterized as towns, the largest of which were fortified by ditches or moats and embankments made of piled earth with wooden palisades, albeit smaller and simpler than the elaborately fortified large cities which grew after 600 BCE in the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Black_Polished_Ware" title="Northern Black Polished Ware">Northern Black Polished Ware</a> culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[85]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Central Ganges Plain, where <a href="/wiki/Magadha" title="Magadha">Magadha</a> gained prominence, forming the base of the <a href="/wiki/Maurya_Empire" title="Maurya Empire">Maurya Empire</a>, was a distinct cultural area,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201048–51_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201048–51-87">[86]</a></sup> with new states arising after 500 BCE<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB-Beginning_historical_period_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-EB-Beginning_historical_period-88">[87]</a></sup> during the so-called "second urbanisation".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201042–48_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201042–48-89">[88]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[note 2]</a></sup> It was influenced by the Vedic culture,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201061_91-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201061-91">[89]</a></sup> but differed markedly from the Kuru-Panchala region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201048–51_87-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201048–51-87">[86]</a></sup> It "was the area of the earliest known cultivation of rice in South Asia and by 1800 BCE was the location of an advanced Neolithic population associated with the sites of Chirand and Chechar".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201049_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201049-92">[90]</a></sup> In this region, the Śramaṇic movements flourished, and Jainism and Buddhism originated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel2010_85-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel2010-85">[84]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Buddhism_and_Jainism">Buddhism and Jainism</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Upanishads" title="Upanishads">Upanishads</a> and <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Arama%E1%B9%87a" title="Śramaṇa">Śramaṇa</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Hinduism" title="History of Hinduism">History of Hinduism</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Buddhism" title="History of Buddhism">History of Buddhism</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Jainism" title="History of Jainism">History of Jainism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indian_religions" title="Indian religions">Indian religions</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Indian_philosophy" title="Indian philosophy">Indian philosophy</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader">Upanishads and Śramaṇa movements</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:290px;max-width:290px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:119px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MS_Indic_37,_Isa_upanisad._Wellcome_L0027330.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="880" data-file-width="2128" decoding="async" height="119" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/MS_Indic_37%2C_Isa_upanisad._Wellcome_L0027330.jpg/288px-MS_Indic_37%2C_Isa_upanisad._Wellcome_L0027330.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/MS_Indic_37%2C_Isa_upanisad._Wellcome_L0027330.jpg/432px-MS_Indic_37%2C_Isa_upanisad._Wellcome_L0027330.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/MS_Indic_37%2C_Isa_upanisad._Wellcome_L0027330.jpg/576px-MS_Indic_37%2C_Isa_upanisad._Wellcome_L0027330.jpg 2x" width="288"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">A page of <i><a href="/wiki/Isha_Upanishad" title="Isha Upanishad">Isha Upanishad</a></i> manuscript.</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:115px;max-width:115px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:128px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vardhaman_Keezhakuyilkudi.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="3035" decoding="async" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Vardhaman_Keezhakuyilkudi.jpg/113px-Vardhaman_Keezhakuyilkudi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Vardhaman_Keezhakuyilkudi.jpg/170px-Vardhaman_Keezhakuyilkudi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Vardhaman_Keezhakuyilkudi.jpg/226px-Vardhaman_Keezhakuyilkudi.jpg 2x" width="113"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Mahavira" title="Mahavira">Mahavira</a>, the 24th and last <a href="/wiki/Tirthankara" title="Tirthankara">Tirthankara</a> of <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a>.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:173px;max-width:173px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:128px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Buddha%27s_cremation_stupa,_Kushinagar.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="128" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Buddha%27s_cremation_stupa%2C_Kushinagar.jpg/171px-Buddha%27s_cremation_stupa%2C_Kushinagar.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Buddha%27s_cremation_stupa%2C_Kushinagar.jpg/257px-Buddha%27s_cremation_stupa%2C_Kushinagar.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Buddha%27s_cremation_stupa%2C_Kushinagar.jpg/342px-Buddha%27s_cremation_stupa%2C_Kushinagar.jpg 2x" width="171"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">Gautama Buddha</a>'s cremation stupa, <a href="/wiki/Kushinagar" title="Kushinagar">Kushinagar</a> (Kushinara).</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The time between 800 BCE and 400 BCE witnessed the composition of the earliest <a href="/wiki/Upanishads" title="Upanishads">Upanishads</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Flood_1996_82_4-1"><a href="#cite_note-Flood_1996_82-4">[4]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mascaró1965_93-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mascaró1965-93">[91]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[92]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Upanishads" title="Upanishads">Upanishads</a> form the theoretical basis of <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">classical Hinduism</a>, and are also known as <a href="/wiki/Vedanta" title="Vedanta">Vedanta</a> (conclusion of the <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedas</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[93]</a></sup>
</p><p>Increasing urbanisation of India in 7th and 6th centuries BCE led to the rise of new ascetic or "Śramaṇa movements" which challenged the orthodoxy of rituals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Flood_1996_82_4-2"><a href="#cite_note-Flood_1996_82-4">[4]</a></sup> Mahavira (c. 549–477 BCE), proponent of <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">Gautama Buddha</a> (c. 563–483 BCE), founder of Buddhism, were the most prominent icons of this movement. Śramaṇa gave rise to the concept of the cycle of birth and death, the concept of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Samsara" title="Samsara">samsara</a>, and the concept of liberation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[94]</a></sup> Buddha found a <a href="/wiki/Middle_Way" title="Middle Way">Middle Way</a> that ameliorated the extreme <a href="/wiki/Asceticism" title="Asceticism">asceticism</a> found in the <i><a href="/wiki/%C5%9Arama%E1%B9%87a" title="Śramaṇa">Śramaṇa</a></i> religions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[95]</a></sup>
</p><p>Around the same time, <a href="/wiki/Mahavira" title="Mahavira">Mahavira</a> (the 24th <i><a href="/wiki/Tirthankara" title="Tirthankara">Tirthankara</a></i> in Jainism) propagated a theology that was to later become Jainism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[96]</a></sup> However, Jain orthodoxy believes the teachings of the <i>Tirthankaras</i> predates all known time and scholars believe <a href="/wiki/Parshvanatha" title="Parshvanatha">Parshvanatha</a> (c. 872 – c. 772 BCE), accorded status as the 23rd <i>Tirthankara</i>, was a historical figure. The Vedas are believed to have documented a few <i>Tirthankaras</i> and an ascetic order similar to the <i>Śramaṇa</i> movement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[97]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Sanskrit_epics">Sanskrit epics</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Mahabharata" title="Mahabharata">Mahabharata</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ramayana" title="Ramayana">Ramayana</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_historic_Indian_texts" title="List of historic Indian texts">List of historic Indian texts</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Hindu_texts" title="List of Hindu texts">List of Hindu texts</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kurukshetra.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="428" data-file-width="614" decoding="async" height="174" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Kurukshetra.jpg/250px-Kurukshetra.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Kurukshetra.jpg/375px-Kurukshetra.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Kurukshetra.jpg/500px-Kurukshetra.jpg 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kurukshetra.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Manuscript illustration of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_Kurukshetra" title="Battle of Kurukshetra">Battle of Kurukshetra</a>.</div></div></div>
