<p>The Sanskrit epics <i><a href="/wiki/Ramayana" title="Ramayana">Ramayana</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Mahabharata" title="Mahabharata">Mahabharata</a></i> were composed during this period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[98]</a></sup> The <i>Mahabharata</i> remains, till this day, the longest single poem in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[99]</a></sup> Historians formerly postulated an "epic age" as the milieu of these two epic poems, but now recognize that the texts (which are both familiar with each other) went through multiple stages of development over centuries. For instance, the <i>Mahabharata</i> may have been based on a small-scale conflict (possibly about 1000 BCE) which was eventually "transformed into a gigantic epic war by bards and poets". There is no conclusive proof from archaeology as to whether the specific events of the Mahabharata have any historical basis.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUpinder_Singh200818–21_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUpinder_Singh200818–21-102">[100]</a></sup> The existing texts of these epics are believed to belong to the post-Vedic age, between c. 400 BCE and 400 CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUpinder_Singh200818–21_102-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUpinder_Singh200818–21-102">[100]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[101]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Mahajanapadas">Mahajanapadas</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mahajanapadas" title="Mahajanapadas">Mahajanapadas</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mahajanapadas_(c._500_BCE).png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="771" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="170" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Mahajanapadas_%28c._500_BCE%29.png/220px-Mahajanapadas_%28c._500_BCE%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Mahajanapadas_%28c._500_BCE%29.png/330px-Mahajanapadas_%28c._500_BCE%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Mahajanapadas_%28c._500_BCE%29.png/440px-Mahajanapadas_%28c._500_BCE%29.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mahajanapadas_(c._500_BCE).png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Mahajanapadas" title="Mahajanapadas">Mahajanapadas</a> were the sixteen most powerful and vast kingdoms and republics of the era, located mainly across the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indo-Gangetic_plains" title="Indo-Gangetic plains">Indo-Gangetic plains</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The period from c. 600 BCE to c. 300 BCE witnessed the rise of the <a href="/wiki/Mahajanapadas" title="Mahajanapadas">Mahajanapadas</a>, sixteen powerful and vast <a href="/wiki/Realm" title="Realm">kingdoms</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oligarchy" title="Oligarchy">oligarchic</a> <a href="/wiki/Republic" title="Republic">republics</a>. These Mahajanapadas evolved and flourished in a belt stretching from <a href="/wiki/Gandhara" title="Gandhara">Gandhara</a> in the northwest to <a href="/wiki/Bengal" title="Bengal">Bengal</a> in the eastern part of the Indian subcontinent and included parts of the trans-<a href="/wiki/Vindhya_Range" title="Vindhya Range">Vindhyan</a> region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUpinder_Singh2008260–264_104-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUpinder_Singh2008260–264-104">[102]</a></sup> Ancient <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_texts" title="Buddhist texts">Buddhist texts</a>, like the <i><a href="/wiki/A%E1%B9%85guttara_Nik%C4%81ya" title="Aṅguttara Nikāya">Aṅguttara Nikāya</a></i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[103]</a></sup> make frequent reference to these sixteen great kingdoms and republics—<a href="/wiki/Anga" title="Anga">Anga</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Assaka" title="Assaka">Assaka</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Avanti_(India)" title="Avanti (India)">Avanti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chedi_Kingdom" title="Chedi Kingdom">Chedi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gandhara" title="Gandhara">Gandhara</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Kashi" title="Kingdom of Kashi">Kashi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kambojas" title="Kambojas">Kamboja</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kosala" title="Kosala">Kosala</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kuru_(India)" title="Kuru (India)">Kuru</a>, <a href="/wiki/Magadha" title="Magadha">Magadha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malla_(tribe)" title="Malla (tribe)">Malla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Matsya_(tribe)" title="Matsya (tribe)">Matsya</a> (or Machcha), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Panchala" title="Panchala">Panchala</a>, <a href="/wiki/Surasena" title="Surasena">Surasena</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vajjika_League" title="Vajjika League">Vṛji</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vatsa" title="Vatsa">Vatsa</a>. This period saw the second major rise of urbanism in India after the <a href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilisation" title="Indus Valley Civilisation">Indus Valley Civilisation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReddy2003A107_106-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReddy2003A107-106">[104]</a></sup>
</p><p>Early "republics" or <a href="/wiki/Ga%E1%B9%87asa%E1%B9%85gha" title="Gaṇasaṅgha"><span title="Sanskrit-language romanization"><i lang="sa-Latn">gaṇasaṅgha</i></span></a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thapar_107-0"><a href="#cite_note-Thapar-107">[105]</a></sup> such as <a href="/wiki/Shakya" title="Shakya">Shakyas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Koliya" title="Koliya">Koliyas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malla_(tribe)" title="Malla (tribe)">Mallakas</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Licchavi_(tribe)" title="Licchavi (tribe)">Licchavis</a> had republican governments. <span title="Sanskrit-language romanization"><i lang="sa-Latn">Gaṇasaṅgha</i></span>s,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thapar_107-1"><a href="#cite_note-Thapar-107">[105]</a></sup> such as the Mallakas, centered in the city of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kusinagara" title="Kusinagara">Kusinagara</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Vajjika_League" title="Vajjika League">Vajjika League</a>, centered in the city of <a href="/wiki/Vaishali_(ancient_city)" title="Vaishali (ancient city)">Vaishali</a>, existed as early as the 6th century BCE and persisted in some areas until the 4th century CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[106]</a></sup> The most famous clan amongst the ruling confederate clans of the Vajji Mahajanapada were the <a href="/wiki/Licchavi_(tribe)" title="Licchavi (tribe)">Licchavis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[107]</a></sup>
</p><p>This period corresponds in an archaeological context to the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Black_Polished_Ware" title="Northern Black Polished Ware">Northern Black Polished Ware</a> culture. Especially focused in the Central Ganges plain but also spreading across vast areas of the northern and central Indian subcontinent, this culture is characterized by the emergence of large cities with massive fortifications, significant population growth, increased social stratification, wide-ranging trade networks, construction of public architecture and water channels, specialized craft industries (e.g., ivory and carnelian carving), a system of weights, <a href="/wiki/Punch-marked_coins" title="Punch-marked coins">punch-marked coins</a>, and the introduction of writing in the form of <a href="/wiki/Brahmi_script" title="Brahmi script">Brahmi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kharosthi" title="Kharosthi">Kharosthi</a> scripts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[108]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[109]</a></sup> The language of the gentry at that time was <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a>, while the languages of the general population of northern India are referred to as <a href="/wiki/Prakrit" title="Prakrit">Prakrits</a>.
</p><p>Many of the sixteen kingdoms had coalesced into four major ones by 500/400 BCE, by the time of <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">Gautama Buddha</a>. These four were Vatsa, Avanti, Kosala, and Magadha. The life of Gautama Buddha was mainly associated with these four kingdoms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReddy2003A107_106-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReddy2003A107-106">[104]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_Magadha_dynasties">Early Magadha dynasties</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Magadha" title="Magadha">Magadha</a> and <a href="/wiki/Greater_Magadha" title="Greater Magadha">Greater Magadha</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Pradyota_dynasty" title="Pradyota dynasty">Pradyota dynasty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Haryanka_dynasty" title="Haryanka dynasty">Haryanka dynasty</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Shaishunaga_dynasty" title="Shaishunaga dynasty">Shaishunaga dynasty</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:392px;max-width:392px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader">Maghada dynasties</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:270px;max-width:270px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:206px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Magadha_Expansion_(6th-4th_centuries_BCE).png"><img alt="" data-file-height="771" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="207" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Magadha_Expansion_%286th-4th_centuries_BCE%29.png/268px-Magadha_Expansion_%286th-4th_centuries_BCE%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Magadha_Expansion_%286th-4th_centuries_BCE%29.png/402px-Magadha_Expansion_%286th-4th_centuries_BCE%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Magadha_Expansion_%286th-4th_centuries_BCE%29.png/536px-Magadha_Expansion_%286th-4th_centuries_BCE%29.png 2x" width="268"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">The Magadha state c. 600 BCE, before it expanded from its capital <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rajagriha" title="Rajagriha">Rajagriha</a> – under the <a href="/wiki/Haryanka_dynasty" title="Haryanka dynasty">Haryanka dynasty</a> and the successor <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shishunaga_dynasty" title="Shishunaga dynasty">Shishunaga dynasty</a>.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:118px;max-width:118px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:206px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Xerxes_Hidush_warrior_480_BCE.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1282" data-file-width="723" decoding="async" height="206" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Xerxes_Hidush_warrior_480_BCE.jpg/116px-Xerxes_Hidush_warrior_480_BCE.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Xerxes_Hidush_warrior_480_BCE.jpg/174px-Xerxes_Hidush_warrior_480_BCE.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Xerxes_Hidush_warrior_480_BCE.jpg/232px-Xerxes_Hidush_warrior_480_BCE.jpg 2x" width="116"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">Indian warrior of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Achaemenid_army" title="Achaemenid army">Achaemenid army</a>, circa 480 BCE, on the <a href="/wiki/Tomb_of_Xerxes_I" title="Tomb of Xerxes I">Tomb of Xerxes I</a>.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Magadha formed one of the sixteen <a href="/wiki/Mahajanapadas" title="Mahajanapadas">Mahajanapadas</a> (<a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a>: "Great Realms") or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdoms_of_Ancient_India" title="Kingdoms of Ancient India">kingdoms in ancient India</a>. The core of the kingdom was the area of <a href="/wiki/Bihar" title="Bihar">Bihar</a> south of the <a href="/wiki/Ganges" title="Ganges">Ganges</a>; its first capital was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rajagriha" title="Rajagriha">Rajagriha</a> (modern Rajgir) then <a href="/wiki/Pataliputra" title="Pataliputra">Pataliputra</a> (modern <a href="/wiki/Patna" title="Patna">Patna</a>). Magadha expanded to include most of Bihar and Bengal with the conquest of <a href="/wiki/Licchavi_(kingdom)" title="Licchavi (kingdom)">Licchavi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anga" title="Anga">Anga</a> respectively,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ramesh_Chandra_Majumdar_(1977)_112-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ramesh_Chandra_Majumdar_(1977)-112">[110]</a></sup> followed by much of eastern Uttar Pradesh and Orissa. The ancient kingdom of Magadha is heavily mentioned in Jain and Buddhist texts. It is also mentioned in the <a href="/wiki/Ramayana" title="Ramayana">Ramayana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mahabharata" title="Mahabharata">Mahabharata</a> and <a href="/wiki/Puranas" title="Puranas">Puranas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[111]</a></sup> The earliest reference to the Magadha people occurs in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atharva-Veda" title="Atharva-Veda">Atharva-Veda</a> where they are found listed along with the <a href="/wiki/Anga" title="Anga">Angas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gandhara" title="Gandhara">Gandharis</a>, and Mujavats. Magadha played an important role in the development of <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a> and Buddhism. The Magadha kingdom included republican communities such as the community of Rajakumara. Villages had their own assemblies under their local chiefs called Gramakas. Their administrations were divided into executive, judicial, and military functions.
</p><p>Early sources, from the Buddhist <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/P%C4%81li_Canon" title="Pāli Canon">Pāli Canon</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jain_Agamas_(%C5%9Av%C4%93t%C4%81mbara)" title="Jain Agamas (Śvētāmbara)">Jain Agamas</a> and the Hindu <a href="/wiki/Puranas" title="Puranas">Puranas</a>, mention Magadha being ruled by the <a href="/wiki/Pradyota_dynasty" title="Pradyota dynasty">Pradyota dynasty</a> and <a href="/wiki/Haryanka_dynasty" title="Haryanka dynasty">Haryanka dynasty</a> (c. 544–413 BCE) for some 200 years, c. 600–413 BCE. King <a href="/wiki/Bimbisara" title="Bimbisara">Bimbisara</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Haryanka_dynasty" title="Haryanka dynasty">Haryanka dynasty</a> led an active and expansive policy, conquering Anga in what is now eastern Bihar and <a href="/wiki/West_Bengal" title="West Bengal">West Bengal</a>. King Bimbisara was overthrown and killed by his son, Prince <a href="/wiki/Ajatashatru" title="Ajatashatru">Ajatashatru</a>, who continued the expansionist policy of Magadha. During this period, <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">Gautama Buddha</a>, the founder of Buddhism, lived much of his life in Magadha kingdom. He attained enlightenment in <a href="/wiki/Bodh_Gaya" title="Bodh Gaya">Bodh Gaya</a>, gave his first sermon in <a href="/wiki/Sarnath" title="Sarnath">Sarnath</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_councils" title="Buddhist councils">first Buddhist council</a> was held in Rajgriha.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lumbinitrust_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-lumbinitrust-114">[112]</a></sup> The Haryanka dynasty was overthrown by the <a href="/wiki/Shaishunaga_dynasty" title="Shaishunaga dynasty">Shaishunaga dynasty</a> (c. 413–345 BCE). The last Shishunaga ruler, <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Kalasoka&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Kalasoka (page does not exist)">Kalasoka</a>, was assassinated by <a href="/wiki/Mahapadma_Nanda" title="Mahapadma Nanda">Mahapadma Nanda</a> in 345 BCE, the first of the so-called Nine Nandas, which were Mahapadma and his eight sons.
</p>
<h4><span id="Nanda_Empire_and_Alexander.27s_campaign"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Nanda_Empire_and_Alexander's_campaign">Nanda Empire and Alexander's campaign</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Nanda_Empire" title="Nanda Empire">Nanda Empire</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Indian_campaign_of_Alexander_the_Great" title="Indian campaign of Alexander the Great">Indian campaign of Alexander the Great</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Nanda_Empire" title="Nanda Empire">Nanda Empire</a> (c. 345–322 BCE), at its greatest extent, extended from Bengal in the east, to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Punjab_region" title="Punjab region">Punjab region</a> in the west and as far south as the <a href="/wiki/Vindhya_Range" title="Vindhya Range">Vindhya Range</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMookerji198828–33_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMookerji198828–33-115">[113]</a></sup> The Nanda dynasty was famed for their great wealth. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nanda_dynasty" title="Nanda dynasty">Nanda dynasty</a> built on the foundations laid by their <a href="/wiki/Haryanka_dynasty" title="Haryanka dynasty">Haryanka</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shishunaga_dynasty" title="Shishunaga dynasty">Shishunaga</a> predecessors to create the first great empire of <a href="/wiki/North_India" title="North India">north India</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUpinder_Singh2008273_116-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUpinder_Singh2008273-116">[114]</a></sup> To achieve this objective they built a vast army, consisting of 200,000 <a href="/wiki/Infantry" title="Infantry">infantry</a>, 20,000 <a href="/wiki/Cavalry" title="Cavalry">cavalry</a>, 2,000 war <a href="/wiki/Chariot" title="Chariot">chariots</a> and 3,000 <a href="/wiki/War_elephant" title="War elephant">war elephants</a> (at the lowest estimates).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMookerji198834_117-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMookerji198834-117">[115]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sastri1988p16_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sastri1988p16-118">[116]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[117]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">Greek</a> historian <a href="/wiki/Plutarch" title="Plutarch">Plutarch</a>, the size of the Nanda army was even larger, numbering 200,000 infantry, 80,000 cavalry, 8,000 war chariots, and 6,000 war elephants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sastri1988p16_118-1"><a href="#cite_note-Sastri1988p16-118">[116]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[118]</a></sup> However, the Nanda Empire did not have the opportunity to see their army face <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a>, who invaded north-western India at the time of <a href="/wiki/Dhana_Nanda" title="Dhana Nanda">Dhana Nanda</a>, since Alexander was forced to confine <a href="/wiki/Indian_campaign_of_Alexander_the_Great" title="Indian campaign of Alexander the Great">his campaign</a> to the plains of <a href="/wiki/Punjab" title="Punjab">Punjab</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sindh" title="Sindh">Sindh</a>, for his forces mutinied at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/River_Beas" title="River Beas">river Beas</a> and refused to go any further upon encountering Nanda and Gangaridai forces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sastri1988p16_118-2"><a href="#cite_note-Sastri1988p16-118">[116]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Maurya_Empire">Maurya Empire</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Maurya_Empire" title="Maurya Empire">Maurya Empire</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:392px;max-width:392px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader">Maurya Empire</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:173px;max-width:173px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:159px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Maurya_Empire,_c.250_BCE.png"><img alt="" data-file-height="1121" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Maurya_Empire%2C_c.250_BCE.png/171px-Maurya_Empire%2C_c.250_BCE.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Maurya_Empire%2C_c.250_BCE.png/257px-Maurya_Empire%2C_c.250_BCE.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Maurya_Empire%2C_c.250_BCE.png/342px-Maurya_Empire%2C_c.250_BCE.png 2x" width="171"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">The <a href="/wiki/Maurya_Empire" title="Maurya Empire">Maurya Empire</a> under <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ashoka_the_Great" title="Ashoka the Great">Ashoka the Great</a>.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:215px;max-width:215px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:159px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ashoka_pillar_at_Vaishali,_Bihar,_India.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1704" data-file-width="2272" decoding="async" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Ashoka_pillar_at_Vaishali%2C_Bihar%2C_India.jpg/213px-Ashoka_pillar_at_Vaishali%2C_Bihar%2C_India.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Ashoka_pillar_at_Vaishali%2C_Bihar%2C_India.jpg/320px-Ashoka_pillar_at_Vaishali%2C_Bihar%2C_India.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Ashoka_pillar_at_Vaishali%2C_Bihar%2C_India.jpg/426px-Ashoka_pillar_at_Vaishali%2C_Bihar%2C_India.jpg 2x" width="213"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ashokan_pillar" title="Ashokan pillar">Ashokan pillar</a> at <a href="/wiki/Vaishali_(ancient_city)" title="Vaishali (ancient city)">Vaishali</a>, 3rd century BCE.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The Maurya Empire (322–185 BCE) unified most of the Indian subcontinent into one state, and was the largest empire ever to exist on the Indian subcontinent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Peter_2006_121-0"><a href="#cite_note-Peter_2006-121">[119]</a></sup> At its greatest extent, the Mauryan Empire stretched to the north up to the natural boundaries of the <a href="/wiki/Himalayas" title="Himalayas">Himalayas</a> and to the east into what is now <a href="/wiki/Assam" title="Assam">Assam</a>. To the west, it reached beyond modern Pakistan, to the <a href="/wiki/Hindu_Kush" title="Hindu Kush">Hindu Kush</a> mountains in what is now Afghanistan. The empire was established by <a href="/wiki/Chandragupta_Maurya" title="Chandragupta Maurya">Chandragupta Maurya</a> assisted by Chanakya (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kautilya" title="Kautilya">Kautilya</a>) in <a href="/wiki/Magadha" title="Magadha">Magadha</a> (in modern <a href="/wiki/Bihar" title="Bihar">Bihar</a>) when he overthrew the <a href="/wiki/Nanda_Empire" title="Nanda Empire">Nanda Empire</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[120]</a></sup>
</p><p>Chandragupta rapidly expanded his power westwards across central and western India, and by 317 BCE the empire had fully occupied Northwestern India. The Mauryan Empire then defeated <a href="/wiki/Seleucus_I_Nicator" title="Seleucus I Nicator">Seleucus I</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Diadochi" title="Diadochi">diadochus</a> and founder of the <a href="/wiki/Seleucid_Empire" title="Seleucid Empire">Seleucid Empire</a>, during the <a href="/wiki/Seleucid%E2%80%93Mauryan_war" title="Seleucid–Mauryan war">Seleucid–Mauryan war</a>, thus gained additional territory west of the <a href="/wiki/Indus_River" title="Indus River">Indus River</a>. Chandragupta's son <a href="/wiki/Bindusara" title="Bindusara">Bindusara</a> succeeded to the throne around 297 BCE. By the time he died in c. 272 BCE, a large part of the Indian subcontinent was under Mauryan suzerainty. However, the region of <a href="/wiki/Kalinga_(historical_region)" title="Kalinga (historical region)">Kalinga</a> (around modern day <a href="/wiki/Odisha" title="Odisha">Odisha</a>) remained outside Mauryan control, perhaps interfering with their trade with the south.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThapar2003178–180_123-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThapar2003178–180-123">[121]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lomas_Rishi_entrance.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3240" data-file-width="3290" decoding="async" height="217" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Lomas_Rishi_entrance.jpg/220px-Lomas_Rishi_entrance.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Lomas_Rishi_entrance.jpg/330px-Lomas_Rishi_entrance.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Lomas_Rishi_entrance.jpg/440px-Lomas_Rishi_entrance.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lomas_Rishi_entrance.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Mauryan carved door of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lomas_Rishi_cave" title="Lomas Rishi cave">Lomas Rishi</a>, one of the <a href="/wiki/Barabar_Caves" title="Barabar Caves">Barabar Caves</a>, c. 250 BCE.</div></div></div>
<p>Bindusara was succeeded by <a href="/wiki/Ashoka" title="Ashoka">Ashoka</a>, whose reign lasted for around 37 years until his death in about 232 BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThapar2003204–206_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThapar2003204–206-124">[122]</a></sup> His campaign against the Kalingans in about 260 BCE, though successful, led to immense loss of life and misery. This filled Ashoka with remorse and led him to shun violence, and subsequently to embrace Buddhism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThapar2003178–180_123-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThapar2003178–180-123">[121]</a></sup> The empire began to decline after his death and the last Mauryan ruler, <a href="/wiki/Brihadratha_Maurya" title="Brihadratha Maurya">Brihadratha</a>, was assassinated by <a href="/wiki/Pushyamitra_Shunga" title="Pushyamitra Shunga">Pushyamitra Shunga</a> to establish the <a href="/wiki/Shunga_Empire" title="Shunga Empire">Shunga Empire</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThapar2003204–206_124-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThapar2003204–206-124">[122]</a></sup>
</p><p>Under Chandragupta Maurya and his successors, internal and external trade, agriculture, and economic activities all thrived and expanded across India thanks to the creation of a single efficient system of finance, administration, and security. The Mauryans built the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Trunk_Road" title="Grand Trunk Road">Grand Trunk Road</a>, one of <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a>'s oldest and longest major roads connecting the Indian subcontinent with Central Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[123]</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/Kalinga_War" title="Kalinga War">Kalinga War</a>, the Empire experienced nearly half a century of peace and security under Ashoka. Mauryan India also enjoyed an era of social harmony, religious transformation, and expansion of the sciences and of knowledge. Chandragupta Maurya's embrace of <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a> increased social and religious renewal and reform across his society, while Ashoka's embrace of Buddhism has been said to have been the foundation of the reign of social and political peace and non-violence across all of India. Ashoka sponsored the spreading of Buddhist missionaries into <a href="/wiki/Sri_Lanka" title="Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Southeast_Asia" title="Buddhism in Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/West_Asia" title="West Asia">West Asia</a>, <a href="/wiki/North_Africa" title="North Africa">North Africa</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Southern_Europe" title="Southern Europe">Mediterranean Europe</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200467_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200467-126">[124]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <i><a href="/wiki/Arthashastra" title="Arthashastra">Arthashastra</a></i> wrote by <a href="/wiki/Chanakya" title="Chanakya">Chanakya</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Edicts_of_Ashoka" title="Edicts of Ashoka">Edicts of Ashoka</a> are the primary written records of the Mauryan times. Archaeologically, this period falls into the era of <a href="/wiki/Northern_Black_Polished_Ware" title="Northern Black Polished Ware">Northern Black Polished Ware</a>. The Mauryan Empire was based on a modern and efficient economy and society. However, the sale of merchandise was closely regulated by the government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[125]</a></sup> Although there was no banking in the Mauryan society, usury was customary. A significant amount of written records on slavery are found, suggesting a prevalence thereof.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAntonovaBongard-LevinKotovsky197991_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAntonovaBongard-LevinKotovsky197991-128">[126]</a></sup> During this period, a high quality steel called <a href="/wiki/Wootz_steel" title="Wootz steel">Wootz steel</a> was developed in south India and was later exported to China and Arabia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Menon_R.V.G_p.15_8-1"><a href="#cite_note-Menon_R.V.G_p.15-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Sangam_period">Sangam period</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Sangam_period" title="Sangam period">Sangam period</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sources_of_ancient_Tamil_history" title="Sources of ancient Tamil history">Sources of ancient Tamil history</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sangam_literature" title="Sangam literature">Sangam literature</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Five_Great_Epics" title="Five Great Epics">Five Great Epics</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Three_Crowned_Kings" title="Three Crowned Kings">Three Crowned Kings</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tamilakam" title="Tamilakam">Tamilakam</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Tamil_monarchs" title="List of Tamil monarchs">List of Tamil monarchs</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:392px;max-width:392px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:243px;max-width:243px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:214px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:South_India_in_Sangam_Period.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1419" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="214" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/South_India_in_Sangam_Period.jpg/241px-South_India_in_Sangam_Period.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/South_India_in_Sangam_Period.jpg/362px-South_India_in_Sangam_Period.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/South_India_in_Sangam_Period.jpg/482px-South_India_in_Sangam_Period.jpg 2x" width="241"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Tamilakam" title="Tamilakam">Tamilakam</a>, located in the tip of <a href="/wiki/South_India" title="South India">South India</a> during the Sangam period, ruled by <a href="/wiki/Chera_dynasty" title="Chera dynasty">Chera dynasty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chola_dynasty" title="Chola dynasty">Chola dynasty</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pandyan_dynasty" title="Pandyan dynasty">Pandyan dynasty</a>.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:145px;max-width:145px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:214px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Puhar-ILango.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1800" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="215" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Puhar-ILango.jpg/143px-Puhar-ILango.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Puhar-ILango.jpg/215px-Puhar-ILango.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Puhar-ILango.jpg/286px-Puhar-ILango.jpg 2x" width="143"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Ilango_Adigal" title="Ilango Adigal">Ilango Adigal</a> is the author of <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Silappatikaram" title="Silappatikaram">Silappatikaram</a></i>, one of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Five_Great_Epics_of_Tamil_Literature" title="The Five Great Epics of Tamil Literature">five great epics</a> of <a href="/wiki/Tamil_literature" title="Tamil literature">Tamil literature</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[127]</a></sup></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>During the Sangam period <a href="/wiki/Tamil_language" title="Tamil language">Tamil</a> literature flourished from the 3rd century BCE to the 4th century CE. During this period, three Tamil dynasties, collectively known as the <a href="/wiki/Three_Crowned_Kings" title="Three Crowned Kings">Three Crowned Kings</a> of <a href="/wiki/Tamilakam" title="Tamilakam">Tamilakam</a>: <a href="/wiki/Chera_dynasty" title="Chera dynasty">Chera dynasty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chola_dynasty" title="Chola dynasty">Chola dynasty</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Pandya_dynasty" title="Pandya dynasty">Pandya dynasty</a> ruled parts of southern India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESen1999204–205_130-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESen1999204–205-130">[128]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Sangam literature deals with the history, politics, wars, and culture of the Tamil people of this period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[129]</a></sup> The scholars of the Sangam period rose from among the common people who sought the patronage of the Tamil Kings, but who mainly wrote about the common people and their concerns.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_First_Spring_p.655_132-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_First_Spring_p.655-132">[130]</a></sup> Unlike Sanskrit writers who were mostly Brahmins, Sangam writers came from diverse classes and social backgrounds and were mostly non-Brahmins. They belonged to different faiths and professions such as farmers, artisans, merchants, monks, and priests, including also royalty and women.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_First_Spring_p.655_132-1"><a href="#cite_note-The_First_Spring_p.655-132">[130]</a></sup>
</p><p>Around c. 300 BCE – c. 200 CE, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pathupattu" title="Pathupattu">Pathupattu</a>, an anthology of ten mid-length books collection, which is considered part of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sangam_Literature" title="Sangam Literature">Sangam Literature</a>, were composed; the composition of eight anthologies of poetic works <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ettuthogai" title="Ettuthogai">Ettuthogai</a> as well as the composition of eighteen minor poetic works <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pati%E1%B9%89e%E1%B9%87k%C4%AB%E1%B8%BBka%E1%B9%87akku" title="Patiṉeṇkīḻkaṇakku">Patiṉeṇkīḻkaṇakku</a>; while <a href="/wiki/Tolk%C4%81ppiyam" title="Tolkāppiyam">Tolkāppiyam</a>, the earliest grammarian work in the <a href="/wiki/Tamil_language" title="Tamil language">Tamil language</a> was developed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[131]</a></sup> Also, during Sangam period, two of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Five_Great_Epics_of_Tamil_Literature" title="The Five Great Epics of Tamil Literature">the Five Great Epics of Tamil Literature</a> were composed. <a href="/wiki/Ilango_Adigal" title="Ilango Adigal">Ilango Adigal</a> composed <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Silappatikaram" title="Silappatikaram">Silappatikaram</a></i>, which is a non-religious work, that revolves around <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kannagi_(Tamil_mythology)" title="Kannagi (Tamil mythology)">Kannagi</a>, who having lost her husband to a miscarriage of justice at the court of the Pandyan dynasty, wreaks her revenge on his kingdom,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[132]</a></sup> and <i><a href="/wiki/Manimekalai" title="Manimekalai">Manimekalai</a></i>, composed by <a href="/wiki/Chithalai_Chathanar" title="Chithalai Chathanar">Chithalai Chathanar</a>, is a <a href="/wiki/Sequel" title="Sequel">sequel</a> to <i>Silappatikaram</i>, and tells the story of the daughter of <a href="/wiki/Kovalan" title="Kovalan">Kovalan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Madhavi_(Silappatikaram)" title="Madhavi (Silappatikaram)">Madhavi</a>, who became a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhist" title="Buddhist">Buddhist</a> Bikkuni.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Muk1_135-0"><a href="#cite_note-Muk1-135">[133]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[134]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Classical_period_.28c._200_BCE_.E2.80.93_c._650_CE.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Classical_period_(c._200_BCE_–_c._650_CE)">Classical period (c. 200 BCE – c. 650 CE)</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Classical_India" title="Classical India">Classical India</a></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1021810730">@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery{width:100%!important}}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery{display:table}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery-default{background:transparent;margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery-center{margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery-left{float:left}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery-right{float:right}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery-none{float:none}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery-collapsible{width:100%}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .title,.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .main,.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .footer{display:table-row}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .title>div{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0 0.6em 1.6em;text-align:center;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .main>div{display:table-cell}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .gallery{line-height:1.35em}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .footer>div{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0 0.6em 1.6em;text-align:right;font-size:80%;line-height:1em}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .title>div *,.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .footer>div *{overflow:visible}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .gallerybox img{background:none!important}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .bordered-images .thumb img{border:solid #eaecf0 1px}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .whitebg .thumb{background:#fff!important}</style><div class="mod-gallery mod-gallery-default mod-gallery-center"><div class="main"><div><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional nochecker bordered-images whitebg">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 195px"><div style="width: 195px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 190px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:SungaEmpireMap.jpg" title="Ancient India during the rise of the Shungas from the North, Satavahanas from the Deccan, and Pandyas and Cholas from the southern tip of India."><img alt="Ancient India during the rise of the Shungas from the North, Satavahanas from the Deccan, and Pandyas and Cholas from the southern tip of India." data-file-height="1440" data-file-width="1202" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/SungaEmpireMap.jpg/150px-SungaEmpireMap.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/SungaEmpireMap.jpg/225px-SungaEmpireMap.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/SungaEmpireMap.jpg/300px-SungaEmpireMap.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ancient_India" title="Ancient India">Ancient India</a> during the rise of the <a href="/wiki/Shunga_Empire" title="Shunga Empire">Shungas</a> from the North, <a href="/wiki/Satavahana_dynasty" title="Satavahana dynasty">Satavahanas</a> from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Deccan" title="Deccan">Deccan</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pandyan_dynasty" title="Pandyan dynasty">Pandyas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chola_dynasty" title="Chola dynasty">Cholas</a> from the <a href="/wiki/South_India" title="South India">southern tip of India</a>.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 195px"><div style="width: 195px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 190px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Karla_caves_Chaitya.jpg" title="The Great Chaitya in the Karla Caves. The shrines were developed over the period from 2nd century BCE to the 5th century CE."><img alt="The Great Chaitya in the Karla Caves. The shrines were developed over the period from 2nd century BCE to the 5th century CE." data-file-height="1620" data-file-width="1080" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Karla_caves_Chaitya.jpg/120px-Karla_caves_Chaitya.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Karla_caves_Chaitya.jpg/180px-Karla_caves_Chaitya.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Karla_caves_Chaitya.jpg/240px-Karla_caves_Chaitya.jpg 2x" width="120"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>The Great Chaitya in the <a href="/wiki/Karla_Caves" title="Karla Caves">Karla Caves</a>. The shrines were developed over the period from 2nd century BCE to the 5th century CE.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 195px"><div style="width: 195px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 190px;"><div style="margin:51.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Udayagiri_Caves_-_Rani_Gumpha_01.jpg" title="Udayagiri and Khandagiri Caves is home to the Hathigumpha inscription, which was inscribed under Kharavela, the then Emperor of Kalinga of the Mahameghavahana dynasty."><img alt="Udayagiri and Khandagiri Caves is home to the Hathigumpha inscription, which was inscribed under Kharavela, the then Emperor of Kalinga of the Mahameghavahana dynasty." data-file-height="3368" data-file-width="5053" decoding="async" height="107" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Udayagiri_Caves_-_Rani_Gumpha_01.jpg/160px-Udayagiri_Caves_-_Rani_Gumpha_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Udayagiri_Caves_-_Rani_Gumpha_01.jpg/240px-Udayagiri_Caves_-_Rani_Gumpha_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Udayagiri_Caves_-_Rani_Gumpha_01.jpg/320px-Udayagiri_Caves_-_Rani_Gumpha_01.jpg 2x" width="160"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Udayagiri_and_Khandagiri_Caves" title="Udayagiri and Khandagiri Caves">Udayagiri and Khandagiri Caves</a> is home to the <a href="/wiki/Hathigumpha_inscription" title="Hathigumpha inscription">Hathigumpha inscription</a>, which was inscribed under <a href="/wiki/Kharavela" title="Kharavela">Kharavela</a>, the then Emperor of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kalinga_(historical_kingdom)" title="Kalinga (historical kingdom)">Kalinga</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Mahameghavahana_dynasty" title="Mahameghavahana dynasty">Mahameghavahana dynasty</a>.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 195px"><div style="width: 195px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 190px;"><div style="margin:27.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Andhra_pradesh,_santuario_a_pi%C3%B9_piani,_da_ghantasala,_90-110_ca..JPG" title="Relief of a multi-storied temple, 2nd century CE, Ghantasala Stupa.[135][136]"><img alt="Relief of a multi-storied temple, 2nd century CE, Ghantasala Stupa.[135][136]" data-file-height="2007" data-file-width="2074" decoding="async" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Andhra_pradesh%2C_santuario_a_pi%C3%B9_piani%2C_da_ghantasala%2C_90-110_ca..JPG/160px-Andhra_pradesh%2C_santuario_a_pi%C3%B9_piani%2C_da_ghantasala%2C_90-110_ca..JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Andhra_pradesh%2C_santuario_a_pi%C3%B9_piani%2C_da_ghantasala%2C_90-110_ca..JPG/240px-Andhra_pradesh%2C_santuario_a_pi%C3%B9_piani%2C_da_ghantasala%2C_90-110_ca..JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Andhra_pradesh%2C_santuario_a_pi%C3%B9_piani%2C_da_ghantasala%2C_90-110_ca..JPG/320px-Andhra_pradesh%2C_santuario_a_pi%C3%B9_piani%2C_da_ghantasala%2C_90-110_ca..JPG 2x" width="160"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Relief of a multi-storied temple, 2nd century CE, <a href="/wiki/Ghantasala,_Krishna_district" title="Ghantasala, Krishna district">Ghantasala</a> Stupa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[135]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[136]</a></sup>
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul></div></div></div>
<p>The time between the Maurya Empire in the 3rd century BCE and the end of the <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta Empire</a> in the 6th century CE is referred to as the "Classical" period of India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stein_139-0"><a href="#cite_note-stein-139">[137]</a></sup> It can be divided in various sub-periods, depending on the chosen periodisation. Classical period begins after the decline of the <a href="/wiki/Maurya_Empire" title="Maurya Empire">Maurya Empire</a>, and the corresponding rise of the <a href="/wiki/Shunga_Empire" title="Shunga Empire">Shunga Empire</a> and <a href="/wiki/Satavahana_dynasty" title="Satavahana dynasty">Satavahana dynasty</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta Empire</a> (4th–6th century) is regarded as the "Golden Age" of Hinduism, although a host of kingdoms ruled over India in these centuries. Also, the <a href="/wiki/Sangam_literature" title="Sangam literature">Sangam literature</a> flourished from the 3rd century BCE to the 3rd century CE in southern India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_7-1"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-7">[7]</a></sup> During this period, <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_India" title="Economic history of India">India's economy</a> is estimated to have been the largest in the world, having between one-third and one-quarter of the world's wealth, from 1 CE to 1000 CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Maddisson_World_GDP_140-0"><a href="#cite_note-Maddisson_World_GDP-140">[138]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[139]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Early_classical_period_.28c._200_BCE_.E2.80.93_c._320_CE.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_classical_period_(c._200_BCE_–_c._320_CE)">Early classical period (c. 200 BCE – c. 320 CE)</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Shunga_Empire">Shunga Empire</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Shunga_Empire" title="Shunga Empire">Shunga Empire</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:392px;max-width:392px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader">Shunga Empire</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:264px;max-width:264px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:158px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:East_Gateway_and_Railings_Bharhut_Stupa.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3545" data-file-width="5859" decoding="async" height="159" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/East_Gateway_and_Railings_Bharhut_Stupa.jpg/262px-East_Gateway_and_Railings_Bharhut_Stupa.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/East_Gateway_and_Railings_Bharhut_Stupa.jpg/393px-East_Gateway_and_Railings_Bharhut_Stupa.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/East_Gateway_and_Railings_Bharhut_Stupa.jpg/524px-East_Gateway_and_Railings_Bharhut_Stupa.jpg 2x" width="262"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">East Gateway and Railings, <a href="/wiki/Bharhut" title="Bharhut">Bharhut</a> <a href="/wiki/Stupa" title="Stupa">Stupa</a>, 2nd century BCE.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:124px;max-width:124px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:158px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Royal_family_Sunga_West_Bengal_1st_century_BCE.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2029" data-file-width="1558" decoding="async" height="159" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Royal_family_Sunga_West_Bengal_1st_century_BCE.jpg/122px-Royal_family_Sunga_West_Bengal_1st_century_BCE.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Royal_family_Sunga_West_Bengal_1st_century_BCE.jpg/183px-Royal_family_Sunga_West_Bengal_1st_century_BCE.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Royal_family_Sunga_West_Bengal_1st_century_BCE.jpg/244px-Royal_family_Sunga_West_Bengal_1st_century_BCE.jpg 2x" width="122"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">Shunga royal family, 1st century BCE.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The Shungas originated from <a href="/wiki/Magadha" title="Magadha">Magadha</a>, and controlled large areas of the central and eastern Indian subcontinent from around 187 to 78 BCE. The dynasty was established by <a href="/wiki/Pushyamitra_Shunga" title="Pushyamitra Shunga">Pushyamitra Shunga</a>, who overthrew the last <a href="/wiki/Maurya_Empire" title="Maurya Empire">Maurya emperor</a>. Its capital was <a href="/wiki/Pataliputra" title="Pataliputra">Pataliputra</a>, but later emperors, such as <a href="/wiki/Bhagabhadra" title="Bhagabhadra">Bhagabhadra</a>, also held court at <a href="/wiki/Vidisha" title="Vidisha">Vidisha</a>, modern <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Besnagar" title="Besnagar">Besnagar</a> in Eastern <a href="/wiki/Malwa" title="Malwa">Malwa</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[140]</a></sup>
</p><p>Pushyamitra Shunga ruled for 36 years and was succeeded by his son <a href="/wiki/Agnimitra" title="Agnimitra">Agnimitra</a>. There were ten Shunga rulers. However, after the death of Agnimitra, the empire rapidly disintegrated;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[141]</a></sup> inscriptions and coins indicate that much of northern and central India consisted of small kingdoms and city-states that were independent of any Shunga hegemony.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[142]</a></sup> The empire is noted for its numerous wars with both foreign and indigenous powers. They fought battles with the <a href="/wiki/Mahameghavahana_dynasty" title="Mahameghavahana dynasty">Mahameghavahana dynasty</a> of <a href="/wiki/Kalinga_(historical_region)" title="Kalinga (historical region)">Kalinga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Satavahana_dynasty" title="Satavahana dynasty">Satavahana dynasty</a> of <a href="/wiki/Deccan_Plateau" title="Deccan Plateau">Deccan</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indo-Greeks" title="Indo-Greeks">Indo-Greeks</a>, and possibly the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Panchala" title="Panchala">Panchalas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mitra_dynasty_(Mathura)" title="Mitra dynasty (Mathura)">Mitras of Mathura</a>.
</p><p>Art, education, philosophy, and other forms of learning flowered during this period including small terracotta images, larger stone sculptures, and architectural monuments such as the Stupa at <a href="/wiki/Bharhut" title="Bharhut">Bharhut</a>, and the renowned Great Stupa at <a href="/wiki/Sanchi" title="Sanchi">Sanchi</a>. The Shunga rulers helped to establish the tradition of royal sponsorship of learning and art. The script used by the empire was a variant of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brahmi" title="Brahmi">Brahmi</a> and was used to write the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sanskrit_language" title="Sanskrit language">Sanskrit language</a>. The Shunga Empire played an imperative role in patronising <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_culture" title="Indian culture">Indian culture</a> at a time when some of the most important developments in Hindu thought were taking place. This helped the empire flourish and gain power.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Satavahana_Empire">Satavahana Empire</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Satavahana_Empire" title="Satavahana Empire">Satavahana Empire</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:392px;max-width:392px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader">Satavahana Empire</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:228px;max-width:228px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:150px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sanchi_Stupa_No.2_Front_view1.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" decoding="async" height="151" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Sanchi_Stupa_No.2_Front_view1.jpg/226px-Sanchi_Stupa_No.2_Front_view1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Sanchi_Stupa_No.2_Front_view1.jpg/339px-Sanchi_Stupa_No.2_Front_view1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Sanchi_Stupa_No.2_Front_view1.jpg/452px-Sanchi_Stupa_No.2_Front_view1.jpg 2x" width="226"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Sanchi" title="Sanchi">Sanchi Stupa Two and Southern Gateway</a>, 1st century CE (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>).</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:160px;max-width:160px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:150px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Indian_ship_on_lead_coin_of_Vashishtiputra_Shri_Pulumavi.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1435" data-file-width="1506" decoding="async" height="151" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Indian_ship_on_lead_coin_of_Vashishtiputra_Shri_Pulumavi.jpg/158px-Indian_ship_on_lead_coin_of_Vashishtiputra_Shri_Pulumavi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Indian_ship_on_lead_coin_of_Vashishtiputra_Shri_Pulumavi.jpg/237px-Indian_ship_on_lead_coin_of_Vashishtiputra_Shri_Pulumavi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Indian_ship_on_lead_coin_of_Vashishtiputra_Shri_Pulumavi.jpg/316px-Indian_ship_on_lead_coin_of_Vashishtiputra_Shri_Pulumavi.jpg 2x" width="158"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">Indian ship on lead coin of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vasisthiputra_Sri_Pulamavi" title="Vasisthiputra Sri Pulamavi">Vasisthiputra Sri Pulamavi</a>, testimony to the naval, seafaring and trading capabilities of the Sātavāhanas during the 1st–2nd century CE.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The Śātavāhanas were based from <a href="/wiki/Amaravathi,_Palnadu_district" title="Amaravathi, Palnadu district">Amaravati</a> in <a href="/wiki/Andhra_Pradesh" title="Andhra Pradesh">Andhra Pradesh</a> as well as <a href="/wiki/Junnar" title="Junnar">Junnar</a> (<a href="/wiki/Pune" title="Pune">Pune</a>) and Prathisthan (<a href="/wiki/Paithan" title="Paithan">Paithan</a>) in <a href="/wiki/Maharashtra" title="Maharashtra">Maharashtra</a>. The territory of the empire covered large parts of India from the 1st century BCE onward. The Sātavāhanas started out as feudatories to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mauryan_dynasty" title="Mauryan dynasty">Mauryan dynasty</a>, but declared independence with its decline.
</p><p>The Sātavāhanas are known for their patronage of Hinduism and Buddhism, which resulted in Buddhist monuments from <a href="/wiki/Ellora_Caves" title="Ellora Caves">Ellora</a> (a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>) to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Amaravathi_village,_Guntur_district" title="Amaravathi village, Guntur district">Amaravati</a>. They were one of the first Indian states to issue coins struck with their rulers embossed. They formed a cultural bridge and played a vital role in trade as well as the transfer of ideas and culture to and from the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Gangetic_Plain" title="Indo-Gangetic Plain">Indo-Gangetic Plain</a> to the southern tip of India.
</p><p>They had to compete with the <a href="/wiki/Shunga_Empire" title="Shunga Empire">Shunga Empire</a> and then the <a href="/wiki/Kanva_dynasty" title="Kanva dynasty">Kanva dynasty</a> of <a href="/wiki/Magadha" title="Magadha">Magadha</a> to establish their rule. Later, they played a crucial role to protect large part of India against foreign invaders like the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sakas" title="Sakas">Sakas</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yavanas" title="Yavanas">Yavanas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pahlavas" title="Pahlavas">Pahlavas</a>. In particular, their struggles with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_Kshatrapas" title="Western Kshatrapas">Western Kshatrapas</a> went on for a long time. The notable rulers of the Satavahana Dynasty <a href="/wiki/Gautamiputra_Satakarni" title="Gautamiputra Satakarni">Gautamiputra Satakarni</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sri_Yajna_S%C4%81takarni" title="Sri Yajna Sātakarni">Sri Yajna Sātakarni</a> were able to defeat the foreign invaders like the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_Kshatrapas" title="Western Kshatrapas">Western Kshatrapas</a> and to stop their expansion. In the 3rd century CE the empire was split into smaller states.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[143]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Trade_and_travels_to_India">Trade and travels to India</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Silk_Road_transmission_of_Buddhism" title="Silk Road transmission of Buddhism">Silk Road transmission of Buddhism</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Silk_route.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1866" data-file-width="2868" decoding="async" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Silk_route.jpg/220px-Silk_route.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Silk_route.jpg/330px-Silk_route.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Silk_route.jpg/440px-Silk_route.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Silk_route.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Silk_Road" title="Silk Road">Silk Road</a> and <a href="/wiki/Spice_trade" title="Spice trade">Spice trade</a>, ancient trade routes that linked India with the <a href="/wiki/Old_World" title="Old World">Old World</a>; carried goods and ideas between the ancient civilisations of the Old World and India. The land routes are red, and the water routes are blue.</div></div></div>
<ul><li>The <a href="/wiki/Spice_trade" title="Spice trade">spice trade</a> in <a href="/wiki/Kerala" title="Kerala">Kerala</a> attracted traders from all over the Old World to India. Early writings and Stone Age carvings of <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> age obtained indicates that India's Southwest coastal port <a href="/wiki/Muziris" title="Muziris">Muziris</a>, in Kerala, had established itself as a major spice trade centre from as early as 3,000 BCE, according to <a href="/wiki/Sumer" title="Sumer">Sumerian records</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jewish" title="Jewish">Jewish</a> traders from <a href="/wiki/Judea" title="Judea">Judea</a> arrived in <a href="/wiki/Kochi" title="Kochi">Kochi</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kerala,_India" title="Kerala, India">Kerala, India</a> as early as 562 BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TheShengold_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-TheShengold-146">[144]</a></sup></li>
<li>Buddhism entered China through the <a href="/wiki/Silk_Road_transmission_of_Buddhism" title="Silk Road transmission of Buddhism">Silk Road transmission of Buddhism</a> in the 1st or 2nd century CE. The interaction of cultures resulted in several Chinese travellers and monks to enter India. Most notable were <a href="/wiki/Faxian" title="Faxian">Faxian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yijing_(monk)" title="Yijing (monk)">Yijing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Song_Yun" title="Song Yun">Song Yun</a> and <a href="/wiki/Xuanzang" title="Xuanzang">Xuanzang</a>. These travellers wrote detailed accounts of the Indian subcontinent, which includes the political and social aspects of the region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[145]</a></sup></li>
<li>Hindu and Buddhist religious establishments of Southeast Asia came to be associated with the economic activity and commerce as patrons entrust large funds which would later be used to benefit the local economy by estate management, craftsmanship, promotion of trading activities. Buddhism in particular, travelled alongside the maritime trade, promoting coinage, art, and literacy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonkin200367_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonkin200367-148">[146]</a></sup> Indian merchants involved in spice trade took <a href="/wiki/Indian_cuisine" title="Indian cuisine">Indian cuisine</a> to Southeast Asia, where spice mixtures and <a href="/wiki/Curry" title="Curry">curries</a> became popular with the native inhabitants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECollingham2006245_149-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECollingham2006245-149">[147]</a></sup></li>
<li>The <a href="/wiki/Greco-Roman_world" title="Greco-Roman world">Greco-Roman world</a> followed by trading along the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Incense_route" title="Incense route">incense route</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Roman_trade_relations" title="Indo-Roman trade relations">Roman-India routes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELaw1978164_150-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELaw1978164-150">[148]</a></sup> During the 2nd century BCE Greek and Indian ships met to trade at <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula" title="Arabian Peninsula">Arabian</a> ports such as <a href="/wiki/Aden" title="Aden">Aden</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[149]</a></sup> During the first millennium, the sea routes to India were controlled by the Indians and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethiopian" title="Ethiopian">Ethiopians</a> that became the maritime trading power of the <a href="/wiki/Red_Sea" title="Red Sea">Red Sea</a>.</li></ul>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Kushan_Empire">Kushan Empire</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Kushan_Empire" title="Kushan Empire">Kushan Empire</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader">Kushan Empire</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:183px;max-width:183px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:167px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_the_Kushan_Empire.png"><img alt="" data-file-height="2151" data-file-width="2324" decoding="async" height="168" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Map_of_the_Kushan_Empire.png/181px-Map_of_the_Kushan_Empire.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Map_of_the_Kushan_Empire.png/272px-Map_of_the_Kushan_Empire.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Map_of_the_Kushan_Empire.png/362px-Map_of_the_Kushan_Empire.png 2x" width="181"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">Kushan territories (full line) and maximum extent of Kushan dominions under Kanishka (dotted line), according to the Rabatak inscription.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:105px;max-width:105px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:167px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kanishka_Buddha_detail.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="700" data-file-width="430" decoding="async" height="168" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Kanishka_Buddha_detail.jpg/103px-Kanishka_Buddha_detail.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Kanishka_Buddha_detail.jpg/155px-Kanishka_Buddha_detail.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Kanishka_Buddha_detail.jpg/206px-Kanishka_Buddha_detail.jpg 2x" width="103"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">Depiction of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddha" title="Buddha">Buddha</a> in Kanishka's coinage, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mathura_art" title="Mathura art">Mathura art</a>, 2nd century CE.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Kushan_Empire" title="Kushan Empire">Kushan Empire</a> expanded out of what is now Afghanistan into the northwest of the Indian subcontinent under the leadership of their first emperor, <a href="/wiki/Kujula_Kadphises" title="Kujula Kadphises">Kujula Kadphises</a>, about the middle of the 1st century CE. The Kushans were possibly of <a href="/wiki/Tocharians" title="Tocharians">Tocharian</a> <a href="/wiki/Tocharian_languages" title="Tocharian languages">speaking</a> tribe;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TCHAC_152-0"><a href="#cite_note-TCHAC-152">[150]</a></sup> one of five branches of the <a href="/wiki/Yuezhi" title="Yuezhi">Yuezhi</a> confederation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[151]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-liu156_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-liu156-154">[152]</a></sup> By the time of his grandson, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kanishka_the_Great" title="Kanishka the Great">Kanishka the Great</a>, the empire spread to encompass much of <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[153]</a></sup> and then the northern parts of the Indian subcontinent at least as far as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saketa" title="Saketa">Saketa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sarnath" title="Sarnath">Sarnath</a> near <a href="/wiki/Varanasi" title="Varanasi">Varanasi</a> (Banaras).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[154]</a></sup>
</p><p>Emperor Kanishka was a great patron of Buddhism; however, as Kushans expanded southward, the deities of their later coinage came to reflect its new <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a> majority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[155]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[156]</a></sup> They played an important role in the establishment of Buddhism in India and its spread to Central Asia and China.
</p><p>Historian <a href="/wiki/Vincent_Arthur_Smith" title="Vincent Arthur Smith">Vincent Smith</a> said about Kanishka:
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r996844942">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>He played the part of a second Ashoka in the history of Buddhism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceC_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceC-159">[157]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>The empire linked the Indian Ocean maritime trade with the commerce of the <a href="/wiki/Silk_Road" title="Silk Road">Silk Road</a> through the Indus valley, encouraging long-distance trade, particularly between China and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_empire" title="Roman empire">Rome</a>. The Kushans brought new trends to the budding and blossoming <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gandhara_art" title="Gandhara art">Gandhara art</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mathura_art" title="Mathura art">Mathura art</a>, which reached its peak during Kushan rule.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ArtPal1986_160-0"><a href="#cite_note-ArtPal1986-160">[158]</a></sup>
</p><p>H.G. Rowlinson commented:
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>The Kushan period is a fitting prelude to the Age of the Guptas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[159]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>By the 3rd century, their empire in India was disintegrating and their last known great emperor was <a href="/wiki/Vasudeva_I" title="Vasudeva I">Vasudeva I</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kushan_162-0"><a href="#cite_note-kushan-162">[160]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[161]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Classical_period_.28c._320_.E2.80.93_650_CE.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Classical_period_(c._320_–_650_CE)">Classical period (c. 320 – 650 CE)</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Gupta_Empire">Gupta Empire</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta Empire</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Meghad%C5%ABta" title="Meghadūta">Meghadūta</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abhij%C3%B1%C4%81na%C5%9B%C4%81kuntala" title="Abhijñānaśākuntala">Abhijñānaśākuntala</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kum%C4%81rasambhava" title="Kumārasambhava">Kumārasambhava</a>, <a href="/wiki/Panchatantra" title="Panchatantra">Panchatantra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aryabhatiya" title="Aryabhatiya">Aryabhatiya</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_numerals" title="Indian numerals">Indian numerals</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kama_Sutra" title="Kama Sutra">Kama Sutra</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:342px;max-width:342px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader">Gupta Empire</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:177px;max-width:177px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:211px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gupta_empire_map.png"><img alt="" data-file-height="2087" data-file-width="1729" decoding="async" height="211" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Gupta_empire_map.png/175px-Gupta_empire_map.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Gupta_empire_map.png/263px-Gupta_empire_map.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Gupta_empire_map.png/350px-Gupta_empire_map.png 2x" width="175"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta Empire</a> expansion from 320 CE to 550 CE.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:161px;max-width:161px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:211px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mahabodhitemple.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="1944" decoding="async" height="212" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Mahabodhitemple.jpg/159px-Mahabodhitemple.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Mahabodhitemple.jpg/239px-Mahabodhitemple.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Mahabodhitemple.jpg/318px-Mahabodhitemple.jpg 2x" width="159"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">The current structure of the <a href="/wiki/Mahabodhi_Temple" title="Mahabodhi Temple">Mahabodhi Temple</a> dates to the Gupta era, 5th century CE. Marking the location where the Buddha is said to have attained enlightenment.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The Gupta period was noted for cultural creativity, especially in literature, architecture, sculpture, and painting.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[162]</a></sup> The Gupta period produced scholars such as <a href="/wiki/Kalidasa" title="Kalidasa">Kalidasa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aryabhata" title="Aryabhata">Aryabhata</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Varahamihira" title="Varahamihira">Varahamihira</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vishnu_Sharma" title="Vishnu Sharma">Vishnu Sharma</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vatsyayana" title="Vatsyayana">Vatsyayana</a> who made great advancements in many academic fields. The Gupta period marked a watershed of Indian culture: the Guptas performed Vedic sacrifices to legitimise their rule, but they also patronised Buddhism, which continued to provide an alternative to Brahmanical orthodoxy. The military exploits of the first three rulers – <a href="/wiki/Chandragupta_I" title="Chandragupta I">Chandragupta I</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samudragupta" title="Samudragupta">Samudragupta</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chandragupta_II" title="Chandragupta II">Chandragupta II</a> – brought much of India under their leadership.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[163]</a></sup> Science and political administration reached new heights during the Gupta era. Strong trade ties also made the region an important cultural centre and established it as a base that would influence nearby kingdoms and regions in: Sri Lanka; <a href="/wiki/Maritime_Southeast_Asia" title="Maritime Southeast Asia">Maritime Southeast Asia</a> (<a href="/wiki/Brunei" title="Brunei">Brunei</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malaysia" title="Malaysia">Malaysia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Timor-Leste" title="Timor-Leste">Timor-Leste</a>);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[164]</a></sup> as well as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indochina" title="Indochina">Indochina</a> (<a href="/wiki/Cambodia" title="Cambodia">Cambodia</a>, Laos, Myanmar, <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">Thailand</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[165]</a></sup>
</p><p>The latter Guptas successfully resisted the northwestern kingdoms until the arrival of the <a href="/wiki/Alchon_Huns" title="Alchon Huns">Alchon Huns</a>, who established themselves in Afghanistan by the first half of the 5th century CE, with their capital at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bamyan,_Afghanistan" title="Bamyan, Afghanistan">Bamiyan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[166]</a></sup> However, much of the southern India including <a href="/wiki/Deccan_Plateau" title="Deccan Plateau">Deccan</a> were largely unaffected by these events in the north.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[167]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[168]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Vakataka_Empire">Vakataka Empire</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vakataka_Empire" title="Vakataka Empire">Vakataka Empire</a></div>
<p>The Vākāṭaka Empire originated from the <a href="/wiki/Deccan_Plateau" title="Deccan Plateau">Deccan</a> in the mid-third century CE. Their state is believed to have extended from the southern edges of <a href="/wiki/Malwa" title="Malwa">Malwa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gujarat" title="Gujarat">Gujarat</a> in the north to the <a href="/wiki/Tungabhadra_River" title="Tungabhadra River">Tungabhadra River</a> in the south as well as from the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Sea" title="Arabian Sea">Arabian Sea</a> in the western to the edges of <a href="/wiki/Chhattisgarh" title="Chhattisgarh">Chhattisgarh</a> in the east. They were the most important successors of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Satavahanas" title="Satavahanas">Satavahanas</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Deccan_Plateau" title="Deccan Plateau">Deccan</a>, contemporaneous with the <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Guptas</a> in northern India and succeeded by the <a href="/wiki/Vishnukundina_dynasty" title="Vishnukundina dynasty">Vishnukundina dynasty</a>.
</p><p>The Vakatakas are noted for having been patrons of the arts, architecture and literature. They led public works and their monuments are a visible legacy. The rock-cut Buddhist viharas and chaityas of <a href="/wiki/Ajanta_Caves" title="Ajanta Caves">Ajanta Caves</a> (a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>) were built under the patronage of Vakataka emperor, <a href="/wiki/Harishena" title="Harishena">Harishena</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Madan_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-Madan-171">[169]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[170]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1021810730" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="mod-gallery mod-gallery-default mod-gallery-center"><div class="main"><div><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional nochecker bordered-images whitebg">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
