<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:45px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:AJANTA_CAVES_-_C.SHELARE_(2).jpg" title="The Ajanta Caves are 30 rock-cut Buddhist cave monument built under the Vakatakas."><img alt="The Ajanta Caves are 30 rock-cut Buddhist cave monument built under the Vakatakas." data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/AJANTA_CAVES_-_C.SHELARE_%282%29.jpg/180px-AJANTA_CAVES_-_C.SHELARE_%282%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/AJANTA_CAVES_-_C.SHELARE_%282%29.jpg/270px-AJANTA_CAVES_-_C.SHELARE_%282%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/AJANTA_CAVES_-_C.SHELARE_%282%29.jpg/360px-AJANTA_CAVES_-_C.SHELARE_%282%29.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Ajanta_Caves" title="Ajanta Caves">Ajanta Caves</a> are 30 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rock_cut_architecture" title="Rock cut architecture">rock-cut</a> Buddhist cave monument built under the Vakatakas.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ajanta_Cave_26_Dagoba_with_praying_monks.jpg" title="Buddhist monks praying in front of the Dagoba of Chaitya Cave 26 of the Ajanta Caves."><img alt="Buddhist monks praying in front of the Dagoba of Chaitya Cave 26 of the Ajanta Caves." data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Ajanta_Cave_26_Dagoba_with_praying_monks.jpg/120px-Ajanta_Cave_26_Dagoba_with_praying_monks.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Ajanta_Cave_26_Dagoba_with_praying_monks.jpg/180px-Ajanta_Cave_26_Dagoba_with_praying_monks.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Ajanta_Cave_26_Dagoba_with_praying_monks.jpg/240px-Ajanta_Cave_26_Dagoba_with_praying_monks.jpg 2x" width="120"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Buddhist monks praying in front of the Dagoba of Chaitya Cave 26 of the Ajanta Caves.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:46.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cave_26,_Ajanta.jpg" title='Buddhist "Chaitya Griha" or prayer hall, with a seated Buddha, Cave 26 of the Ajanta Caves.'><img alt='Buddhist "Chaitya Griha" or prayer hall, with a seated Buddha, Cave 26 of the Ajanta Caves.' data-file-height="2662" data-file-width="4100" decoding="async" height="117" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Cave_26%2C_Ajanta.jpg/180px-Cave_26%2C_Ajanta.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Cave_26%2C_Ajanta.jpg/270px-Cave_26%2C_Ajanta.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Cave_26%2C_Ajanta.jpg/360px-Cave_26%2C_Ajanta.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">

</p>
</div>

<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:37px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ajanta_Cave_17_frescoe.jpg" title="Many foreign ambassadors, representatives, and travelers are included as devotees attending the Buddha's descent from Trayastrimsa Heaven; painting from Cave 17 of the Ajanta Caves."><img alt="Many foreign ambassadors, representatives, and travelers are included as devotees attending the Buddha's descent from Trayastrimsa Heaven; painting from Cave 17 of the Ajanta Caves." data-file-height="2140" data-file-width="2840" decoding="async" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Ajanta_Cave_17_frescoe.jpg/180px-Ajanta_Cave_17_frescoe.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Ajanta_Cave_17_frescoe.jpg/270px-Ajanta_Cave_17_frescoe.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Ajanta_Cave_17_frescoe.jpg/360px-Ajanta_Cave_17_frescoe.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>

</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul></div></div></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Kamarupa_Kingdom">Kamarupa Kingdom</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kamarupa_Kingdom" title="Kamarupa Kingdom">Kamarupa Kingdom</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:122px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Copper_Plate_Seal_of_Kamarupa_Kings.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1548" data-file-width="834" decoding="async" height="223" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Copper_Plate_Seal_of_Kamarupa_Kings.jpg/120px-Copper_Plate_Seal_of_Kamarupa_Kings.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Copper_Plate_Seal_of_Kamarupa_Kings.jpg/180px-Copper_Plate_Seal_of_Kamarupa_Kings.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Copper_Plate_Seal_of_Kamarupa_Kings.jpg/240px-Copper_Plate_Seal_of_Kamarupa_Kings.jpg 2x" width="120"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Copper_Plate_Seal_of_Kamarupa_Kings.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Copper Plate Seal of Kamarupa Kings at <a href="/wiki/Madan_Kamdev" title="Madan Kamdev">Madan Kamdev</a> ruins.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Samudragupta" title="Samudragupta">Samudragupta</a>'s 4th-century <a href="/wiki/Allahabad_Pillar#Samudragupta_inscription" title="Allahabad Pillar">Allahabad pillar inscription</a> mentions Kamarupa (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_Assam" title="Western Assam">Western Assam</a>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[171]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Davaka" title="Davaka">Davaka</a> (Central Assam)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[172]</a></sup> as frontier kingdoms of the Gupta Empire. Davaka was later absorbed by Kamarupa, which grew into a large kingdom that spanned from Karatoya river to near present <a href="/wiki/Sadiya" title="Sadiya">Sadiya</a> and covered the entire Brahmaputra valley, <a href="/wiki/North_Bengal" title="North Bengal">North Bengal</a>, parts of <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a> and, at times <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Purnea" title="Purnea">Purnea</a> and parts of <a href="/wiki/West_Bengal" title="West Bengal">West Bengal</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[173]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ruled by three dynasties <a href="/wiki/Varman_dynasty" title="Varman dynasty">Varmanas</a> (c. 350–650 CE), <a href="/wiki/Mlechchha_dynasty" title="Mlechchha dynasty">Mlechchha dynasty</a> (c. 655–900 CE) and <a href="/wiki/Pala_dynasty_(Kamarupa)" title="Pala dynasty (Kamarupa)">Kamarupa-Palas</a> (c. 900–1100 CE), from their capitals in present-day <a href="/wiki/Guwahati" title="Guwahati">Guwahati</a> (<a href="/wiki/Pragjyotishpura" title="Pragjyotishpura">Pragjyotishpura</a>), Tezpur (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Haruppeswara" title="Haruppeswara">Haruppeswara</a>) and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North_Gauhati" title="North Gauhati">North Gauhati</a> (<a href="/wiki/Durjaya" title="Durjaya">Durjaya</a>) respectively. All three dynasties claimed their descent from <a href="/wiki/Narakasura" title="Narakasura">Narakasura</a>, an immigrant from <a href="/wiki/%C4%80ry%C4%81varta" title="Āryāvarta">Aryavarta</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[174]</a></sup> In the reign of the Varman king, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bhaskar_Varman" title="Bhaskar Varman">Bhaskar Varman</a> (c. 600–650 CE), the Chinese traveller <a href="/wiki/Xuanzang" title="Xuanzang">Xuanzang</a> visited the <a href="/wiki/Kamrup_region" title="Kamrup region">region</a> and recorded his travels. Later, after weakening and disintegration (after the Kamarupa-Palas), the Kamarupa tradition was somewhat extended until c. 1255 CE by the Lunar I (c. 1120–1185 CE) and Lunar II (c. 1155–1255 CE) dynasties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[175]</a></sup> The Kamarupa kingdom came to an end in the middle of the 13th century when the <a href="/wiki/Khen_dynasty" title="Khen dynasty">Khen dynasty</a> under <a href="/wiki/Sandhya_(ruler_of_Kamarupa)" title="Sandhya (ruler of Kamarupa)">Sandhya</a> of Kamarupanagara (North Guwahati), moved his capital to Kamatapur (North Bengal) after the invasion of Muslim Turks, and established the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kamata_kingdom" title="Kamata kingdom">Kamata kingdom</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[176]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Pallava_Empire">Pallava Empire</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pallava_Empire" title="Pallava Empire">Pallava Empire</a></div><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:142px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Shore_temple,_mahabalipuram.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="211" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Shore_temple%2C_mahabalipuram.jpg/140px-Shore_temple%2C_mahabalipuram.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Shore_temple%2C_mahabalipuram.jpg/211px-Shore_temple%2C_mahabalipuram.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Shore_temple%2C_mahabalipuram.jpg/281px-Shore_temple%2C_mahabalipuram.jpg 2x" width="140"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Shore_temple,_mahabalipuram.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Shore_Temple" title="Shore Temple">Shore Temple</a> (a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>) at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mahabalipuram" title="Mahabalipuram">Mahabalipuram</a> built by <a href="/wiki/Narasimhavarman_II" title="Narasimhavarman II">Narasimhavarman II</a>.</div></div></div><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pallava" title="Pallava">Pallavas</a>, during the 4th to 9th centuries were, alongside the <a href="/wiki/Gupta" title="Gupta">Guptas</a> of the <a href="/wiki/North_India" title="North India">North</a>, great patronisers of Sanskrit development in the <a href="/wiki/South_India" title="South India">South</a> of the Indian subcontinent. The Pallava reign saw the first Sanskrit inscriptions in a script called <a href="/wiki/Grantha_script" title="Grantha script">Grantha</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[177]</a></sup> Early Pallavas had different connexions to <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asian</a> countries. The Pallavas used Dravidian architecture to build some very important Hindu temples and academies in <a href="/wiki/Mamallapuram" title="Mamallapuram">Mamallapuram</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kanchipuram" title="Kanchipuram">Kanchipuram</a> and other places; their rule saw the rise of great poets. The practice of dedicating temples to different deities came into vogue followed by fine artistic <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple_architecture" title="Hindu temple architecture">temple architecture</a> and sculpture style of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vastu_Shastra" title="Vastu Shastra">Vastu Shastra</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[178]</a></sup>
</p><p>Pallavas reached the height of power during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Mahendravarman_I" title="Mahendravarman I">Mahendravarman I</a> (571–630 CE) and <a href="/wiki/Narasimhavarman_I" title="Narasimhavarman I">Narasimhavarman I</a> (630–668 CE) and dominated the <a href="/wiki/Telugu_people" title="Telugu people">Telugu</a> and northern parts of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ancient_Tamil_country" title="Ancient Tamil country">Tamil</a> region for about six hundred years until the end of the 9th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-histoworldwhitney_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-histoworldwhitney-181">[179]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Kadamba_Empire">Kadamba Empire</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kadamba_Empire" title="Kadamba Empire">Kadamba Empire</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Close_up_view_of_shrines_at_Lakshmi_Devi_temple_complex_at_Doddagaddavalli.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Close_up_view_of_shrines_at_Lakshmi_Devi_temple_complex_at_Doddagaddavalli.JPG/220px-Close_up_view_of_shrines_at_Lakshmi_Devi_temple_complex_at_Doddagaddavalli.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Close_up_view_of_shrines_at_Lakshmi_Devi_temple_complex_at_Doddagaddavalli.JPG/330px-Close_up_view_of_shrines_at_Lakshmi_Devi_temple_complex_at_Doddagaddavalli.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Close_up_view_of_shrines_at_Lakshmi_Devi_temple_complex_at_Doddagaddavalli.JPG/440px-Close_up_view_of_shrines_at_Lakshmi_Devi_temple_complex_at_Doddagaddavalli.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Close_up_view_of_shrines_at_Lakshmi_Devi_temple_complex_at_Doddagaddavalli.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kadamba <i>shikara</i> (tower) with <i>Kalasa</i> (pinnacle) on top, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doddagaddavalli" title="Doddagaddavalli">Doddagaddavalli</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Kadambas originated from <a href="/wiki/Karnataka" title="Karnataka">Karnataka</a>, was founded by <a href="/wiki/Mayurasharma" title="Mayurasharma">Mayurasharma</a> in 345 CE which at later times showed the potential of developing into imperial proportions, an indication to which is provided by the titles and epithets assumed by its rulers. King Mayurasharma defeated the armies of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pallavas_of_Kanchi" title="Pallavas of Kanchi">Pallavas of Kanchi</a> possibly with help of some native tribes. The Kadamba fame reached its peak during the rule of <a href="/wiki/Kakusthavarma" title="Kakusthavarma">Kakusthavarma</a>, a notable ruler with whom even the kings of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gupta_Dynasty" title="Gupta Dynasty">Gupta Dynasty</a> of northern India cultivated marital alliances. The Kadambas were contemporaries of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_Ganga_Dynasty" title="Western Ganga Dynasty">Western Ganga Dynasty</a> and together they formed the earliest native kingdoms to rule the land with absolute autonomy. The dynasty later continued to rule as a feudatory of larger Kannada empires, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chalukya" title="Chalukya">Chalukya</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rashtrakuta" title="Rashtrakuta">Rashtrakuta</a> empires, for over five hundred years during which time they branched into minor dynasties known as the <a href="/wiki/Kadambas_of_Goa" title="Kadambas of Goa">Kadambas of Goa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kadambas_of_Halasi" title="Kadambas of Halasi">Kadambas of Halasi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kadambas_of_Hangal" title="Kadambas of Hangal">Kadambas of Hangal</a>.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Empire_of_Harsha">Empire of Harsha</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Harsha" title="Harsha">Harsha</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pushyabhuti_dynasty" title="Pushyabhuti dynasty">Pushyabhuti dynasty</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Harsha" title="Harsha">Harsha</a> ruled northern India from 606 to 647 CE. He was the son of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prabhakarvardhana" title="Prabhakarvardhana">Prabhakarvardhana</a> and the younger brother of <a href="/wiki/Rajyavardhana" title="Rajyavardhana">Rajyavardhana</a>, who were members of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vardhana_dynasty" title="Vardhana dynasty">Vardhana dynasty</a> and ruled <a href="/wiki/Thanesar" title="Thanesar">Thanesar</a>, in present-day <a href="/wiki/Haryana" title="Haryana">Haryana</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Harshavardhana_Circa_AD_606-647.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="401" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="125" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Harshavardhana_Circa_AD_606-647.jpg/250px-Harshavardhana_Circa_AD_606-647.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Harshavardhana_Circa_AD_606-647.jpg/375px-Harshavardhana_Circa_AD_606-647.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Harshavardhana_Circa_AD_606-647.jpg/500px-Harshavardhana_Circa_AD_606-647.jpg 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Harshavardhana_Circa_AD_606-647.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Coin of <a href="/wiki/Harsha" title="Harsha">Emperor Harsha</a>, c. 606–647 CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[180]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>After the downfall of the prior <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta Empire</a> in the middle of the 6th century, <a href="/wiki/North_India" title="North India">North India</a> reverted to smaller republics and monarchical states. The power vacuum resulted in the rise of the Vardhanas of Thanesar, who began uniting the republics and monarchies from the Punjab to central India. After the death of Harsha's father and brother, representatives of the empire crowned Harsha emperor at an assembly in April 606 CE, giving him the title of Maharaja when he was merely 16 years old.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RN_Kundra_&amp;_SS_Bawa_183-0"><a href="#cite_note-RN_Kundra_&amp;_SS_Bawa-183">[181]</a></sup> At the height of his power, his Empire covered much of North and Northwestern India, extended East until <a href="/wiki/Kamarupa" title="Kamarupa">Kamarupa</a>, and South until <a href="/wiki/Narmada_River" title="Narmada River">Narmada River</a>; and eventually made <a href="/wiki/Kannauj" title="Kannauj">Kannauj</a> (in present <a href="/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh" title="Uttar Pradesh">Uttar Pradesh</a> state) his capital, and ruled until 647 CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Historic_Places_p.507_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-Historic_Places_p.507-184">[182]</a></sup>
</p><p>The peace and prosperity that prevailed made his court a centre of cosmopolitanism, attracting scholars, artists and religious visitors from far and wide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Historic_Places_p.507_184-1"><a href="#cite_note-Historic_Places_p.507-184">[182]</a></sup> During this time, Harsha converted to Buddhism from <a href="/wiki/Surya" title="Surya">Surya</a> worship.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[183]</a></sup> The Chinese traveller <a href="/wiki/Xuanzang" title="Xuanzang">Xuanzang</a> visited the court of Harsha and wrote a very favourable account of him, praising his justice and generosity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Historic_Places_p.507_184-2"><a href="#cite_note-Historic_Places_p.507-184">[182]</a></sup> His biography <i><a href="/wiki/Harshacharita" title="Harshacharita">Harshacharita</a></i> ("Deeds of Harsha") written by Sanskrit poet <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Banabhatta" title="Banabhatta">Banabhatta</a>, describes his association with Thanesar, besides mentioning the defence wall, a moat and the palace with a two-storied <i>Dhavalagriha</i> (White Mansion).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-encystan_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-encystan-186">[184]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[185]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Early_medieval_period_.28mid_6th_c..E2.80.931200_CE.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_medieval_period_(mid_6th_c.–1200_CE)">Early medieval period (mid 6th c.–1200 CE)</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Medieval_India" title="Medieval India">Medieval India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Decline_of_Buddhism_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="Decline of Buddhism in the Indian subcontinent">Decline of Buddhism in the Indian subcontinent</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tripartite_Struggle" title="Tripartite Struggle">Tripartite Struggle</a></div>
<p>Early <a href="/wiki/Medieval_India" title="Medieval India">medieval India</a> began after the end of the <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta Empire</a> in the 6th century CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stein_139-1"><a href="#cite_note-stein-139">[137]</a></sup> This period also covers the "Late Classical Age" of Hinduism,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200441_188-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200441-188">[186]</a></sup> which began after the end of the <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta Empire</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200441_188-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200441-188">[186]</a></sup> and the collapse of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Empire_of_Harsha" title="Empire of Harsha">Empire of Harsha</a> in the 7th century CE;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200441_188-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200441-188">[186]</a></sup> the beginning of Imperial <a href="/wiki/Kannauj" title="Kannauj">Kannauj</a>, leading to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tripartite_struggle" title="Tripartite struggle">Tripartite struggle</a>; and ended in the 13th century with the rise of the <a href="/wiki/Delhi_Sultanate" title="Delhi Sultanate">Delhi Sultanate</a> in Northern India<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200443_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200443-189">[187]</a></sup> and the end of the <a href="/wiki/Later_Cholas" title="Later Cholas">Later Cholas</a> with the death of <a href="/wiki/Rajendra_Chola_III" title="Rajendra Chola III">Rajendra Chola III</a> in 1279 in Southern India; however some aspects of the Classical period continued until the fall of the <a href="/wiki/Vijayanagara_Empire" title="Vijayanagara Empire">Vijayanagara Empire</a> in the south around the 17th century.
</p><p>From the fifth century to the thirteenth, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shrauta" title="Shrauta">Śrauta</a> sacrifices declined, and initiatory traditions of Buddhism, Jainism or more commonly <a href="/wiki/Shaivism" title="Shaivism">Shaivism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vaishnavism" title="Vaishnavism">Vaishnavism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shaktism" title="Shaktism">Shaktism</a> expanded in royal courts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sanderson,_Alexis_2009_pages_41-43_190-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sanderson,_Alexis_2009_pages_41-43-190">[188]</a></sup> This period produced some of India's finest art, considered the epitome of classical development, and the development of the main spiritual and philosophical systems which continued to be in Hinduism, Buddhism and Jainism.
</p><p>In the 7th century CE, <a href="/wiki/Kum%C4%81rila_Bha%E1%B9%AD%E1%B9%ADa" title="Kumārila Bhaṭṭa">Kumārila Bhaṭṭa</a> formulated his school of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mimamsa" title="Mimamsa">Mimamsa</a> philosophy and defended the position on Vedic rituals against Buddhist attacks. Scholars note Bhaṭṭa's contribution to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Decline_of_Buddhism_in_India" title="Decline of Buddhism in India">decline of Buddhism in India</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[189]</a></sup> In the 8th century, <a href="/wiki/Adi_Shankara" title="Adi Shankara">Adi Shankara</a> travelled across the Indian subcontinent to propagate and spread the doctrine of <a href="/wiki/Advaita_Vedanta" title="Advaita Vedanta">Advaita Vedanta</a>, which he consolidated; and is credited with unifying the main characteristics of the current thoughts in Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[190]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[191]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[192]</a></sup> He was a critic of both Buddhism and Minamsa school of Hinduism;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SKChattopadhyaya_195-0"><a href="#cite_note-SKChattopadhyaya-195">[193]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eroer1_196-0"><a href="#cite_note-eroer1-196">[194]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eroer2_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-eroer2-197">[195]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[196]</a></sup> and founded <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mathas" title="Mathas">mathas</a> (monasteries), in the four corners of the Indian subcontinent for the spread and development of Advaita Vedanta.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DeepakChopraBookLink_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-DeepakChopraBookLink-199">[197]</a></sup> While, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muhammad_bin_Qasim" title="Muhammad bin Qasim">Muhammad bin Qasim</a>'s invasion of <a href="/wiki/Sindh" title="Sindh">Sindh</a> (modern Pakistan) in 711 CE witnessed further decline of Buddhism. The <a href="/wiki/Chach_Nama" title="Chach Nama">Chach Nama</a> records many instances of conversion of stupas to mosques such as at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hyderabad,_Pakistan" title="Hyderabad, Pakistan">Nerun</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[198]</a></sup>
</p><p>From the 8th to the 10th century, three dynasties contested for control of northern India: the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gurjara_Pratihara" title="Gurjara Pratihara">Gurjara Pratiharas</a> of Malwa, the <a href="/wiki/Pala_Empire" title="Pala Empire">Palas</a> of Bengal, and the <a href="/wiki/Rashtrakuta_dynasty" title="Rashtrakuta dynasty">Rashtrakutas</a> of the Deccan. The <a href="/wiki/Sena_dynasty" title="Sena dynasty">Sena dynasty</a> would later assume control of the Pala Empire; the Gurjara Pratiharas fragmented into various states, notably the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paramara" title="Paramara">Paramaras</a> of Malwa, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chandela" title="Chandela">Chandelas</a> of <a href="/wiki/Bundelkhand" title="Bundelkhand">Bundelkhand</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Kalachuris_of_Tripuri" title="Kalachuris of Tripuri">Kalachuris</a> of <a href="/wiki/Mahakoshal" title="Mahakoshal">Mahakoshal</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tomaras" title="Tomaras">Tomaras</a> of <a href="/wiki/Haryana" title="Haryana">Haryana</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Chahamanas_of_Shakambhari" title="Chahamanas of Shakambhari">Chauhans</a> of <a href="/wiki/Rajputana" title="Rajputana">Rajputana</a>, these states were some of the earliest <a href="/wiki/List_of_Rajput_dynasties_and_states" title="List of Rajput dynasties and states">Rajput kingdoms</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[199]</a></sup> while the Rashtrakutas were annexed by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_Chalukyas" title="Western Chalukyas">Western Chalukyas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKamath2001100–103_202-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKamath2001100–103-202">[200]</a></sup> During this period, the <a href="/wiki/Chaulukya_dynasty" title="Chaulukya dynasty">Chaulukya dynasty</a> emerged; the Chaulukyas constructed the <a href="/wiki/Dilwara_Temples" title="Dilwara Temples">Dilwara Temples</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sun_Temple,_Modhera" title="Sun Temple, Modhera">Modhera Sun Temple</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rani_ki_vav" title="Rani ki vav">Rani ki vav</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[201]</a></sup> in the style of <a href="/wiki/M%C4%81ru-Gurjara_architecture" title="Māru-Gurjara architecture">Māru-Gurjara architecture</a>, and their capital Anhilwara (modern <a href="/wiki/Patan,_Gujarat" title="Patan, Gujarat">Patan, Gujarat</a>) was one of the largest cities in the Indian subcontinent, with the population estimated at 100,000 in 1000 CE.
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chola_Empire" title="Chola Empire">Chola Empire</a> emerged as a major power during the reign of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Raja_Raja_Chola_I" title="Raja Raja Chola I">Raja Raja Chola I</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rajendra_Chola_I" title="Rajendra Chola I">Rajendra Chola I</a> who successfully <a href="/wiki/South-East_Asia_campaign_of_Rajendra_Chola_I" title="South-East Asia campaign of Rajendra Chola I">invaded parts of Southeast Asia</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chola_occupation_of_Sri_Lanka_(993-1077)" title="Chola occupation of Sri Lanka (993-1077)">Sri Lanka</a> in the 11th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Dancing_Girl_p.129_204-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_Dancing_Girl_p.129-204">[202]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lalitaditya_Muktapida" title="Lalitaditya Muktapida">Lalitaditya Muktapida</a> (r. 724–760 CE) was an emperor of the Kashmiri <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Karko%E1%B9%ADa_dynasty" title="Karkoṭa dynasty">Karkoṭa dynasty</a>, which exercised influence in northwestern India from 625 CE until 1003, and was followed by <a href="/wiki/Lohara_dynasty" title="Lohara dynasty">Lohara dynasty</a>. <a href="/wiki/Kalhana" title="Kalhana">Kalhana</a> in his <a href="/wiki/Rajatarangini" title="Rajatarangini">Rajatarangini</a> credits king Lalitaditya with leading an aggressive military campaign in Northern India and Central Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[203]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[204]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[205]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu_Shahi" title="Hindu Shahi">Hindu Shahi</a> dynasty ruled portions of eastern Afghanistan, northern Pakistan, and Kashmir from the mid-7th century to the early 11th century. While in <a href="/wiki/Odisha" title="Odisha">Odisha</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Ganga_dynasty" title="Eastern Ganga dynasty">Eastern Ganga Empire</a> rose to power; noted for the advancement of <a href="/wiki/Hindu_architecture" title="Hindu architecture">Hindu architecture</a>, most notable being <a href="/wiki/Jagannath_Temple,_Puri" title="Jagannath Temple, Puri">Jagannath Temple</a> and <a href="/wiki/Konark_Sun_Temple" title="Konark Sun Temple">Konark Sun Temple</a>, as well as being patrons of art and literature.
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1021810730" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="mod-gallery mod-gallery-default mod-gallery-center"><div class="main"><div><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional nochecker bordered-images whitebg">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">

</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Chalukya_Empire">Chalukya Empire</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chalukya_Empire" title="Chalukya Empire">Chalukya Empire</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Chalukya_dynasty" title="Chalukya dynasty">Chalukya Empire</a> ruled large parts of <a href="/wiki/South_India" title="South India">southern</a> and <a href="/wiki/Central_India" title="Central India">central India</a> between the 6th and the 12th centuries. During this period, they ruled as three related yet individual dynasties. The earliest dynasty, known as the "Badami Chalukyas", ruled from Vatapi (modern <a href="/wiki/Badami" title="Badami">Badami</a>) from the middle of the 6th century. The Badami Chalukyas began to assert their independence at the decline of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kadamba_Dynasty" title="Kadamba Dynasty">Kadamba</a> kingdom of <a href="/wiki/Banavasi" title="Banavasi">Banavasi</a> and rapidly rose to prominence during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Pulakeshin_II" title="Pulakeshin II">Pulakeshin II</a>. The rule of the Chalukyas marks an important milestone in the history of <a href="/wiki/South_India" title="South India">South India</a> and a golden age in the history of <a href="/wiki/Karnataka" title="Karnataka">Karnataka</a>. The political atmosphere in South India shifted from smaller kingdoms to large empires with the ascendancy of Badami Chalukyas. A Southern India-based kingdom took control and consolidated the entire region between the <a href="/wiki/Kaveri" title="Kaveri">Kaveri</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Narmada_River" title="Narmada River">Narmada</a> rivers. The rise of this empire saw the birth of efficient administration, overseas trade and commerce and the development of new style of architecture called "Chalukyan architecture". The <a href="/wiki/Chalukya_dynasty" title="Chalukya dynasty">Chalukya dynasty</a> ruled parts of southern and central India from Badami in Karnataka between 550 and 750, and then again from <a href="/wiki/Basavakalyan" title="Basavakalyan">Kalyani</a> between 970 and 1190.
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1021810730" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="mod-gallery mod-gallery-default mod-gallery-center"><div class="main"><div><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional nochecker bordered-images whitebg">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Galaganatha_Temple,_Pattadakal,_Karnataka.jpg" title="Galaganatha Temple at Pattadakal complex (UNESCO World Heritage) is an example of Badami Chalukya architecture."><img alt="Galaganatha Temple at Pattadakal complex (UNESCO World Heritage) is an example of Badami Chalukya architecture." data-file-height="926" data-file-width="830" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Galaganatha_Temple%2C_Pattadakal%2C_Karnataka.jpg/161px-Galaganatha_Temple%2C_Pattadakal%2C_Karnataka.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Galaganatha_Temple%2C_Pattadakal%2C_Karnataka.jpg/242px-Galaganatha_Temple%2C_Pattadakal%2C_Karnataka.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Galaganatha_Temple%2C_Pattadakal%2C_Karnataka.jpg/323px-Galaganatha_Temple%2C_Pattadakal%2C_Karnataka.jpg 2x" width="161"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Galaganatha Temple at <a href="/wiki/Pattadakal" title="Pattadakal">Pattadakal complex</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage" title="UNESCO World Heritage">UNESCO World Heritage</a>) is an example of <a href="/wiki/Badami_Chalukya_architecture" title="Badami Chalukya architecture">Badami Chalukya architecture</a>.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:51px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:View_of_Bhutanatha_temple_in_Badami_during_monsoon.jpg" title="Bhutanatha temple complex at Badami, next to a waterfall, during the monsoon."><img alt="Bhutanatha temple complex at Badami, next to a waterfall, during the monsoon." data-file-height="2373" data-file-width="3957" decoding="async" height="108" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/View_of_Bhutanatha_temple_in_Badami_during_monsoon.jpg/180px-View_of_Bhutanatha_temple_in_Badami_during_monsoon.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/View_of_Bhutanatha_temple_in_Badami_during_monsoon.jpg/270px-View_of_Bhutanatha_temple_in_Badami_during_monsoon.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/View_of_Bhutanatha_temple_in_Badami_during_monsoon.jpg/360px-View_of_Bhutanatha_temple_in_Badami_during_monsoon.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">

</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">

</p>

<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">

</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul></div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Rashtrakuta_Empire">Rashtrakuta Empire</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rashtrakuta_Empire" title="Rashtrakuta Empire">Rashtrakuta Empire</a></div>
<p>Founded by <a href="/wiki/Dantidurga" title="Dantidurga">Dantidurga</a> around 753,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThapar2003334_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThapar2003334-208">[206]</a></sup> the Rashtrakuta Empire ruled from its capital at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manyakheta" title="Manyakheta">Manyakheta</a> for almost two centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chandra_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chandra-209">[207]</a></sup> At its peak, the Rashtrakutas ruled from the Ganges River and Yamuna River doab in the north to Cape Comorin in the south, a fruitful time of political expansion, architectural achievements and famous literary contributions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKamath200189_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKamath200189-210">[208]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[209]</a></sup>
</p><p>The early rulers of this dynasty were Hindu, but the later rulers were strongly influenced by Jainism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESen1999380_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESen1999380-212">[210]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Govinda_III" title="Govinda III">Govinda III</a> and <a href="/wiki/Amoghavarsha" title="Amoghavarsha">Amoghavarsha</a> were the most famous of the long line of able administrators produced by the dynasty. Amoghavarsha, who ruled for 64 years, was also an author and wrote <a href="/wiki/Kavirajamarga" title="Kavirajamarga">Kavirajamarga</a>, the earliest known Kannada work on poetics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chandra_209-1"><a href="#cite_note-Chandra-209">[207]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESen1999380–381_213-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESen1999380–381-213">[211]</a></sup> Architecture reached a milestone in the Dravidian style, the finest example of which is seen in the Kailasanath Temple at Ellora. Other important contributions are the Kashivishvanatha temple and the Jain Narayana temple at <a href="/wiki/Pattadakal" title="Pattadakal">Pattadakal</a> in Karnataka.
</p><p>The Arab traveller Suleiman described the Rashtrakuta Empire as one of the four great Empires of the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDaniélou2003170_214-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDaniélou2003170-214">[212]</a></sup> The Rashtrakuta period marked the beginning of the golden age of southern Indian mathematics. The great south Indian mathematician <a href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81v%C4%ABra_(mathematician)" title="Mahāvīra (mathematician)">Mahāvīra</a> lived in the Rashtrakuta Empire and his text had a huge impact on the medieval south Indian mathematicians who lived after him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[213]</a></sup> The Rashtrakuta rulers also patronised men of letters, who wrote in a variety of languages from Sanskrit to the <a href="/wiki/Apabhra%E1%B9%83%C5%9Ba" title="Apabhraṃśa">Apabhraṃśas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chandra_209-2"><a href="#cite_note-Chandra-209">[207]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1021810730" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="mod-gallery mod-gallery-default mod-gallery-center"><div class="main"><div><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional nochecker bordered-images whitebg">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:38px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ellora_Cave_16_si0308.jpg" title="Kailasa temple, is one of the largest rock-cut ancient Hindu temples located in Ellora."><img alt="Kailasa temple, is one of the largest rock-cut ancient Hindu temples located in Ellora." data-file-height="1170" data-file-width="1571" decoding="async" height="134" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Ellora_Cave_16_si0308.jpg/180px-Ellora_Cave_16_si0308.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Ellora_Cave_16_si0308.jpg/270px-Ellora_Cave_16_si0308.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Ellora_Cave_16_si0308.jpg/360px-Ellora_Cave_16_si0308.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Kailasa_Temple,_Ellora" title="Kailasa Temple, Ellora">Kailasa temple</a>, is one of the largest <a href="/wiki/Indian_rock-cut_architecture" title="Indian rock-cut architecture">rock-cut</a> ancient <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple" title="Hindu temple">Hindu temples</a> located in <a href="/wiki/Ellora_Caves" title="Ellora Caves">Ellora</a>.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">

<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">

</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">

</div></li>
</ul></div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Gurjara-Pratihara_Empire">Gurjara-Pratihara Empire</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gurjara-Pratihara_Empire" title="Gurjara-Pratihara Empire">Gurjara-Pratihara Empire</a></div>
<p>The Gurjara-Pratiharas were instrumental in containing Arab armies moving east of the <a href="/wiki/Indus_River" title="Indus River">Indus River</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[214]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Nagabhata_I" title="Nagabhata I">Nagabhata I</a> defeated the Arab army under Junaid and Tamin during the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caliphate_campaigns_in_India" title="Caliphate campaigns in India">Caliphate campaigns in India</a>. Under <a href="/wiki/Nagabhata_II" title="Nagabhata II">Nagabhata II</a>, the Gurjara-Pratiharas became the most powerful dynasty in northern India. He was succeeded by his son <a href="/wiki/Ramabhadra" title="Ramabhadra">Ramabhadra</a>, who ruled briefly before being succeeded by his son, <a href="/wiki/Mihira_Bhoja" title="Mihira Bhoja">Mihira Bhoja</a>. Under Bhoja and his successor <a href="/wiki/Mahendrapala_I" title="Mahendrapala I">Mahendrapala I</a>, the Pratihara Empire reached its peak of prosperity and power. By the time of Mahendrapala, the extent of its territory rivalled that of the <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta Empire</a> stretching from the border of <a href="/wiki/Sindh" title="Sindh">Sindh</a> in the west to Bihar in the east and from the <a href="/wiki/Himalayas" title="Himalayas">Himalayas</a> in the north to areas past the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Narmada" title="Narmada">Narmada</a> in the south.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAvari2007303_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAvari2007303-217">[215]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag needs to be fact-checked with the cited source(s). (June 2022)">verification needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The expansion triggered a <a href="/wiki/Tripartite_Struggle" title="Tripartite Struggle">tripartite power struggle</a> with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rashtrakuta" title="Rashtrakuta">Rashtrakuta</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pala_Empire" title="Pala Empire">Pala</a> empires for control of the Indian subcontinent. During this period, Imperial Pratihara took the title of <i><a href="/wiki/Maharaja" title="Maharaja">Maharajadhiraja</a> of <a href="/wiki/%C4%80ry%C4%81varta" title="Āryāvarta">Āryāvarta</a></i> (<i>Great King of Kings of India</i>).<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>By the 10th century, several feudatories of the empire took advantage of the temporary weakness of the Gurjara-Pratiharas to declare their independence, notably the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paramara" title="Paramara">Paramaras</a> of Malwa, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chandela" title="Chandela">Chandelas</a> of <a href="/wiki/Bundelkhand" title="Bundelkhand">Bundelkhand</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Kalachuris_of_Tripuri" title="Kalachuris of Tripuri">Kalachuris</a> of <a href="/wiki/Mahakoshal" title="Mahakoshal">Mahakoshal</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tomaras" title="Tomaras">Tomaras</a> of <a href="/wiki/Haryana" title="Haryana">Haryana</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Chahamanas_of_Shakambhari" title="Chahamanas of Shakambhari">Chauhans</a> of <a href="/wiki/Rajputana" title="Rajputana">Rajputana</a>.
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1021810730" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="mod-gallery mod-gallery-default mod-gallery-center"><div class="main"><div><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional nochecker bordered-images whitebg">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Teli_ka_Mandir_(15702266503).jpg" title="One of the four entrances of the Teli ka Mandir. </p>

<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">

</p>

</div></li>
</ul></div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Gahadavala_dynasty">Gahadavala dynasty</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Gahadavala_dynasty" title="Gahadavala dynasty">Gahadavala dynasty</a></div>
<p>Gahadavala dynasty ruled parts of the present-day <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_states" title="Indian states">Indian states</a> of <a href="/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh" title="Uttar Pradesh">Uttar Pradesh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bihar" title="Bihar">Bihar</a>, during 11th and 12th centuries. Their capital was located at <a href="/wiki/Varanasi" title="Varanasi">Varanasi</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Gangetic_Plain" title="Indo-Gangetic Plain">Gangetic plains</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENiyogi195938_219-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENiyogi195938-219">[217]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Khayaravala_dynasty">Khayaravala dynasty</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Khayaravala_dynasty" title="Khayaravala dynasty">Khayaravala dynasty</a></div><p>
The Khayaravala dynasty, ruled parts of the present-day <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_states" title="Indian states">Indian states</a> of <a href="/wiki/Bihar" title="Bihar">Bihar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jharkhand" title="Jharkhand">Jharkhand</a>, during 11th and 12th centuries. Their capital was located at Khayaragarh in <a href="/wiki/Shahabad_district" title="Shahabad district">Shahabad district</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pratapdhavala" title="Pratapdhavala">Pratapdhavala</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shri_Pratapa" title="Shri Pratapa">Shri Pratapa</a> were king of the dynasty according to inscription of <a href="/wiki/Rohtas_Fort,_India" title="Rohtas Fort, India">Rohtas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[218]</a></sup></p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rohtasgarh_Fort_Entrance.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Rohtasgarh_Fort_Entrance.jpg/220px-Rohtasgarh_Fort_Entrance.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Rohtasgarh_Fort_Entrance.jpg/330px-Rohtasgarh_Fort_Entrance.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Rohtasgarh_Fort_Entrance.jpg/440px-Rohtasgarh_Fort_Entrance.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Rohtasgarh_Fort_Entrance.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Rohtas_Fort,_India" title="Rohtas Fort, India">Rohtasgarh Fort</a></div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pala_Empire">Pala Empire</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nalanda_University_India_ruins.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Nalanda_University_India_ruins.jpg/220px-Nalanda_University_India_ruins.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Nalanda_University_India_ruins.jpg/330px-Nalanda_University_India_ruins.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Nalanda_University_India_ruins.jpg/440px-Nalanda_University_India_ruins.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Nalanda_University_India_ruins.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Excavated ruins of <a href="/wiki/Nalanda" title="Nalanda">Nalanda</a>, a centre of Buddhist learning from 450 to 1193 CE.</div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Pala_Empire" title="Pala Empire">Pala Empire</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Pala_Empire" title="Pala Empire">Pala Empire</a> was founded by <a href="/wiki/Gopala_I" title="Gopala I">Gopala I</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[219]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nitish2011_222-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nitish2011-222">[220]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Biplab2005_223-0"><a href="#cite_note-Biplab2005-223">[221]</a></sup> It was ruled by a Buddhist dynasty from Bengal in the eastern region of the Indian subcontinent. The Palas reunified Bengal after the fall of <a href="/wiki/Shashanka" title="Shashanka">Shashanka</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Gauda_Kingdom" title="Gauda Kingdom">Gauda Kingdom</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[222]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Palas were followers of the <a href="/wiki/Mahayana" title="Mahayana">Mahayana</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tantric_Buddhism" title="Tantric Buddhism">Tantric</a> schools of Buddhism,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[223]</a></sup> they also patronised <a href="/wiki/Shaivism" title="Shaivism">Shaivism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vaishnavism" title="Vaishnavism">Vaishnavism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChandraPala_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-ChandraPala-226">[224]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Morpheme" title="Morpheme">morpheme</a> <i>Pala</i>, meaning "protector", was used as an ending for the names of all the Pala monarchs. The empire reached its peak under <a href="/wiki/Dharmapala_(emperor)" title="Dharmapala (emperor)">Dharmapala</a> and <a href="/wiki/Devapala_(Pala_dynasty)" title="Devapala (Pala dynasty)">Devapala</a>. Dharmapala is believed to have conquered Kanauj and extended his sway up to the farthest limits of India in the northwest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChandraPala_226-1"><a href="#cite_note-ChandraPala-226">[224]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Pala Empire can be considered as the golden era of Bengal in many ways.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESen1999278_227-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESen1999278-227">[225]</a></sup> Dharmapala founded the <a href="/wiki/Vikramashila" title="Vikramashila">Vikramashila</a> and revived Nalanda,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChandraPala_226-2"><a href="#cite_note-ChandraPala-226">[224]</a></sup> considered one of the first great universities in recorded history. Nalanda reached its height under the patronage of the Pala Empire.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESen1999278_227-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESen1999278-227">[225]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PNChopra2003_228-0"><a href="#cite_note-PNChopra2003-228">[226]</a></sup> The Palas also built many <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vihara" title="Vihara">viharas</a>. They maintained close cultural and commercial ties with countries of Southeast Asia and <a href="/wiki/Tibet" title="Tibet">Tibet</a>. Sea trade added greatly to the prosperity of the Pala Empire. The Arab merchant Suleiman notes the enormity of the Pala army in his memoirs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChandraPala_226-3"><a href="#cite_note-ChandraPala-226">[224]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cholas">Cholas</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Chola_dynasty" title="Chola dynasty">Chola dynasty</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rajendra_map_new.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="333" data-file-width="466" decoding="async" height="179" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Rajendra_map_new.svg/250px-Rajendra_map_new.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Rajendra_map_new.svg/375px-Rajendra_map_new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Rajendra_map_new.svg/500px-Rajendra_map_new.svg.png 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Rajendra_map_new.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chola_Empire" title="Chola Empire">Chola Empire</a> under <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rajendra_Chola" title="Rajendra Chola">Rajendra Chola</a>, c. 1030 CE.</div></div></div>
<p>Medieval Cholas rose to prominence during the middle of the 9th century CE and established the greatest empire South India had seen.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[227]</a></sup> They successfully united the South India under their rule and through their naval strength extended their influence in the Southeast Asian countries such as Srivijaya.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Dancing_Girl_p.129_204-1"><a href="#cite_note-The_Dancing_Girl_p.129-204">[202]</a></sup> Under <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rajaraja_Chola_I" title="Rajaraja Chola I">Rajaraja Chola I</a> and his successors <a href="/wiki/Rajendra_Chola_I" title="Rajendra Chola I">Rajendra Chola I</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rajadhiraja_Chola" title="Rajadhiraja Chola">Rajadhiraja Chola</a>, <a href="/wiki/Virarajendra_Chola" title="Virarajendra Chola">Virarajendra Chola</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kulothunga_Chola_I" title="Kulothunga Chola I">Kulothunga Chola I</a> the dynasty became a military, economic and cultural power in South Asia and South-East Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund2004115_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund2004115-230">[228]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-keay215_231-0"><a href="#cite_note-keay215-231">[229]</a></sup> Rajendra Chola I's navies went even further, occupying the sea coasts from Burma to Vietnam,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[230]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Andaman_and_Nicobar_Islands" title="Andaman and Nicobar Islands">Andaman and Nicobar Islands</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Lakshadweep" title="Lakshadweep">Lakshadweep</a> (Laccadive) islands, <a href="/wiki/Sumatra" title="Sumatra">Sumatra</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Malay_Peninsula" title="Malay Peninsula">Malay Peninsula</a> in Southeast Asia and the Pegu islands. The power of the new empire was proclaimed to the eastern world by the expedition to the <a href="/wiki/Ganges" title="Ganges">Ganges</a> which Rajendra Chola I undertook and by the occupation of cities of the maritime empire of <a href="/wiki/Srivijaya" title="Srivijaya">Srivijaya</a> in Southeast Asia, as well as by the repeated embassies to China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sastri158_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-sastri158-233">[231]</a></sup>
</p><p>They dominated the political affairs of Sri Lanka for over two centuries through repeated invasions and occupation. They also had continuing trade contacts with the Arabs in the west and with the Chinese empire in the east.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[232]</a></sup> Rajaraja Chola I and his equally distinguished son Rajendra Chola I gave political unity to the whole of Southern India and established the Chola Empire as a respected sea power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[233]</a></sup> Under the Cholas, the South India reached new heights of excellence in art, religion and literature. In all of these spheres, the Chola period marked the culmination of movements that had begun in an earlier age under the Pallavas. Monumental architecture in the form of majestic temples and sculpture in stone and bronze reached a finesse never before achieved in India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[234]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1021810730" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="mod-gallery mod-gallery-default mod-gallery-center"><div class="main"><div><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional nochecker bordered-images whitebg">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Big_Temple-Temple.jpg" title="The granite gopuram (tower) of Brihadeeswarar Temple, 1010 CE."><img alt="The granite gopuram (tower) of Brihadeeswarar Temple, 1010 CE." data-file-height="1024" data-file-width="768" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Big_Temple-Temple.jpg/135px-Big_Temple-Temple.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Big_Temple-Temple.jpg/202px-Big_Temple-Temple.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Big_Temple-Temple.jpg/270px-Big_Temple-Temple.jpg 2x" width="135"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>The granite <a href="/wiki/Gopuram" title="Gopuram">gopuram (tower)</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brihadeeswarar_Temple" title="Brihadeeswarar Temple">Brihadeeswarar Temple</a>, 1010 CE.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:37.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chariot_detail,_Airavatesvara,_Tamil_Nadu.jpg" title="Chariot detail at Airavatesvara Temple built by Rajaraja Chola II in the 12th century CE."><img alt="Chariot detail at Airavatesvara Temple built by Rajaraja Chola II in the 12th century CE." data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="3264" decoding="async" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Chariot_detail%2C_Airavatesvara%2C_Tamil_Nadu.jpg/180px-Chariot_detail%2C_Airavatesvara%2C_Tamil_Nadu.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Chariot_detail%2C_Airavatesvara%2C_Tamil_Nadu.jpg/270px-Chariot_detail%2C_Airavatesvara%2C_Tamil_Nadu.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Chariot_detail%2C_Airavatesvara%2C_Tamil_Nadu.jpg/360px-Chariot_detail%2C_Airavatesvara%2C_Tamil_Nadu.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Chariot detail at <a href="/wiki/Airavatesvara_Temple" title="Airavatesvara Temple">Airavatesvara Temple</a> built by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rajaraja_Chola_II" title="Rajaraja Chola II">Rajaraja Chola II</a> in the 12th century CE.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Back_view_of_Raja_gopuram.jpg" title="The pyramidal structure above the sanctum at Brihadisvara Temple."><img alt="The pyramidal structure above the sanctum at Brihadisvara Temple." data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="2304" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Back_view_of_Raja_gopuram.jpg/120px-Back_view_of_Raja_gopuram.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Back_view_of_Raja_gopuram.jpg/180px-Back_view_of_Raja_gopuram.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Back_view_of_Raja_gopuram.jpg/240px-Back_view_of_Raja_gopuram.jpg 2x" width="120"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>The pyramidal structure above the sanctum at <a href="/wiki/Brihadisvara_Temple,_Gangaikonda_Cholapuram" title="Brihadisvara Temple, Gangaikonda Cholapuram">Brihadisvara Temple</a>.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:45px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Brihadeeswara_Temple_Entrance_Gopurams,_Thanjavur.JPG" title="Brihadeeswara Temple Entrance Gopurams at Thanjavur."><img alt="Brihadeeswara Temple Entrance Gopurams at Thanjavur." data-file-height="1728" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Brihadeeswara_Temple_Entrance_Gopurams%2C_Thanjavur.JPG/180px-Brihadeeswara_Temple_Entrance_Gopurams%2C_Thanjavur.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Brihadeeswara_Temple_Entrance_Gopurams%2C_Thanjavur.JPG/270px-Brihadeeswara_Temple_Entrance_Gopurams%2C_Thanjavur.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Brihadeeswara_Temple_Entrance_Gopurams%2C_Thanjavur.JPG/360px-Brihadeeswara_Temple_Entrance_Gopurams%2C_Thanjavur.JPG 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Brihadeeswara Temple Entrance Gopurams at <a href="/wiki/Thanjavur" title="Thanjavur">Thanjavur</a>.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul></div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Western_Chalukya_Empire">Western Chalukya Empire</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Western_Chalukya_Empire" title="Western Chalukya Empire">Western Chalukya Empire</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Western_Chalukya_Empire" title="Western Chalukya Empire">Western Chalukya Empire</a> ruled most of the <a href="/wiki/Deccan_Plateau" title="Deccan Plateau">western Deccan</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_India" title="South India">South India</a>, between the 10th and 12th centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Medieval_India_p.24_237-0"><a href="#cite_note-Medieval_India_p.24-237">[235]</a></sup> Vast areas between the <a href="/wiki/Narmada_River" title="Narmada River">Narmada River</a> in the north and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kaveri_River" title="Kaveri River">Kaveri River</a> in the south came under Chalukya control.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Medieval_India_p.24_237-1"><a href="#cite_note-Medieval_India_p.24-237">[235]</a></sup> During this period the other major ruling families of the Deccan, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hoysalas" title="Hoysalas">Hoysalas</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seuna_Yadavas_of_Devagiri" title="Seuna Yadavas of Devagiri">Seuna Yadavas of Devagiri</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Kakatiya_dynasty" title="Kakatiya dynasty">Kakatiya dynasty</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Kalachuris_of_Kalyani" title="Kalachuris of Kalyani">Southern Kalachuris</a>, were subordinates of the Western Chalukyas and gained their independence only when the power of the Chalukya waned during the latter half of the 12th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[236]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Western Chalukyas developed an architectural style known today as a transitional style, an architectural link between the style of the early Chalukya dynasty and that of the later Hoysala empire. Most of its monuments are in the districts bordering the Tungabhadra River in central Karnataka. Well known examples are the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kasivisvesvara_Temple" title="Kasivisvesvara Temple">Kasivisvesvara Temple</a> at <a href="/wiki/Lakkundi" title="Lakkundi">Lakkundi</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Mallikarjuna_Temple,_Kuruvatti" title="Mallikarjuna Temple, Kuruvatti">Mallikarjuna Temple</a> at Kuruvatti, the <a href="/wiki/Kalleshvara_Temple,_Bagali" title="Kalleshvara Temple, Bagali">Kallesvara Temple</a> at Bagali, <a href="/wiki/Siddhesvara_Temple" title="Siddhesvara Temple">Siddhesvara Temple</a> at Haveri, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mahadeva_Temple_(Itagi)" title="Mahadeva Temple (Itagi)">Mahadeva Temple</a> at Itagi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[237]</a></sup> This was an important period in the development of fine arts in Southern India, especially in literature as the Western Chalukya kings encouraged writers in the native language of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kannada_language" title="Kannada language">Kannada</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> like the philosopher and statesman <a href="/wiki/Basava" title="Basava">Basava</a> and the great mathematician <a href="/wiki/Bh%C4%81skara_II" title="Bhāskara II">Bhāskara II</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[238]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[239]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1021810730" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="mod-gallery mod-gallery-default mod-gallery-center"><div class="main"><div><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional nochecker bordered-images whitebg">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Profile_of_the_vimana_(sanctum_outerwall_and_tower)_of_the_Siddhesvara_temple_at_Haveri_2.JPG" title="Shrine outer wall and Dravida style superstructure (shikhara) at Siddhesvara Temple at Haveri."><img alt="Shrine outer wall and Dravida style superstructure (shikhara) at Siddhesvara Temple at Haveri." data-file-height="5184" data-file-width="3456" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Profile_of_the_vimana_%28sanctum_outerwall_and_tower%29_of_the_Siddhesvara_temple_at_Haveri_2.JPG/120px-Profile_of_the_vimana_%28sanctum_outerwall_and_tower%29_of_the_Siddhesvara_temple_at_Haveri_2.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Profile_of_the_vimana_%28sanctum_outerwall_and_tower%29_of_the_Siddhesvara_temple_at_Haveri_2.JPG/180px-Profile_of_the_vimana_%28sanctum_outerwall_and_tower%29_of_the_Siddhesvara_temple_at_Haveri_2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Profile_of_the_vimana_%28sanctum_outerwall_and_tower%29_of_the_Siddhesvara_temple_at_Haveri_2.JPG/240px-Profile_of_the_vimana_%28sanctum_outerwall_and_tower%29_of_the_Siddhesvara_temple_at_Haveri_2.JPG 2x" width="120"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">

</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:45px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ornate_entrance_to_closed_mantapa_in_Kalleshvara_temple_at_Bagali.JPG" title="Ornate entrance to the closed hall from the south at Kalleshvara Temple at Bagali."><img alt="Ornate entrance to the closed hall from the south at Kalleshvara Temple at Bagali." data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" decoding="async" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Ornate_entrance_to_closed_mantapa_in_Kalleshvara_temple_at_Bagali.JPG/180px-Ornate_entrance_to_closed_mantapa_in_Kalleshvara_temple_at_Bagali.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Ornate_entrance_to_closed_mantapa_in_Kalleshvara_temple_at_Bagali.JPG/270px-Ornate_entrance_to_closed_mantapa_in_Kalleshvara_temple_at_Bagali.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Ornate_entrance_to_closed_mantapa_in_Kalleshvara_temple_at_Bagali.JPG/360px-Ornate_entrance_to_closed_mantapa_in_Kalleshvara_temple_at_Bagali.JPG 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>

</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">

</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rear_view_showing_lateral_entrances_of_the_Mahadeva_Temple_at_Itagi_in_the_Koppal_district.JPG" title="Rear view showing lateral entrances of the Mahadeva Temple at Itagi."><img alt="Rear view showing lateral entrances of the Mahadeva Temple at Itagi." data-file-height="5184" data-file-width="3456" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Rear_view_showing_lateral_entrances_of_the_Mahadeva_Temple_at_Itagi_in_the_Koppal_district.JPG/120px-Rear_view_showing_lateral_entrances_of_the_Mahadeva_Temple_at_Itagi_in_the_Koppal_district.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Rear_view_showing_lateral_entrances_of_the_Mahadeva_Temple_at_Itagi_in_the_Koppal_district.JPG/180px-Rear_view_showing_lateral_entrances_of_the_Mahadeva_Temple_at_Itagi_in_the_Koppal_district.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Rear_view_showing_lateral_entrances_of_the_Mahadeva_Temple_at_Itagi_in_the_Koppal_district.JPG/240px-Rear_view_showing_lateral_entrances_of_the_Mahadeva_Temple_at_Itagi_in_the_Koppal_district.JPG 2x" width="120"/></a></div></div>
