</ul></div></div></div>
<h2><span id="Late_medieval_period_.28c._1200.E2.80.931526_CE.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Late_medieval_period_(c._1200–1526_CE)">Late medieval period (c. 1200–1526 CE)</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Medieval_India" title="Medieval India">Medieval India</a></div>
<p>The late <a href="/wiki/Medieval_India" title="Medieval India">medieval period</a> is marked by repeated invasions of the Muslim Central Asian nomadic clans,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200847_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200847-242">[240]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf20066_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf20066-243">[241]</a></sup> the rule of the Delhi sultanate, and by the growth of other dynasties and empires, built upon military technology of the Sultanate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200853_244-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200853-244">[242]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Delhi_Sultanate">Delhi Sultanate</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Delhi_Sultanate" title="Delhi Sultanate">Delhi Sultanate</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tughlaq_dynasty_1321_-_1398_ad.PNG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="703" data-file-width="503" decoding="async" height="307" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Tughlaq_dynasty_1321_-_1398_ad.PNG/220px-Tughlaq_dynasty_1321_-_1398_ad.PNG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Tughlaq_dynasty_1321_-_1398_ad.PNG/330px-Tughlaq_dynasty_1321_-_1398_ad.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Tughlaq_dynasty_1321_-_1398_ad.PNG/440px-Tughlaq_dynasty_1321_-_1398_ad.PNG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tughlaq_dynasty_1321_-_1398_ad.PNG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Delhi_Sultanate" title="Delhi Sultanate">Delhi Sultanate</a> reached its zenith under the <a href="/wiki/Turkic_peoples" title="Turkic peoples">Turko</a>-<a href="/wiki/Indian_people" title="Indian people">Indian</a> <a href="/wiki/Tughlaq_dynasty" title="Tughlaq dynasty">Tughlaq dynasty</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-malik_245-0"><a href="#cite_note-malik-245">[243]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The Delhi Sultanate was a series of successive <a href="/wiki/Islamic_state" title="Islamic state">Islamic states</a> based in Delhi, ruled by several dynasties of <a href="/wiki/Turkic_peoples" title="Turkic peoples">Turkic</a>, Turko-Indian<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-whunter_246-0"><a href="#cite_note-whunter-246">[244]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pashtun" title="Pashtun">Pashtun</a> origins.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[245]</a></sup> It ruled large parts of the Indian subcontinent from the 13th century to the early 16th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-delhi_248-0"><a href="#cite_note-delhi-248">[246]</a></sup> In the 12th and 13th centuries, Central Asian Turks invaded parts of northern India and established the Delhi Sultanate in the former Hindu holdings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[247]</a></sup> The subsequent <a href="/wiki/Mamluk_dynasty_(Delhi)" title="Mamluk dynasty (Delhi)">Mamluk dynasty</a> of <a href="/wiki/Delhi" title="Delhi">Delhi</a> managed to conquer large areas of northern India, while the <a href="/wiki/Khalji_dynasty" title="Khalji dynasty">Khalji dynasty</a> conquered most of central India while forcing the principal Hindu kingdoms of South India to become <a href="/wiki/Vassal_state" title="Vassal state">vassal states</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-delhi_248-1"><a href="#cite_note-delhi-248">[246]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Sultanate ushered in a period of Indian cultural renaissance. The resulting "Indo-Muslim" fusion of cultures left lasting syncretic monuments in architecture, music, literature, religion, and clothing. It is surmised that the language of <a href="/wiki/Urdu" title="Urdu">Urdu</a> was born during the Delhi Sultanate period as a result of the intermingling of the local speakers of Sanskritic <a href="/wiki/Prakrit" title="Prakrit">Prakrits</a> with immigrants speaking <a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkic_languages" title="Turkic languages">Turkic</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a> under the Muslim rulers. The Delhi Sultanate is the only Indo-Islamic empire to enthrone one of the few female rulers in India, <a href="/wiki/Razia_Sultana" title="Razia Sultana">Razia Sultana</a> (1236–1240).
</p><p>During the Delhi Sultanate, there was a synthesis between Indian civilisation and <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Golden_Age" title="Islamic Golden Age">Islamic civilisation</a><sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs a reliable source. (March 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>. The latter was a <a href="/wiki/Cosmopolitanism" title="Cosmopolitanism">cosmopolitan</a> civilisation, with a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Multicultural" title="Multicultural">multicultural</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cultural_pluralism" title="Cultural pluralism">pluralistic</a> society, and wide-ranging international networks, including social and economic networks, spanning large parts of <a href="/wiki/Afro-Eurasia" title="Afro-Eurasia">Afro-Eurasia</a>, leading to escalating circulation of goods, peoples, technologies and ideas. While initially disruptive due to the passing of power from native Indian elites to Turkic Muslim elites, the Delhi Sultanate was responsible for integrating the Indian subcontinent into a growing world system, drawing India into a wider international network, which had a significant impact on Indian culture and society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200850–52_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200850–52-250">[248]</a></sup> However, the Delhi Sultanate also caused large-scale destruction and desecration of temples in the Indian subcontinent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-re2000_251-0"><a href="#cite_note-re2000-251">[249]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasions_of_India" title="Mongol invasions of India">Mongol invasions of India</a> were successfully repelled by the Delhi Sultanate during the rule of <a href="/wiki/Alauddin_Khalji" title="Alauddin Khalji">Alauddin Khalji</a>. A major factor in their success was their Turkic <a href="/wiki/Mamluk" title="Mamluk">Mamluk</a> slave army, who were highly skilled in the same style of nomadic <a href="/wiki/Cavalry" title="Cavalry">cavalry</a> warfare as the <a href="/wiki/Mongols" title="Mongols">Mongols</a>, as a result of having similar <a href="/wiki/Nomad" title="Nomad">nomadic</a> Central Asian roots. It is possible that the Mongol Empire may have expanded into India were it not for the Delhi Sultanate's role in repelling them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200850–51_252-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200850–51-252">[250]</a></sup> By repeatedly repulsing the Mongol raiders, the sultanate saved India from the devastation visited on West and Central Asia, setting the scene for centuries of <a href="/wiki/Human_migration" title="Human migration">migration</a> of fleeing soldiers, learned men, mystics, traders, artists, and artisans from that region into the subcontinent, thereby creating a syncretic Indo-Islamic culture in the north.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELudden200267_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELudden200267-253">[251]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200850–51_252-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200850–51-252">[250]</a></sup>
</p><p>A <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turco-Mongol" title="Turco-Mongol">Turco-Mongol</a> conqueror in Central Asia, <a href="/wiki/Timur" title="Timur">Timur</a> (Tamerlane), attacked the reigning Sultan Nasir-u Din Mehmud of the <a href="/wiki/Tughlaq_dynasty" title="Tughlaq dynasty">Tughlaq dynasty</a> in the north Indian city of Delhi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[252]</a></sup> The Sultan's army was defeated on 17 December 1398. Timur entered Delhi and the city was sacked, destroyed, and left in ruins after Timur's army had killed and plundered for three days and nights. He ordered the whole city to be sacked except for the <a href="/wiki/Sayyid" title="Sayyid">sayyids</a>, scholars, and the "other Muslims" (artists); 100,000 war prisoners were put to death in one day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[253]</a></sup> The Sultanate suffered significantly from the sacking of Delhi. Though revived briefly under the <a href="/wiki/Lodi_dynasty" title="Lodi dynasty">Lodi dynasty</a>, it was but a shadow of the former.
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1021810730" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="mod-gallery mod-gallery-default mod-gallery-center"><div class="main"><div><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional nochecker bordered-images whitebg">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Qutb_minar_ruins.jpg" title="Qutb Minar, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, whose construction was begun by Qutb ud-Din Aibak, the first Sultan of Delhi."><img alt="Qutb Minar, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, whose construction was begun by Qutb ud-Din Aibak, the first Sultan of Delhi." data-file-height="2250" data-file-width="1500" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Qutb_minar_ruins.jpg/120px-Qutb_minar_ruins.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Qutb_minar_ruins.jpg/180px-Qutb_minar_ruins.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Qutb_minar_ruins.jpg/240px-Qutb_minar_ruins.jpg 2x" width="120"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Qutb_Minar" title="Qutb Minar">Qutb Minar</a>, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>, whose construction was begun by <a href="/wiki/Qutb_ud-Din_Aibak" title="Qutb ud-Din Aibak">Qutb ud-Din Aibak</a>, the first Sultan of Delhi.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:37.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nizamuddin_Dargah_and_Jamaat_Khana_Masjid,_Delhi.jpg" title="Dargahs of Sufi-saint Nizamuddin Auliya, and poet and musician Amir Khusro in Delhi."><img alt="Dargahs of Sufi-saint Nizamuddin Auliya, and poet and musician Amir Khusro in Delhi." data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Nizamuddin_Dargah_and_Jamaat_Khana_Masjid%2C_Delhi.jpg/180px-Nizamuddin_Dargah_and_Jamaat_Khana_Masjid%2C_Delhi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Nizamuddin_Dargah_and_Jamaat_Khana_Masjid%2C_Delhi.jpg/270px-Nizamuddin_Dargah_and_Jamaat_Khana_Masjid%2C_Delhi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Nizamuddin_Dargah_and_Jamaat_Khana_Masjid%2C_Delhi.jpg/360px-Nizamuddin_Dargah_and_Jamaat_Khana_Masjid%2C_Delhi.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">

</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:37.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tomb_of_Razia_Sultana_001.jpg" title="The grave of Razia, the Sultana of Delhi, from 1236 CE to 1240 CE, the only female ruler of a major realm on the Indian subcontinent until modern times.[citation needed]"><img alt="The grave of Razia, the Sultana of Delhi, from 1236 CE to 1240 CE, the only female ruler of a major realm on the Indian subcontinent until modern times.[citation needed]" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Tomb_of_Razia_Sultana_001.jpg/180px-Tomb_of_Razia_Sultana_001.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Tomb_of_Razia_Sultana_001.jpg/270px-Tomb_of_Razia_Sultana_001.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Tomb_of_Razia_Sultana_001.jpg/360px-Tomb_of_Razia_Sultana_001.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>

(August 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>

</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">

</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">

</div>
</div></li>
</ul></div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Vijayanagara_Empire">Vijayanagara Empire</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Vijayanagara_Empire" title="Vijayanagara Empire">Vijayanagara Empire</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:342px;max-width:342px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader">Vijayanagara Empire</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:336px;max-width:336px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:227px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Poligars1525.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="547" data-file-width="802" decoding="async" height="228" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4e/Poligars1525.jpg/334px-Poligars1525.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4e/Poligars1525.jpg/501px-Poligars1525.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4e/Poligars1525.jpg/668px-Poligars1525.jpg 2x" width="334"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">The <a href="/wiki/Vijayanagara_Empire" title="Vijayanagara Empire">Vijayanagara Empire</a> in 1525</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The Vijayanagara Empire was established in 1336 by <a href="/wiki/Harihara_I" title="Harihara I">Harihara I</a> and his brother <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bukka_Raya_I" title="Bukka Raya I">Bukka Raya I</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sangama_Dynasty" title="Sangama Dynasty">Sangama Dynasty</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[254]</a></sup> which originated as a political heir of the <a href="/wiki/Hoysala_Empire" title="Hoysala Empire">Hoysala Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kakatiya_dynasty" title="Kakatiya dynasty">Kakatiya Empire</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEaton200528–29_257-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEaton200528–29-257">[255]</a></sup> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pandyan_Empire" title="Pandyan Empire">Pandyan Empire</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESastri2002239_258-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESastri2002239-258">[256]</a></sup> The empire rose to prominence as a culmination of attempts by the south Indian powers to ward off <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic_invasions_of_India" title="Islamic invasions of India">Islamic invasions</a> by the end of the 13th century. It lasted until 1646, although its power declined after a major military defeat in 1565 by the combined armies of the <a href="/wiki/Deccan_sultanates" title="Deccan sultanates">Deccan sultanates</a>. The empire is named after its capital city of <a href="/wiki/Vijayanagara" title="Vijayanagara">Vijayanagara</a>, whose ruins surround present day <a href="/wiki/Hampi" title="Hampi">Hampi</a>, now a <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a> in <a href="/wiki/Karnataka" title="Karnataka">Karnataka</a>, <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[257]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the first two decades after the founding of the empire, Harihara I gained control over most of the area south of the Tungabhadra river and earned the title of <i>Purvapaschima Samudradhishavara</i> ("master of the eastern and western seas"). By 1374 Bukka Raya I, successor to Harihara I, had defeated the chiefdom of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arcot" title="Arcot">Arcot</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Reddy" title="Reddy">Reddys</a> of Kondavidu, and the <a href="/wiki/Madurai_Sultanate" title="Madurai Sultanate">Sultan of Madurai</a> and had gained control over <a href="/wiki/Goa" title="Goa">Goa</a> in the west and the Tungabhadra-<a href="/wiki/Krishna_River" title="Krishna River">Krishna River</a> <a href="/wiki/Doab" title="Doab">doab</a> in the north.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKamath2001162_260-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKamath2001162-260">[258]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESastri1955317_261-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESastri1955317-261">[259]</a></sup>
</p><p>With the Vijayanagara Kingdom now imperial in stature, <a href="/wiki/Harihara_II" title="Harihara II">Harihara II</a>, the second son of Bukka Raya I, further consolidated the kingdom beyond the <a href="/wiki/Krishna_River" title="Krishna River">Krishna River</a> and brought the whole of South India under the Vijayanagara umbrella.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-umbrella_262-0"><a href="#cite_note-umbrella-262">[260]</a></sup> The next ruler, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Deva_Raya_I" title="Deva Raya I">Deva Raya I</a>, emerged successful against the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gajapatis" title="Gajapatis">Gajapatis</a> of <a href="/wiki/Odisha" title="Odisha">Odisha</a> and undertook important works of fortification and irrigation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aqueduct_263-0"><a href="#cite_note-aqueduct-263">[261]</a></sup> Italian traveler Niccolo de Conti wrote of him as the most powerful ruler of India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[262]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Deva_Raya_II" title="Deva Raya II">Deva Raya II</a> (called <i>Gajabetekara</i>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hunter_265-0"><a href="#cite_note-hunter-265">[263]</a></sup> succeeded to the throne in 1424 and was possibly the most capable of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sangama_Dynasty" title="Sangama Dynasty">Sangama Dynasty</a> rulers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESastri1955244_266-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESastri1955244-266">[264]</a></sup> He quelled rebelling feudal lords as well as the <a href="/wiki/Zamorin" title="Zamorin">Zamorin</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_Kozhikode" title="History of Kozhikode">Calicut</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Quilon" title="Quilon">Quilon</a> in the south. He invaded the island of <a href="/wiki/Sri_Lanka" title="Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a> and became overlord of the kings of <a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Burma</a> at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pegu" title="Pegu">Pegu</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tanintharyi_Division" title="Tanintharyi Division">Tanasserim</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[265]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKamath2001163_268-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKamath2001163-268">[266]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[267]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Vijayanagara Emperors were tolerant of all religions and sects, as writings by foreign visitors show.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-democracy_270-0"><a href="#cite_note-democracy-270">[268]</a></sup> The kings used titles such as <i>Gobrahamana Pratipalanacharya</i> (<i>literally</i>, "protector of cows and Brahmins") and <i>Hindurayasuratrana</i> (<i>lit</i>, "upholder of Hindu faith") that testified to their intention of protecting Hinduism and yet were at the same time staunchly Islamicate in their court ceremonials and dress.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[269]</a></sup> The empire's founders, Harihara I and Bukka Raya I, were devout <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shaiva" title="Shaiva">Shaivas</a> (worshippers of <a href="/wiki/Shiva" title="Shiva">Shiva</a>), but made grants to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vaishnava" title="Vaishnava">Vaishnava</a> order of <a href="/wiki/Sringeri" title="Sringeri">Sringeri</a> with <a href="/wiki/Vidyaranya" title="Vidyaranya">Vidyaranya</a> as their patron saint, and designated <i><a href="/wiki/Varaha" title="Varaha">Varaha</a></i> (the boar, an <a href="/wiki/Avatar" title="Avatar">Avatar</a> of <a href="/wiki/Vishnu" title="Vishnu">Vishnu</a>) as their <a href="/wiki/Emblem" title="Emblem">emblem</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKamath2001177_272-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKamath2001177-272">[270]</a></sup> Over one-fourth of the archaeological dig found an "Islamic Quarter" not far from the "Royal Quarter". Nobles from Central Asia's Timurid kingdoms also came to Vijayanagara. The later <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saluva" title="Saluva">Saluva</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tuluva" title="Tuluva">Tuluva</a> kings were Vaishnava by faith, but worshipped at the feet of Lord Virupaksha (Shiva) at Hampi as well as Lord <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Venkateshwara" title="Venkateshwara">Venkateshwara</a> (Vishnu) at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tirumala_Venkateswara_Temple" title="Tirumala Venkateswara Temple">Tirupati</a>. A Sanskrit work, <i>Jambavati Kalyanam</i> by King Krishnadevaraya, called Lord Virupaksha <i>Karnata Rajya Raksha Mani</i> ("protective jewel of Karnata Empire").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFritzMichell14_273-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFritzMichell14-273">[271]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#What_information_to_include" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="A complete citation is needed. (April 2021)">full citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The kings patronised the saints of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dvaita" title="Dvaita">dvaita</a> order (philosophy of dualism) of <a href="/wiki/Madhvacharya" title="Madhvacharya">Madhvacharya</a> at <a href="/wiki/Udupi" title="Udupi">Udupi</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKamath2001177–178_274-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKamath2001177–178-274">[272]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1021810730" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="mod-gallery mod-gallery-default mod-gallery-center"><div class="main"><div><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional nochecker bordered-images whitebg">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:28px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ruins_of_Bala_Krishna_Temple_Vijayanagara_Hampi_1868_Edmund_Lyon_photo.jpg" title="An 1868 photograph of the ruins of the Vijayanagara Empire at Hampi, now a UNESCO World Heritage Site[273]"><img alt="An 1868 photograph of the ruins of the Vijayanagara Empire at Hampi, now a UNESCO World Heritage Site[273]" data-file-height="712" data-file-width="833" decoding="async" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Ruins_of_Bala_Krishna_Temple_Vijayanagara_Hampi_1868_Edmund_Lyon_photo.jpg/180px-Ruins_of_Bala_Krishna_Temple_Vijayanagara_Hampi_1868_Edmund_Lyon_photo.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Ruins_of_Bala_Krishna_Temple_Vijayanagara_Hampi_1868_Edmund_Lyon_photo.jpg/270px-Ruins_of_Bala_Krishna_Temple_Vijayanagara_Hampi_1868_Edmund_Lyon_photo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Ruins_of_Bala_Krishna_Temple_Vijayanagara_Hampi_1868_Edmund_Lyon_photo.jpg/360px-Ruins_of_Bala_Krishna_Temple_Vijayanagara_Hampi_1868_Edmund_Lyon_photo.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>An 1868 photograph of the ruins of the <a href="/wiki/Vijayanagara_Empire" title="Vijayanagara Empire">Vijayanagara Empire</a> at <a href="/wiki/Hampi" title="Hampi">Hampi</a>, now a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> World Heritage Site<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[273]</a></sup>
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:37.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Elephant%27s_stable_or_Gajashaale.JPG" title="Gajashaala or elephant's stable, built by the Vijayanagar rulers for their war elephants.[274]"><img alt="Gajashaala or elephant's stable, built by the Vijayanagar rulers for their war elephants.[274]" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Elephant%27s_stable_or_Gajashaale.JPG/180px-Elephant%27s_stable_or_Gajashaale.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Elephant%27s_stable_or_Gajashaale.JPG/270px-Elephant%27s_stable_or_Gajashaale.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Elephant%27s_stable_or_Gajashaale.JPG/360px-Elephant%27s_stable_or_Gajashaale.JPG 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><i>Gajashaala</i> or elephant's stable, built by the Vijayanagar rulers for their <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/War_elephants" title="War elephants">war elephants</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[274]</a></sup>
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:48px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Krishna_Pushkarani_-_Hampi_Ruins.jpg" title="Vijayanagara marketplace at Hampi, along with the sacred tank located on the side of Krishna temple."><img alt="Vijayanagara marketplace at Hampi, along with the sacred tank located on the side of Krishna temple." data-file-height="2661" data-file-width="4201" decoding="async" height="114" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Krishna_Pushkarani_-_Hampi_Ruins.jpg/180px-Krishna_Pushkarani_-_Hampi_Ruins.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Krishna_Pushkarani_-_Hampi_Ruins.jpg/270px-Krishna_Pushkarani_-_Hampi_Ruins.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Krishna_Pushkarani_-_Hampi_Ruins.jpg/360px-Krishna_Pushkarani_-_Hampi_Ruins.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Vijayanagara marketplace at <a href="/wiki/Hampi" title="Hampi">Hampi</a>, along with the sacred tank located on the side of Krishna temple.

</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:45px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Stone_Chariot,Hampi.jpg" title="Stone temple car in Vitthala Temple at Hampi."><img alt="Stone temple car in Vitthala Temple at Hampi." data-file-height="3648" data-file-width="5472" decoding="async" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/The_Stone_Chariot%2CHampi.jpg/180px-The_Stone_Chariot%2CHampi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/The_Stone_Chariot%2CHampi.jpg/270px-The_Stone_Chariot%2CHampi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/The_Stone_Chariot%2CHampi.jpg/360px-The_Stone_Chariot%2CHampi.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Stone <a href="/wiki/Temple_car" title="Temple car">temple car</a> in Vitthala Temple at Hampi.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul></div></div></div>
<p>The empire's legacy includes many monuments spread over South India, the best known of which is the group at Hampi. The previous temple building traditions in South India came together in the Vijayanagara Architecture style. The mingling of all faiths and vernaculars inspired architectural innovation of Hindu temple construction, first in the Deccan and later in the Dravidian idioms using the local granite. South Indian mathematics flourished under the protection of the Vijayanagara Empire in Kerala. The south Indian mathematician <a href="/wiki/Madhava_of_Sangamagrama" title="Madhava of Sangamagrama">Madhava of Sangamagrama</a> founded the famous <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kerala_School_of_Astronomy_and_Mathematics" title="Kerala School of Astronomy and Mathematics">Kerala School of Astronomy and Mathematics</a> in the 14th century which produced a lot of great south Indian mathematicians like <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parameshvara" title="Parameshvara">Parameshvara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nilakantha_Somayaji" title="Nilakantha Somayaji">Nilakantha Somayaji</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jye%E1%B9%A3%E1%B9%ADhadeva" title="Jyeṣṭhadeva">Jyeṣṭhadeva</a> in medieval south India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[275]</a></sup> Efficient administration and vigorous overseas trade brought new technologies such as water management systems for irrigation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[276]</a></sup> The empire's patronage enabled fine arts and literature to reach new heights in Kannada, Telugu, Tamil, and Sanskrit, while Carnatic music evolved into its current form.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[277]</a></sup>
</p><p>Vijayanagara went into decline after the defeat in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Talikota" title="Battle of Talikota">Battle of Talikota</a> (1565). After the death of <a href="/wiki/Aliya_Rama_Raya" title="Aliya Rama Raya">Aliya Rama Raya</a> in the Battle of Talikota, <a href="/wiki/Tirumala_Deva_Raya" title="Tirumala Deva Raya">Tirumala Deva Raya</a> started the <a href="/wiki/Aravidu_dynasty" title="Aravidu dynasty">Aravidu dynasty</a>, moved and founded a new capital of Penukonda to replace the destroyed Hampi, and attempted to reconstitute the remains of Vijayanagara Empire.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEaton2005100–101_280-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEaton2005100–101-280">[278]</a></sup> Tirumala abdicated in 1572, dividing the remains of his kingdom to his three sons, and pursued a religious life until his death in 1578. The Aravidu dynasty successors ruled the region but the empire collapsed in 1614, and the final remains ended in 1646, from continued wars with the Bijapur sultanate and others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKamath2001174_281-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKamath2001174-281">[279]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[280]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEaton2005101–115_283-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEaton2005101–115-283">[281]</a></sup> During this period, more kingdoms in South India became independent and separate from Vijayanagara. These include the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Mysore" title="Kingdom of Mysore">Mysore Kingdom</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Keladi_Nayaka" title="Keladi Nayaka">Keladi Nayaka</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Madurai_Nayak_Dynasty" title="Madurai Nayak Dynasty">Nayaks of Madurai</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Thanjavur_Nayaks" title="Thanjavur Nayaks">Nayaks of Tanjore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nayakas_of_Chitradurga" title="Nayakas of Chitradurga">Nayakas of Chitradurga</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nayaks_of_Gingee" title="Nayaks of Gingee">Nayak Kingdom of Gingee</a> – all of which declared independence and went on to have a significant impact on the history of South India in the coming centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKamath2001220,_226,_234_284-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKamath2001220,_226,_234-284">[282]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Kingdom_of_Mewar_.28c._728.E2.80.931949_CE.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Kingdom_of_Mewar_(c._728–1949_CE)">Kingdom of Mewar (c. 728–1949 CE)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Guhila_dynasty" title="Guhila dynasty">Guhila dynasty</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Mewar" title="Kingdom of Mewar">Kingdom of Mewar</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1021810730" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="mod-gallery mod-gallery-default mod-gallery-center"><div class="main"><div><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional nochecker bordered-images whitebg">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 165px"><div style="width: 165px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tower_of_victory.jpg" title="Vijaya Stambha (Tower of Victory)"><img alt="Vijaya Stambha (Tower of Victory)" data-file-height="3872" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Tower_of_victory.jpg/120px-Tower_of_victory.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Tower_of_victory.jpg/181px-Tower_of_victory.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Tower_of_victory.jpg/241px-Tower_of_victory.jpg 2x" width="120"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><i><a href="/wiki/Vijaya_Stambha" title="Vijaya Stambha">Vijaya Stambha</a></i> (Tower of Victory)
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 165px"><div style="width: 165px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;"><div style="margin:18.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Temple_in_Rajasthan.jpg" title="Temple inside Chittorgarh fort"><img alt="Temple inside Chittorgarh fort" data-file-height="4160" data-file-width="3120" decoding="async" height="173" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Temple_in_Rajasthan.jpg/130px-Temple_in_Rajasthan.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Temple_in_Rajasthan.jpg/195px-Temple_in_Rajasthan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Temple_in_Rajasthan.jpg/260px-Temple_in_Rajasthan.jpg 2x" width="130"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Temple inside <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chittorgarh_fort" title="Chittorgarh fort">Chittorgarh fort</a>
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 165px"><div style="width: 165px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;"><div style="margin:61.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Man_Singh_Palace_as_viewed_in_the_early_hours_of_the_morning.JPG" title="The Man Singh (Manasimha) palace at the Gwalior fort"><img alt="The Man Singh (Manasimha) palace at the Gwalior fort" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3888" decoding="async" height="87" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Man_Singh_Palace_as_viewed_in_the_early_hours_of_the_morning.JPG/130px-Man_Singh_Palace_as_viewed_in_the_early_hours_of_the_morning.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Man_Singh_Palace_as_viewed_in_the_early_hours_of_the_morning.JPG/195px-Man_Singh_Palace_as_viewed_in_the_early_hours_of_the_morning.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Man_Singh_Palace_as_viewed_in_the_early_hours_of_the_morning.JPG/260px-Man_Singh_Palace_as_viewed_in_the_early_hours_of_the_morning.JPG 2x" width="130"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>The Man Singh (Manasimha) palace at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gwalior_fort" title="Gwalior fort">Gwalior fort</a>
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 165px"><div style="width: 165px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tribute_Giraffe_with_Attendant.jpg" title="Chinese manuscript Tribute Giraffe with Attendant, depicting a giraffe presented by Bengali envoys in the name of Sultan Saifuddin Hamza Shah of Bengal to the Yongle Emperor of Ming China."><img alt="Chinese manuscript Tribute Giraffe with Attendant, depicting a giraffe presented by Bengali envoys in the name of Sultan Saifuddin Hamza Shah of Bengal to the Yongle Emperor of Ming China." data-file-height="1500" data-file-width="759" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Tribute_Giraffe_with_Attendant.jpg/91px-Tribute_Giraffe_with_Attendant.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Tribute_Giraffe_with_Attendant.jpg/136px-Tribute_Giraffe_with_Attendant.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Tribute_Giraffe_with_Attendant.jpg/182px-Tribute_Giraffe_with_Attendant.jpg 2x" width="91"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Chinese manuscript <i>Tribute Giraffe with Attendant</i>, depicting a giraffe presented by Bengali envoys in the name of Sultan <a href="/wiki/Saifuddin_Hamza_Shah" title="Saifuddin Hamza Shah">Saifuddin Hamza Shah</a> of Bengal to the <a href="/wiki/Yongle_Emperor" title="Yongle Emperor">Yongle Emperor</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ming_China" title="Ming China">Ming China</a>.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 165px"><div style="width: 165px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;"><div style="margin:67.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Complete_view_of_Mahumad_Gawan.JPG" title="Mahmud Gawan Madrasa was built by Mahmud Gawan, the Wazir of the Bahmani Sultanate as the centre of religious as well as secular education."><img alt="Mahmud Gawan Madrasa was built by Mahmud Gawan, the Wazir of the Bahmani Sultanate as the centre of religious as well as secular education." data-file-height="2221" data-file-width="3872" decoding="async" height="75" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Complete_view_of_Mahumad_Gawan.JPG/130px-Complete_view_of_Mahumad_Gawan.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Complete_view_of_Mahumad_Gawan.JPG/195px-Complete_view_of_Mahumad_Gawan.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Complete_view_of_Mahumad_Gawan.JPG/260px-Complete_view_of_Mahumad_Gawan.JPG 2x" width="130"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Mahmud Gawan Madrasa was built by Mahmud Gawan, the Wazir of the Bahmani Sultanate as the centre of religious as well as secular education.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 165px"><div style="width: 165px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;"><div style="margin:62.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Oriya_land_grant.jpg" title="15th century copper plate grant of Gajapati king Purushottama Deva"><img alt="15th century copper plate grant of Gajapati king Purushottama Deva" data-file-height="837" data-file-width="1280" decoding="async" height="85" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Oriya_land_grant.jpg/130px-Oriya_land_grant.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Oriya_land_grant.jpg/195px-Oriya_land_grant.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Oriya_land_grant.jpg/260px-Oriya_land_grant.jpg 2x" width="130"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>15th century copper plate grant of Gajapati king Purushottama Deva
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul></div></div></div>
<p>For two and a half centuries from the mid-13th century, politics in Northern India was dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Delhi_Sultanate" title="Delhi Sultanate">Delhi Sultanate</a>, and in Southern India by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vijayanagar_Empire" title="Vijayanagar Empire">Vijayanagar Empire</a>. However, there were other regional powers present as well. After fall of <a href="/wiki/Pala_Empire" title="Pala Empire">Pala Empire</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Chero_dynasty" title="Chero dynasty">Chero dynasty</a> ruled much of Eastern <a href="/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh" title="Uttar Pradesh">Uttar Pradesh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bihar" title="Bihar">Bihar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jharkhand" title="Jharkhand">Jharkhand</a> from 12th CE to 18th CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[283]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gopal2017_286-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gopal2017-286">[284]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SinghGaur2008_287-0"><a href="#cite_note-SinghGaur2008-287">[285]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reddy_dynasty" title="Reddy dynasty">Reddy dynasty</a> successfully defeated the Delhi Sultanate; and extended their rule from <a href="/wiki/Cuttack" title="Cuttack">Cuttack</a> in the north to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kanchi" title="Kanchi">Kanchi</a> in the south, eventually being absorbed into the expanding Vijayanagara Empire.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mackenzie1990_288-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mackenzie1990-288">[286]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the north, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rajput_kingdoms" title="Rajput kingdoms">Rajput kingdoms</a> remained the dominant force in Western and Central India. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mewar_dynasty" title="Mewar dynasty">Mewar dynasty</a> under <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maharana_Hammir" title="Maharana Hammir">Maharana Hammir</a> defeated and captured <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muhammad_Tughlaq" title="Muhammad Tughlaq">Muhammad Tughlaq</a> with the Bargujars as his main allies. Tughlaq had to pay a huge ransom and relinquish all of Mewar's lands. After this event, the Delhi Sultanate did not attack <a href="/wiki/Chittor_Fort" title="Chittor Fort">Chittor</a> for a few hundred years. The Rajputs re-established their independence, and Rajput states were established as far east as Bengal and north into the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Punjab_region" title="Punjab region">Punjab</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Tomaras_of_Gwalior" title="Tomaras of Gwalior">Tomaras</a> established themselves at <a href="/wiki/Gwalior" title="Gwalior">Gwalior</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Man_Singh_Tomar" title="Man Singh Tomar">Man Singh Tomar</a> reconstructed the <a href="/wiki/Gwalior_Fort" title="Gwalior Fort">Gwalior Fort</a> which still stands there.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sen2_289-0"><a href="#cite_note-sen2-289">[287]</a></sup> During this period, Mewar emerged as the leading Rajput state; and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rana_Kumbha" title="Rana Kumbha">Rana Kumbha</a> expanded his kingdom at the expense of the <a href="/wiki/Sultan" title="Sultan">Sultanates</a> of <a href="/wiki/Malwa_Sultanate" title="Malwa Sultanate">Malwa</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Gujarat" title="Sultanate of Gujarat">Gujarat</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sen2_289-1"><a href="#cite_note-sen2-289">[287]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[288]</a></sup> The next great Rajput ruler, <a href="/wiki/Rana_Sanga" title="Rana Sanga">Rana Sanga</a> of Mewar, became the principal player in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northern_India" title="Northern India">Northern India</a>. His objectives grew in scope – he planned to conquer the much sought after prize of the Muslim rulers of the time, <a href="/wiki/Delhi" title="Delhi">Delhi</a>. But, his defeat in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Khanwa" title="Battle of Khanwa">Battle of Khanwa</a> consolidated the new <a href="/wiki/Mughal_dynasty" title="Mughal dynasty">Mughal dynasty</a> in India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sen2_289-2"><a href="#cite_note-sen2-289">[287]</a></sup> The Mewar dynasty under Maharana <a href="/wiki/Udai_Singh_II" title="Udai Singh II">Udai Singh II</a> faced further defeat by Mughal emperor <a href="/wiki/Akbar" title="Akbar">Akbar</a>, with their capital Chittor being captured. Due to this event, Udai Singh II founded <a href="/wiki/Udaipur" title="Udaipur">Udaipur</a>, which became the new capital of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Udaipur_State" title="Udaipur State">Mewar kingdom</a>. His son, <a href="/wiki/Maharana_Pratap" title="Maharana Pratap">Maharana Pratap</a> of Mewar, firmly resisted the Mughals. Akbar sent many missions against him. He survived to ultimately gain control of all of Mewar, excluding the <a href="/wiki/Chittor_Fort" title="Chittor Fort">Chittor Fort</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ap_291-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ap-291">[289]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the south, the <a href="/wiki/Bahmani_Sultanate" title="Bahmani Sultanate">Bahmani Sultanate</a>, which was established either by a Brahman convert or patronised by a Brahman and from that source it was given the name <i>Bahmani</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[290]</a></sup> was the chief rival of the Vijayanagara, and frequently created difficulties for the Vijayanagara.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[291]</a></sup> In the early 16th century <a href="/wiki/Krishnadevaraya" title="Krishnadevaraya">Krishnadevaraya</a> of the Vijayanagar Empire defeated the last remnant of Bahmani Sultanate power. After which, the Bahmani Sultanate collapsed,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEaton200588_294-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEaton200588-294">[292]</a></sup> resulting it being split into five small <a href="/wiki/Deccan_sultanates" title="Deccan sultanates">Deccan sultanates</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[293]</a></sup> In 1490, <a href="/wiki/Ahmadnagar_Sultanate" title="Ahmadnagar Sultanate">Ahmadnagar</a> declared independence, followed by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bijapur_Sultanate" title="Bijapur Sultanate">Bijapur</a> and <a href="/wiki/Berar_Sultanate" title="Berar Sultanate">Berar</a> in the same year; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Golconda_Sultanate" title="Golconda Sultanate">Golkonda</a> became independent in 1518 and <a href="/wiki/Bidar_Sultanate" title="Bidar Sultanate">Bidar</a> in 1528.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[294]</a></sup> Although generally rivals, they did ally against the Vijayanagara Empire in 1565, permanently weakening Vijayanagar in the Battle of Talikota.
</p><p>In the East, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gajapati_Kingdom" title="Gajapati Kingdom">Gajapati Kingdom</a> remained a strong regional power to reckon with, associated with a high point in the growth of regional culture and architecture. Under <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kapilendradeva" title="Kapilendradeva">Kapilendradeva</a>, Gajapatis became an empire stretching from the lower <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ganga" title="Ganga">Ganga</a> in the north to the <a href="/wiki/Kaveri" title="Kaveri">Kaveri</a> in the south.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[295]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Northeast_India" title="Northeast India">Northeast India</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ahom_Kingdom" title="Ahom Kingdom">Ahom Kingdom</a> was a major power for six centuries;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sen1999_298-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sen1999-298">[296]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Saikia2004_299-0"><a href="#cite_note-Saikia2004-299">[297]</a></sup> led by <a href="/wiki/Lachit_Borphukan" title="Lachit Borphukan">Lachit Borphukan</a>, the Ahoms decisively defeated the Mughal army at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Saraighat" title="Battle of Saraighat">Battle of Saraighat</a> during the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ahom-Mughal_conflicts" title="Ahom-Mughal conflicts">Ahom-Mughal conflicts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[298]</a></sup> Further east in Northeastern India was the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Manipur" title="Kingdom of Manipur">Kingdom of Manipur</a>, which ruled from their seat of power at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kangla_Fort" title="Kangla Fort">Kangla Fort</a> and developed a sophisticated Hindu <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gaudiya_Vaishnavite" title="Gaudiya Vaishnavite">Gaudiya Vaishnavite</a> culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams200483–84,_the_other_major_classical_Indian_dances_are:_Bharatanatyam,_Kathak,_Odissi,_Kathakali,_Kuchipudi,_Cchau,_Satriya,_Yaksagana_and_Bhagavata_Mela_301-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams200483–84,_the_other_major_classical_Indian_dances_are:_Bharatanatyam,_Kathak,_Odissi,_Kathakali,_Kuchipudi,_Cchau,_Satriya,_Yaksagana_and_Bhagavata_Mela-301">[299]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMassey2004177_302-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMassey2004177-302">[300]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDevi1990175–180_303-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDevi1990175–180-303">[301]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <b>Sultanate of Bengal</b> was the dominant power of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ganges%E2%80%93Brahmaputra_Delta" title="Ganges–Brahmaputra Delta">Ganges–Brahmaputra Delta</a>, with a network of mint towns spread across the region. It was a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sunni_Muslim" title="Sunni Muslim">Sunni Muslim</a> monarchy with <a href="/wiki/Indo-Turkic_people" title="Indo-Turkic people">Indo-Turkic</a>, Arab, Abyssinian and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bengali_Muslim" title="Bengali Muslim">Bengali Muslim</a> elites. The sultanate was known for its religious pluralism where non-Muslim communities co-existed peacefully. The Bengal Sultanate had a circle of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vassal_states" title="Vassal states">vassal states</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Odisha" title="Odisha">Odisha</a> in the southwest, <a href="/wiki/Arakan" title="Arakan">Arakan</a> in the southeast, and <a href="/wiki/Tripura" title="Tripura">Tripura</a> in the east. In the early 16th century, the Bengal Sultanate reached the peak of its territorial growth with control over <a href="/wiki/Kamarupa" title="Kamarupa">Kamrup</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kamata_Kingdom" title="Kamata Kingdom">Kamata</a> in the northeast and <a href="/wiki/Jaunpur_district" title="Jaunpur district">Jaunpur</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bihar" title="Bihar">Bihar</a> in the west. It was reputed as a thriving trading nation and one of Asia's strongest states.The Bengal Sultanate was described by contemporary European and Chinese visitors as a relatively prosperous kingdom. Due to the abundance of goods in Bengal, the region was described as the "richest country to trade with". The Bengal Sultanate left a strong architectural legacy. Buildings from the period show foreign influences merged into a distinct <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Bengal" title="Architecture of Bengal">Bengali style.</a> The Bengal Sultanate was also the largest and most prestigious authority among the independent medieval Muslim-ruled states in the <a href="/wiki/History_of_Bengal" title="History of Bengal">history of Bengal</a>. Its decline began with an <a href="/wiki/Interregnum" title="Interregnum">interregnum</a> by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Suri_Empire" title="Suri Empire">Suri Empire</a>, followed by <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal</a> <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Subah" title="Bengal Subah">conquest</a> and disintegration into petty kingdoms.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Bhakti_movement_and_Sikhism">Bhakti movement and Sikhism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Bhakti_movement" title="Bhakti movement">Bhakti movement</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_India" title="Buddhism in India">Buddhism in India</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sikhism" title="Sikhism">Sikhism</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Sikhism" title="History of Sikhism">History of Sikhism</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dasam.Granth.Frontispiece.BL.Manuscript.1825-1850.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3582" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="197" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Dasam.Granth.Frontispiece.BL.Manuscript.1825-1850.jpg/220px-Dasam.Granth.Frontispiece.BL.Manuscript.1825-1850.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Dasam.Granth.Frontispiece.BL.Manuscript.1825-1850.jpg/330px-Dasam.Granth.Frontispiece.BL.Manuscript.1825-1850.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Dasam.Granth.Frontispiece.BL.Manuscript.1825-1850.jpg/440px-Dasam.Granth.Frontispiece.BL.Manuscript.1825-1850.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dasam.Granth.Frontispiece.BL.Manuscript.1825-1850.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Dasam_Granth" title="Dasam Granth">Dasam Granth</a> (above) was composed by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sikh_Guru" title="Sikh Guru">Sikh Guru</a> <a href="/wiki/Guru_Gobind_Singh" title="Guru Gobind Singh">Gobind Singh</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The Bhakti movement refers to the <a href="/wiki/Theism" title="Theism">theistic</a> devotional trend that emerged in medieval Hinduism<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchomerMcLeod19871_304-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchomerMcLeod19871-304">[302]</a></sup> and later revolutionised in <a href="/wiki/Sikhism" title="Sikhism">Sikhism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[303]</a></sup> It originated in the seventh-century south India (now parts of Tamil Nadu and Kerala), and spread northwards.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchomerMcLeod19871_304-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchomerMcLeod19871-304">[302]</a></sup> It swept over east and north India from the 15th century onwards, reaching its zenith between the 15th and 17th century CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchomerMcLeod19871–2_306-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchomerMcLeod19871–2-306">[304]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul><li>The Bhakti movement regionally developed around different gods and goddesses, such as <a href="/wiki/Vaishnavism" title="Vaishnavism">Vaishnavism</a> (Vishnu), <a href="/wiki/Shaivism" title="Shaivism">Shaivism</a> (Shiva), <a href="/wiki/Shaktism" title="Shaktism">Shaktism</a> (Shakti goddesses), and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Smartism" title="Smartism">Smartism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[305]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[306]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[307]</a></sup> The movement was inspired by many poet-saints, who championed a wide range of philosophical positions ranging from theistic <a href="/wiki/Dualism_(Indian_philosophy)" title="Dualism (Indian philosophy)">dualism</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dvaita" title="Dvaita">Dvaita</a> to absolute <a href="/wiki/Monism" title="Monism">monism</a> of <a href="/wiki/Advaita_Vedanta" title="Advaita Vedanta">Advaita Vedanta</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchomerMcLeod19872_310-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchomerMcLeod19872-310">[308]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-novetzke_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-novetzke-311">[309]</a></sup></li>
<li>Sikhism is based on the spiritual teachings of <a href="/wiki/Guru_Nanak" title="Guru Nanak">Guru Nanak</a>, the first Guru,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[310]</a></sup> and the ten successive <a href="/wiki/Sikh_gurus" title="Sikh gurus">Sikh gurus</a>. After the death of the tenth Guru, <a href="/wiki/Guru_Gobind_Singh" title="Guru Gobind Singh">Guru Gobind Singh</a>, the Sikh scripture, <a href="/wiki/Guru_Granth_Sahib" title="Guru Granth Sahib">Guru Granth Sahib</a>, became the literal embodiment of the eternal, impersonal Guru, where the scripture's word serves as the spiritual guide for Sikhs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[311]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[312]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-granthfinalguru_315-0"><a href="#cite_note-granthfinalguru-315">[313]</a></sup></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_India" title="Buddhism in India">Buddhism in India</a> flourished in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Himalaya" title="Himalaya">Himalayan</a> kingdoms of <a href="/wiki/Namgyal_dynasty_of_Ladakh" title="Namgyal dynasty of Ladakh">Namgyal Kingdom</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ladakh" title="Ladakh">Ladakh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Sikkim" title="Kingdom of Sikkim">Sikkim Kingdom</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sikkim" title="Sikkim">Sikkim</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chutia_Kingdom" title="Chutia Kingdom">Chutia Kingdom</a> in <a href="/wiki/Arunachal_Pradesh" title="Arunachal Pradesh">Arunachal Pradesh</a> of the Late medieval period.</li></ul>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1021810730" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="mod-gallery mod-gallery-default mod-gallery-center"><div class="main"><div><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional nochecker bordered-images whitebg">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:37.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rang_Ghar_Sibsagar.jpg" title="Rang Ghar, built by Pramatta Singha in Ahom kingdom's capital Rangpur, is one of the earliest pavilions of outdoor stadia in the Indian subcontinent."><img alt="Rang Ghar, built by Pramatta Singha in Ahom kingdom's capital Rangpur, is one of the earliest pavilions of outdoor stadia in the Indian subcontinent." data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Rang_Ghar_Sibsagar.jpg/180px-Rang_Ghar_Sibsagar.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Rang_Ghar_Sibsagar.jpg/270px-Rang_Ghar_Sibsagar.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Rang_Ghar_Sibsagar.jpg/360px-Rang_Ghar_Sibsagar.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Rang_Ghar" title="Rang Ghar">Rang Ghar</a>, built by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pramatta_Singha" title="Pramatta Singha">Pramatta Singha</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ahom_kingdom" title="Ahom kingdom">Ahom kingdom</a>'s capital <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sibsagar" title="Sibsagar">Rangpur</a>, is one of the earliest pavilions of outdoor stadia in the Indian subcontinent.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:45px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chittorgarh_fort.JPG" title="Chittor Fort is the largest fort on the Indian subcontinent; it is one of the six Hill Forts of Rajasthan."><img alt="Chittor Fort is the largest fort on the Indian subcontinent; it is one of the six Hill Forts of Rajasthan." data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3008" decoding="async" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Chittorgarh_fort.JPG/180px-Chittorgarh_fort.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Chittorgarh_fort.JPG/270px-Chittorgarh_fort.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Chittorgarh_fort.JPG/360px-Chittorgarh_fort.JPG 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Chittor_Fort" title="Chittor Fort">Chittor Fort</a> is the largest fort on the Indian subcontinent; it is one of the six <a href="/wiki/Hill_Forts_of_Rajasthan" title="Hill Forts of Rajasthan">Hill Forts of Rajasthan</a>.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:48.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chaumukha_Jain_temple_at_Ranakpur_in_Aravalli_range_near_Udaipur_Rajasthan_India.jpg" title="Ranakpur Jain temple was built in the 15th century with the support of the Rajput state of Mewar."><img alt="Ranakpur Jain temple was built in the 15th century with the support of the Rajput state of Mewar." data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1280" decoding="async" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Chaumukha_Jain_temple_at_Ranakpur_in_Aravalli_range_near_Udaipur_Rajasthan_India.jpg/180px-Chaumukha_Jain_temple_at_Ranakpur_in_Aravalli_range_near_Udaipur_Rajasthan_India.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Chaumukha_Jain_temple_at_Ranakpur_in_Aravalli_range_near_Udaipur_Rajasthan_India.jpg/270px-Chaumukha_Jain_temple_at_Ranakpur_in_Aravalli_range_near_Udaipur_Rajasthan_India.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Chaumukha_Jain_temple_at_Ranakpur_in_Aravalli_range_near_Udaipur_Rajasthan_India.jpg/360px-Chaumukha_Jain_temple_at_Ranakpur_in_Aravalli_range_near_Udaipur_Rajasthan_India.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Ranakpur_Jain_temple" title="Ranakpur Jain temple">Ranakpur Jain temple</a> was built in the 15th century with the support of the Rajput state of <a href="/wiki/Mewar" title="Mewar">Mewar</a>.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:37.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GolGumbaz2.jpg" title="Gol Gumbaz built by the Bijapur Sultanate, has the second largest pre-modern dome in the world after the Byzantine Hagia Sophia."><img alt="Gol Gumbaz built by the Bijapur Sultanate, has the second largest pre-modern dome in the world after the Byzantine Hagia Sophia." data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/GolGumbaz2.jpg/180px-GolGumbaz2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/GolGumbaz2.jpg/270px-GolGumbaz2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/GolGumbaz2.jpg/360px-GolGumbaz2.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Gol_Gumbaz" title="Gol Gumbaz">Gol Gumbaz</a> built by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bijapur_Sultanate" title="Bijapur Sultanate">Bijapur Sultanate</a>, has the second largest pre-modern dome in the world after the Byzantine <a href="/wiki/Hagia_Sophia" title="Hagia Sophia">Hagia Sophia</a>.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul></div></div></div>
<h2><span id="Early_modern_period_.28c._1526.E2.80.931858_CE.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_modern_period_(c._1526–1858_CE)">Early modern period (c. 1526–1858 CE)</span></h2>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Early_modern_period" title="Early modern period">early modern period</a> of Indian history is dated from 1526 CE to 1858 CE, corresponding to the rise and fall of the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal Empire</a>, which inherited from the <a href="/wiki/Timurid_Renaissance" title="Timurid Renaissance">Timurid Renaissance</a>. During this age India's economy expanded, relative peace was maintained and arts were patronized. This period witnessed the further development of <a href="/wiki/Indo-Islamic_architecture" title="Indo-Islamic architecture">Indo-Islamic architecture</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008115_316-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008115-316">[314]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobb200190–91_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobb200190–91-317">[315]</a></sup> the growth of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mahrattas" title="Mahrattas">Mahrattas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sikh_Empire" title="Sikh Empire">Sikhs</a> enabled them to rule significant regions of India in the waning days of the Mughal empire, which formally came to an end when the <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British Raj</a> was founded.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-exeter_22-1"><a href="#cite_note-exeter-22">[22]</a></sup> With the discovery of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cape_route" title="Cape route">Cape route</a> in the 1500s, the first Europeans to arrive by sea and establish themselves, were the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Portuguese_in_Goa_and_Bombay" title="Portuguese in Goa and Bombay">Portuguese in Goa and Bombay</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[316]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mughal_Empire">Mughal Empire</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal Empire</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Subah" title="Bengal Subah">Bengal Subah</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muslin_trade_in_Bengal" title="Muslin trade in Bengal">Muslin trade in Bengal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mughal_architecture" title="Mughal architecture">Mughal architecture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mughal_clothing" title="Mughal clothing">Mughal clothing</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mughal_painting" title="Mughal painting">Mughal painting</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:442px;max-width:442px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader">Mughal Empire</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:139px;max-width:139px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:195px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Joppen1907India1700a.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="840" decoding="async" height="196" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/51/Joppen1907India1700a.jpg/137px-Joppen1907India1700a.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/51/Joppen1907India1700a.jpg/206px-Joppen1907India1700a.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/51/Joppen1907India1700a.jpg/274px-Joppen1907India1700a.jpg 2x" width="137"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">A map of the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal Empire</a> at its greatest geographical extent, c. 1700 CE</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:299px;max-width:299px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:195px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Taj_Mahal_(Edited).jpeg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2525" data-file-width="3840" decoding="async" height="195" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Taj_Mahal_%28Edited%29.jpeg/297px-Taj_Mahal_%28Edited%29.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Taj_Mahal_%28Edited%29.jpeg/446px-Taj_Mahal_%28Edited%29.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Taj_Mahal_%28Edited%29.jpeg/594px-Taj_Mahal_%28Edited%29.jpeg 2x" width="297"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">"The <a href="/wiki/Taj_Mahal" title="Taj Mahal">Taj Mahal</a> is the jewel of Muslim art in India and one of the universally admired masterpieces of the world's heritage." <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a> declaration, 1983.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[317]</a></sup></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>In 1526, <a href="/wiki/Babur" title="Babur">Babur</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Timurid_dynasty" title="Timurid dynasty">Timurid</a> descendant of <a href="/wiki/Timur" title="Timur">Timur</a> and <a href="/wiki/Descent_from_Genghis_Khan" title="Descent from Genghis Khan">Genghis Khan</a> from <a href="/wiki/Fergana_Valley" title="Fergana Valley">Fergana Valley</a> (modern day Uzbekistan), swept across the <a href="/wiki/Khyber_Pass" title="Khyber Pass">Khyber Pass</a> and established the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal Empire</a>, which at its zenith covered much of <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">South Asia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[318]</a></sup> However, his son <a href="/wiki/Humayun" title="Humayun">Humayun</a> was defeated by the Afghan warrior <a href="/wiki/Sher_Shah_Suri" title="Sher Shah Suri">Sher Shah Suri</a> in the year 1540, and Humayun was forced to retreat to <a href="/wiki/Kabul" title="Kabul">Kabul</a>. After Sher Shah's death, his son <a href="/wiki/Islam_Shah_Suri" title="Islam Shah Suri">Islam Shah Suri</a> and his Hindu general <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hemu_Vikramaditya" title="Hemu Vikramaditya">Hemu Vikramaditya</a> established secular rule in North India from <a href="/wiki/Delhi" title="Delhi">Delhi</a> until 1556, when <a href="/wiki/Akbar" title="Akbar">Akbar</a> (<span style="white-space:nowrap;"><abbr title="reigned">r.</abbr> 1556–1605</span>), grandson of Babur, defeated Hemu in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_Panipat_(1556)" title="Battle of Panipat (1556)">Second Battle of Panipat</a> on 6 November 1556 after winning <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_Delhi_(1556)" title="Battle of Delhi (1556)">Battle of Delhi</a>. Akbar tried to establish a good relationship with the Hindus. Akbar declared "Amari" or non-killing of animals in the holy days of Jainism. He rolled back the <i><a href="/wiki/Jizya" title="Jizya">jizya</a></i> tax for non-Muslims. The Mughal emperors married local royalty, allied themselves with local <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maharajas" title="Maharajas">maharajas</a></i>, and attempted to fuse their Turko-Persian culture with ancient Indian styles, creating a unique <a href="/wiki/Indo-Persian_culture" title="Indo-Persian culture">Indo-Persian culture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mughal_architecture" title="Mughal architecture">Indo-Saracenic architecture</a>.
</p><p>Akbar married a <a href="/wiki/Rajput" title="Rajput">Rajput</a> princess, <a href="/wiki/Mariam-uz-Zamani" title="Mariam-uz-Zamani">Mariam-uz-Zamani</a>, and they had a son, <a href="/wiki/Jahangir" title="Jahangir">Jahangir</a> (<span style="white-space:nowrap;"><abbr title="reigned">r.</abbr> 1605–1627</span>), who was part-Mughal and part-Rajput, as were future Mughal emperors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[319]</a></sup> Jahangir more or less followed his father's policy. The Mughal dynasty ruled most of the Indian subcontinent by 1600. The reign of <a href="/wiki/Shah_Jahan" title="Shah Jahan">Shah Jahan</a> (<span style="white-space:nowrap;"><abbr title="reigned">r.</abbr> 1628–1658</span>) was the golden age of Mughal architecture. He erected several large monuments, the most famous of which is the <a href="/wiki/Taj_Mahal" title="Taj Mahal">Taj Mahal</a> at Agra, as well as the Moti Masjid in Agra, the Red Fort, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jama_Masjid" title="Jama Masjid">Jama Masjid</a>, Delhi, and the Lahore Fort.
</p><p>It was one of the largest empires to have existed in the Indian subcontinent,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Turchin223_322-0"><a href="#cite_note-Turchin223-322">[320]</a></sup> and surpassed <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> to become the world's largest economic power, controlling 24.4% of the <a href="/wiki/World_economy" title="World economy">world economy</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-maddison261_323-0"><a href="#cite_note-maddison261-323">[321]</a></sup> and the world leader in manufacturing,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Parthasarathi_324-0"><a href="#cite_note-Parthasarathi-324">[322]</a></sup> producing 25% of global industrial output.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-williamson_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-williamson-325">[323]</a></sup> The economic and demographic upsurge was stimulated by Mughal <a href="/wiki/Agrarian_reform" title="Agrarian reform">agrarian reforms</a> that intensified agricultural production,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-richards_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-richards-326">[324]</a></sup> a <a href="/wiki/Proto-industrialization" title="Proto-industrialization">proto-industrializing</a> economy that began moving towards industrial <a href="/wiki/Manufacturing" title="Manufacturing">manufacturing</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-voss_327-0"><a href="#cite_note-voss-327">[325]</a></sup> and a relatively high degree of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Urbanisation" title="Urbanisation">urbanisation</a> for its time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eraly_328-0"><a href="#cite_note-eraly-328">[326]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1021810730" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="mod-gallery mod-gallery-default mod-gallery-center"><div class="title"><div>Other Mughal UNESCO World Heritage Sites</div></div><div class="main"><div><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional nochecker bordered-images whitebg">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:37.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Agra_Fort_20180908_143826.jpg" title="The Agra Fort showing the river Yamuna and the Taj Mahal in the background"><img alt="The Agra Fort showing the river Yamuna and the Taj Mahal in the background" data-file-height="3036" data-file-width="4048" decoding="async" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Agra_Fort_20180908_143826.jpg/180px-Agra_Fort_20180908_143826.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Agra_Fort_20180908_143826.jpg/270px-Agra_Fort_20180908_143826.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Agra_Fort_20180908_143826.jpg/360px-Agra_Fort_20180908_143826.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Agra_Fort" title="Agra Fort">Agra Fort</a> showing the river <a href="/wiki/Yamuna" title="Yamuna">Yamuna</a> and the Taj Mahal in the background
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:27.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fatehput_Sikiri_Buland_Darwaza_gate_2010.jpg" title="Fatehpur Sikri, near Agra, showing Buland Darwaza, the complex built by Akbar, the third Mughal emperor."><img alt="Fatehpur Sikri, near Agra, showing Buland Darwaza, the complex built by Akbar, the third Mughal emperor." data-file-height="2536" data-file-width="2938" decoding="async" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Fatehput_Sikiri_Buland_Darwaza_gate_2010.jpg/180px-Fatehput_Sikiri_Buland_Darwaza_gate_2010.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Fatehput_Sikiri_Buland_Darwaza_gate_2010.jpg/270px-Fatehput_Sikiri_Buland_Darwaza_gate_2010.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Fatehput_Sikiri_Buland_Darwaza_gate_2010.jpg/360px-Fatehput_Sikiri_Buland_Darwaza_gate_2010.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Fatehpur_Sikri" title="Fatehpur Sikri">Fatehpur Sikri</a>, near Agra, showing <a href="/wiki/Buland_Darwaza" title="Buland Darwaza">Buland Darwaza</a>, the complex built by <a href="/wiki/Akbar" title="Akbar">Akbar</a>, the third Mughal emperor.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:45px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Humayunstomb3.jpg" title="Humayun's Tomb in Delhi, built in 1570 CE."><img alt="Humayun's Tomb in Delhi, built in 1570 CE." data-file-height="4000" data-file-width="6000" decoding="async" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Humayunstomb3.jpg/180px-Humayunstomb3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Humayunstomb3.jpg/270px-Humayunstomb3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Humayunstomb3.jpg/360px-Humayunstomb3.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Humayun%27s_Tomb" title="Humayun's Tomb">Humayun's Tomb</a> in Delhi, built in 1570 CE.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:45px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Red_Fort_in_Delhi_03-2016_img1.jpg" title="The Red Fort, Delhi, its construction begun in 1639 CE, and ended in 1648 CE."><img alt="The Red Fort, Delhi, its construction begun in 1639 CE, and ended in 1648 CE." data-file-height="3387" data-file-width="5080" decoding="async" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Red_Fort_in_Delhi_03-2016_img1.jpg/180px-Red_Fort_in_Delhi_03-2016_img1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Red_Fort_in_Delhi_03-2016_img1.jpg/270px-Red_Fort_in_Delhi_03-2016_img1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Red_Fort_in_Delhi_03-2016_img1.jpg/360px-Red_Fort_in_Delhi_03-2016_img1.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Red_Fort" title="Red Fort">Red Fort</a>, Delhi, its construction begun in 1639 CE, and ended in 1648 CE.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul></div></div></div>
<p>The Mughal Empire reached the zenith of its territorial expanse during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Aurangzeb" title="Aurangzeb">Aurangzeb</a> (<span style="white-space:nowrap;"><abbr title="reigned">r.</abbr> 1658–1707</span>), under whose reign the <a href="/wiki/Proto-industrialization" title="Proto-industrialization">proto-industrialization</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[327]</a></sup> was waved and India surpassed Qing China in becoming the world's largest economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[328]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[329]</a></sup> Aurangzeb was less tolerant than his predecessors, reintroducing the <i>jizya</i> tax and destroying several historical temples, while at the same time building more Hindu temples than he destroyed,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Copland2013_332-0"><a href="#cite_note-Copland2013-332">[330]</a></sup> employing significantly more Hindus in his imperial bureaucracy than his predecessors, and advancing administrators based on their ability rather than their religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TruschkePT50_333-0"><a href="#cite_note-TruschkePT50-333">[331]</a></sup> However, he is often blamed for the erosion of the tolerant syncretic tradition of his predecessors, as well as increasing religious controversy and centralisation.
