The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/English_East_India_Company" title="English East India Company">English East India Company</a> suffered a defeat at the <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Mughal_War" title="Anglo-Mughal War">Anglo-Mughal War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[332]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[333]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:1751_map_of_India_from_%22Historical_Atlas_of_India%22,_by_Charles_Joppen.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1824" data-file-width="1259" decoding="async" height="217" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/1751_map_of_India_from_%22Historical_Atlas_of_India%22%2C_by_Charles_Joppen.jpg/150px-1751_map_of_India_from_%22Historical_Atlas_of_India%22%2C_by_Charles_Joppen.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/1751_map_of_India_from_%22Historical_Atlas_of_India%22%2C_by_Charles_Joppen.jpg/225px-1751_map_of_India_from_%22Historical_Atlas_of_India%22%2C_by_Charles_Joppen.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/1751_map_of_India_from_%22Historical_Atlas_of_India%22%2C_by_Charles_Joppen.jpg/300px-1751_map_of_India_from_%22Historical_Atlas_of_India%22%2C_by_Charles_Joppen.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:1751_map_of_India_from_%22Historical_Atlas_of_India%22,_by_Charles_Joppen.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>18th century political formation in India.</div></div></div>
<p>The empire went into decline thereafter. The Mughals suffered several blows due to invasions from <a href="/wiki/Maratha_Empire" title="Maratha Empire">Marathas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rajput" title="Rajput">Rajputs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bharatpur_State" title="Bharatpur State">Jats</a> and <a href="/wiki/Durrani_Empire" title="Durrani Empire">Afghans</a>. In 1737, the Maratha general <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bajirao" title="Bajirao">Bajirao</a> of the Maratha Empire invaded and plundered Delhi. Under the general Amir Khan Umrao Al Udat, the Mughal Emperor sent 8,000 troops to drive away the 5,000 Maratha cavalry soldiers. Baji Rao, however, easily routed the novice Mughal general and the rest of the imperial Mughal army fled. In 1737, in the final defeat of Mughal Empire, the commander-in-chief of the Mughal Army, Nizam-ul-mulk, was routed at Bhopal by the Maratha army. This essentially brought an end to the Mughal Empire. While <a href="/wiki/Bharatpur_State" title="Bharatpur State">Bharatpur State</a> under <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jat_people" title="Jat people">Jat</a> ruler <a href="/wiki/Suraj_Mal" title="Suraj Mal">Suraj Mal</a>, overran the Mughal garrison at Agra and plundered the city taking with them the two great silver doors of the entrance of the famous Taj Mahal; which were then melted down by Suraj Mal in 1761.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Grewal2007_336-0"><a href="#cite_note-Grewal2007-336">[334]</a></sup> In 1739, <a href="/wiki/Nader_Shah" title="Nader Shah">Nader Shah</a>, emperor of Iran, defeated the Mughal army at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Karnal" title="Battle of Karnal">Battle of Karnal</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[335]</a></sup> After this victory, Nader captured and sacked Delhi, carrying away many treasures, including the <a href="/wiki/Peacock_Throne" title="Peacock Throne">Peacock Throne</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[336]</a></sup> Mughal rule was further weakened by constant native Indian resistance; <a href="/wiki/Banda_Singh_Bahadur" title="Banda Singh Bahadur">Banda Singh Bahadur</a> led the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sikh" title="Sikh">Sikh</a> <a href="/wiki/Khalsa" title="Khalsa">Khalsa</a> against Mughal religious oppression; Hindu <a href="/wiki/Raja" title="Raja">Rajas</a> of Bengal, <a href="/wiki/Pratapaditya" title="Pratapaditya">Pratapaditya</a> and <a href="/wiki/Raja_Sitaram_Ray" title="Raja Sitaram Ray">Raja Sitaram Ray</a> revolted; and <a href="/wiki/Maharaja" title="Maharaja">Maharaja</a> <a href="/wiki/Chhatrasal" title="Chhatrasal">Chhatrasal</a>, of <a href="/wiki/Bundela" title="Bundela">Bundela</a> Rajputs, fought the Mughals and established the <a href="/wiki/Panna_State" title="Panna State">Panna State</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AsherTalbot2006_339-0"><a href="#cite_note-AsherTalbot2006-339">[337]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Mughal_emperors" title="Mughal emperors">Mughal dynasty</a> was reduced to puppet rulers by 1757. <a href="/wiki/Vadda_Ghalughara" title="Vadda Ghalughara">Vadda Ghalughara</a> took place under the Muslim provincial government based at <a href="/wiki/Lahore" title="Lahore">Lahore</a> to wipe out the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sikh" title="Sikh">Sikhs</a>, with 30,000 Sikhs being killed, an offensive that had begun with the Mughals, with the <a href="/wiki/Chhota_Ghallughara" title="Chhota Ghallughara">Chhota Ghallughara</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[338]</a></sup> and lasted several decades under its Muslim successor states.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[339]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Marathas_and_Sikhs">Marathas and Sikhs</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Maratha_Empire">Maratha Empire</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Maratha_Empire" title="Maratha Empire">Maratha Empire</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Maratha_Army" title="Maratha Army">Maratha Army</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maratha_Navy" title="Maratha Navy">Maratha Navy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Battles_involving_the_Maratha_Empire" title="Battles involving the Maratha Empire">Battles involving the Maratha Empire</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:392px;max-width:392px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader">Maratha Empire</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:133px;max-width:133px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:168px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:India1760_1905.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1485" data-file-width="1154" decoding="async" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/India1760_1905.jpg/131px-India1760_1905.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/India1760_1905.jpg/197px-India1760_1905.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/India1760_1905.jpg/262px-India1760_1905.jpg 2x" width="131"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Maratha_Empire" title="Maratha Empire">Maratha Empire</a> at its zenith in 1760 (yellow area), covering much of the Indian subcontinent, stretching from <a href="/wiki/South_India" title="South India">South India</a> to present-day <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:255px;max-width:255px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:168px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Shaniwarwada_gate.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="1504" decoding="async" height="168" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Shaniwarwada_gate.JPG/253px-Shaniwarwada_gate.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Shaniwarwada_gate.JPG/380px-Shaniwarwada_gate.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Shaniwarwada_gate.JPG/506px-Shaniwarwada_gate.JPG 2x" width="253"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shaniwarwada" title="Shaniwarwada">Shaniwarwada</a> palace fort in <a href="/wiki/Pune" title="Pune">Pune</a>, the seat of the Peshwa rulers of the Maratha Empire until 1818.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The Maratha kingdom was founded and consolidated by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chatrapati_Shivaji" title="Chatrapati Shivaji">Chatrapati Shivaji</a>, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maratha" title="Maratha">Maratha</a> aristocrat of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bhonsle" title="Bhonsle">Bhonsle</a> clan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[340]</a></sup> However, the credit for making the Marathas formidable power nationally goes to <i><a href="/wiki/Peshwa" title="Peshwa">Peshwa</a></i> (chief minister) <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bajirao_I" title="Bajirao I">Bajirao I</a>. Historian K.K. Datta wrote that Bajirao I "may very well be regarded as the second founder of the Maratha Empire".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[341]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the early 18th century, under the Peshwas, the Marathas consolidated and ruled over much of South Asia. The Marathas are credited to a large extent for ending <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal rule</a> in India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pearson_344-0"><a href="#cite_note-pearson-344">[342]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-google3_345-0"><a href="#cite_note-google3-345">[343]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-google4_346-0"><a href="#cite_note-google4-346">[344]</a></sup> In 1737, the Marathas defeated a Mughal army in their capital, in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Delhi_(1737)" title="Battle of Delhi (1737)">Battle of Delhi</a>. The Marathas continued <a href="/wiki/Battles_involving_the_Maratha_Empire" title="Battles involving the Maratha Empire">their military campaigns</a> against the Mughals, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nizam" title="Nizam">Nizam</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nawab_of_Bengal" title="Nawab of Bengal">Nawab of Bengal</a> and the Durrani Empire to further extend their boundaries. By 1760, the domain of the Marathas stretched across most of the Indian subcontinent.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The Marathas even attempted to capture Delhi and discussed putting <a href="/wiki/Vishwasrao" title="Vishwasrao">Vishwasrao</a> Peshwa on the throne there in place of the Mughal emperor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[345]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Maratha empire at its peak stretched from <a href="/wiki/Tamil_Nadu" title="Tamil Nadu">Tamil Nadu</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[346]</a></sup> in the south, to <a href="/wiki/Maratha_conquest_of_North-west_India" title="Maratha conquest of North-west India">Peshawar</a> (modern-day <a href="/wiki/Khyber_Pakhtunkhwa" title="Khyber Pakhtunkhwa">Khyber Pakhtunkhwa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-XWiACEwPR8C_p.16_349-0"><a href="#cite_note-XWiACEwPR8C_p.16-349">[347]</a></sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[note 3]</a></sup>) in the north, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maratha_expeditions_in_Bengal" title="Maratha expeditions in Bengal">Bengal</a> in the east. The Northwestern expansion of the Marathas was stopped after the <a href="/wiki/Third_Battle_of_Panipat" title="Third Battle of Panipat">Third Battle of Panipat</a> (1761). However, the <a href="/wiki/Maratha_Resurrection" title="Maratha Resurrection">Maratha authority in the north was re-established</a> within a decade under Peshwa <a href="/wiki/Madhavrao_I" title="Madhavrao I">Madhavrao I</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[349]</a></sup>
</p><p>Under Madhavrao I, the strongest knights were granted semi-autonomy, creating a confederacy of United Maratha states under the <a href="/wiki/Gaekwad" title="Gaekwad">Gaekwads</a> of <a href="/wiki/Baroda_State" title="Baroda State">Baroda</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Holkar" title="Holkar">Holkars</a> of <a href="/wiki/Indore_State" title="Indore State">Indore</a> and <a href="/wiki/Malwa" title="Malwa">Malwa</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Scindia" title="Scindia">Scindias</a> of <a href="/wiki/Gwalior_State" title="Gwalior State">Gwalior</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ujjain" title="Ujjain">Ujjain</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bhonsale" title="Bhonsale">Bhonsales</a> of <a href="/wiki/Nagpur_kingdom" title="Nagpur kingdom">Nagpur</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Paramara_dynasty" title="Paramara dynasty">Puars</a> of <a href="/wiki/Dhar_State" title="Dhar State">Dhar</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dewas_State_(Maratha_Confederacy)" title="Dewas State (Maratha Confederacy)">Dewas</a>. In 1775, the East India Company intervened in a Peshwa family succession struggle in <a href="/wiki/Pune" title="Pune">Pune</a>, which led to the <a href="/wiki/First_Anglo-Maratha_War" title="First Anglo-Maratha War">First Anglo-Maratha War</a>, resulting in a Maratha victory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Naravane2_353-0"><a href="#cite_note-Naravane2-353">[350]</a></sup> The Marathas remained a major power in India until their defeat in the <a href="/wiki/Second_Anglo-Maratha_War" title="Second Anglo-Maratha War">Second</a> and <a href="/wiki/Third_Anglo-Maratha_War" title="Third Anglo-Maratha War">Third Anglo-Maratha Wars</a> (1805–1818), which resulted in the East India Company controlling most of India.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Sikh_Empire">Sikh Empire</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sikh_Empire" title="Sikh Empire">Sikh Empire</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:442px;max-width:442px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader">Sikh Empire under <a href="/wiki/Ranjit_Singh" title="Ranjit Singh">Ranjit Singh</a></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:169px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sikh_Empire_tri-lingual.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="655" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="170" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Sikh_Empire_tri-lingual.jpg/208px-Sikh_Empire_tri-lingual.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Sikh_Empire_tri-lingual.jpg/312px-Sikh_Empire_tri-lingual.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Sikh_Empire_tri-lingual.jpg/416px-Sikh_Empire_tri-lingual.jpg 2x" width="208"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">The Sikh empire at its greatest geographical extent, ca. 1839</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:228px;max-width:228px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:169px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Golden_Temple_India.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="723" data-file-width="963" decoding="async" height="170" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Golden_Temple_India.jpg/226px-Golden_Temple_India.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Golden_Temple_India.jpg/339px-Golden_Temple_India.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Golden_Temple_India.jpg/452px-Golden_Temple_India.jpg 2x" width="226"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Harmandir_Sahib" title="Harmandir Sahib">Harmandir Sahib</a> is the preeminent pilgrimage site of <a href="/wiki/Sikhism" title="Sikhism">Sikhism</a>. Ranjit Singh rebuilt it in marble and copper in 1809, overlaid the sanctum with gold foil in 1830.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[351]</a></sup></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Sikh_Empire" title="Sikh Empire">Sikh Empire</a>, ruled by members of the <a href="/wiki/Sikhism" title="Sikhism">Sikh religion</a>, was a political entity that governed the Northwestern regions of the Indian subcontinent. The empire, based around the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Punjab_region" title="Punjab region">Punjab region</a>, existed from 1799 to 1849. It was forged, on the foundations of the <a href="/wiki/Khalsa" title="Khalsa">Khalsa</a>, under the leadership of <a href="/wiki/Ranjit_Singh" title="Ranjit Singh">Maharaja Ranjit Singh</a> (1780–1839) from an array of autonomous <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Punjabi_people" title="Punjabi people">Punjabi</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Misls" title="Misls">Misls</a> of the Sikh Confederacy.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Maharaja Ranjit Singh consolidated many parts of northern India into an empire. He primarily used his <a href="/wiki/Sikh_Khalsa_Army" title="Sikh Khalsa Army">Sikh Khalsa Army</a> that he trained in European military techniques and equipped with modern military technologies. Ranjit Singh proved himself to be a master strategist and selected well-qualified generals for his army. He continuously defeated the Afghan armies and successfully ended the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Afghan-Sikh_Wars" title="Afghan-Sikh Wars">Afghan-Sikh Wars</a>. In stages, he added central Punjab, the provinces of Multan and Kashmir, and the Peshawar Valley to his empire.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355">[352]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Grewal_356-0"><a href="#cite_note-Grewal-356">[353]</a></sup>
</p><p>At its peak, in the 19th century, the empire extended from the <a href="/wiki/Khyber_Pass" title="Khyber Pass">Khyber Pass</a> in the west, to <a href="/wiki/Kashmir" title="Kashmir">Kashmir</a> in the north, to <a href="/wiki/Sindh" title="Sindh">Sindh</a> in the south, running along Sutlej river to <a href="/wiki/Himachal_Pradesh" title="Himachal Pradesh">Himachal</a> in the east. After the death of Ranjit Singh, the empire weakened, leading to conflict with the British East India Company. The hard-fought <a href="/wiki/First_Anglo-Sikh_War" title="First Anglo-Sikh War">First Anglo-Sikh War</a> and <a href="/wiki/Second_Anglo-Sikh_War" title="Second Anglo-Sikh War">Second Anglo-Sikh War</a> marked the downfall of the Sikh Empire, making it among the last areas of the Indian subcontinent to be conquered by the British.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_kingdoms">Other kingdoms</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:India_1763_EN.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1231" data-file-width="898" decoding="async" height="302" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/India_1763_EN.svg/220px-India_1763_EN.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/India_1763_EN.svg/330px-India_1763_EN.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/India_1763_EN.svg/440px-India_1763_EN.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:India_1763_EN.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Territories of India in 1763</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Mysore" title="Kingdom of Mysore">Kingdom of Mysore</a> in southern India expanded to its greatest extent under <a href="/wiki/Hyder_Ali" title="Hyder Ali">Hyder Ali</a> and his son <a href="/wiki/Tipu_Sultan" title="Tipu Sultan">Tipu Sultan</a> in the later half of the 18th century. Under their rule, Mysore fought series of wars against the Marathas and British or their combined forces. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maratha%E2%80%93Mysore_War" title="Maratha–Mysore War">Maratha–Mysore War</a> ended in April 1787, following the finalizing of <i>treaty of Gajendragad</i>, in which, Tipu Sultan was obligated to pay tribute to the Marathas. Concurrently, the <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Mysore_Wars" title="Anglo-Mysore Wars">Anglo-Mysore Wars</a> took place, where the Mysoreans used the <a href="/wiki/Mysorean_rockets" title="Mysorean rockets">Mysorean rockets</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Fourth_Anglo-Mysore_War" title="Fourth Anglo-Mysore War">Fourth Anglo-Mysore War</a> (1798–1799) saw the death of Tipu. Mysore's alliance with the French was seen as a threat to the British East India Company, and Mysore was attacked from all four sides. The Nizam of Hyderabad and the Marathas launched an invasion from the north. The British won a decisive victory at the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Seringapatam_(1799)" title="Siege of Seringapatam (1799)">Siege of Seringapatam (1799)</a>.
</p><p>Hyderabad was founded by the <a href="/wiki/Qutb_Shahi_dynasty" title="Qutb Shahi dynasty">Qutb Shahi dynasty</a> of <a href="/wiki/Golconda" title="Golconda">Golconda</a> in 1591. Following a brief Mughal rule, Asif Jah, a Mughal official, seized control of Hyderabad and declared himself <a href="/wiki/Nizam_of_Hyderabad" title="Nizam of Hyderabad">Nizam-al-Mulk of Hyderabad</a> in 1724. The Nizams lost considerable territory and paid tribute to the Maratha Empire after being routed in multiple battles, such as the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Palkhed" title="Battle of Palkhed">Battle of Palkhed</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[354]</a></sup> However, the Nizams maintained their sovereignty from 1724 until 1948 through paying tributes to the Marathas, and later, being vassels of the British. <a href="/wiki/Hyderabad_State" title="Hyderabad State">Hyderabad State</a> became a princely state in British India in 1798.
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nawab_of_Bengal" title="Nawab of Bengal">Nawabs of Bengal</a> had become the de facto rulers of Bengal following the decline of Mughal Empire. However, their rule was interrupted by Marathas who carried out <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Expeditions_in_Bengal" title="Expeditions in Bengal">six expeditions in Bengal</a> from 1741 to 1748, as a result of which Bengal became a tributary state of Marathas. On 23 June 1757, <a href="/wiki/Siraj_ud-Daulah" title="Siraj ud-Daulah">Siraj ud-Daulah</a>, the last independent Nawab of Bengal was betrayed in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Plassey" title="Battle of Plassey">Battle of Plassey</a> by <a href="/wiki/Mir_Jafar" title="Mir Jafar">Mir Jafar</a>. He lost to the British, who took over the charge of Bengal in 1757, installed Mir Jafar on the <i>Masnad</i> (throne) and established itself to a political power in Bengal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sirajbanglaped2_358-0"><a href="#cite_note-sirajbanglaped2-358">[355]</a></sup> In 1765 the system of Dual Government was established, in which the Nawabs ruled on behalf of the British and were mere puppets to the British. In 1772 the system was abolished and Bengal was brought under the direct control of the British. In 1793, when the <i>Nizamat</i> (governorship) of the Nawab was also taken away from them, they remained as the mere pensioners of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_East_India_Company" title="British East India Company">British East India Company</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-british2_359-0"><a href="#cite_note-british2-359">[356]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dualgovernment2_360-0"><a href="#cite_note-dualgovernment2-360">[357]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 18th century, the whole of Rajputana was virtually subdued by the Marathas. The <a href="/wiki/Second_Anglo-Maratha_War" title="Second Anglo-Maratha War">Second Anglo-Maratha War</a> distracted the Marathas from 1807 to 1809, but afterward Maratha domination of Rajputana resumed. In 1817, the British went to war with the <a href="/wiki/Pindari" title="Pindari">Pindaris</a>, raiders who were fled in Maratha territory, which quickly became the <a href="/wiki/Third_Anglo-Maratha_War" title="Third Anglo-Maratha War">Third Anglo-Maratha War</a>, and the British government offered its protection to the Rajput rulers from the Pindaris and the Marathas. By the end of 1818 similar treaties had been executed between the other Rajput states and Britain. The Maratha <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sindhia" title="Sindhia">Sindhia</a> ruler of <a href="/wiki/Gwalior" title="Gwalior">Gwalior</a> gave up the district of <a href="/wiki/Ajmer-Merwara" title="Ajmer-Merwara">Ajmer-Merwara</a> to the British, and Maratha influence in Rajasthan came to an end.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[358]</a></sup> Most of the Rajput princes remained loyal to Britain in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Revolt_of_1857" title="Revolt of 1857">Revolt of 1857</a>, and few political changes were made in Rajputana until Indian independence in 1947. The <a href="/wiki/Rajputana_Agency" title="Rajputana Agency">Rajputana Agency</a> contained more than 20 princely states, most notable being <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Udaipur_State" title="Udaipur State">Udaipur State</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jaipur_State" title="Jaipur State">Jaipur State</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bikaner_State" title="Bikaner State">Bikaner State</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jodhpur_State" title="Jodhpur State">Jodhpur State</a>.
</p><p>After the fall of the <a href="/wiki/Maratha_Empire" title="Maratha Empire">Maratha Empire</a>, many <a href="/wiki/List_of_Maratha_dynasties_and_states" title="List of Maratha dynasties and states">Maratha dynasties and states</a> became vassals in a subsidiary alliance with the British, to form the largest bloc of princely states in the <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British Raj</a>, in terms of territory and population.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> With the decline of the <a href="/wiki/Sikh_Empire" title="Sikh Empire">Sikh Empire</a>, after the <a href="/wiki/First_Anglo-Sikh_War" title="First Anglo-Sikh War">First Anglo-Sikh War</a> in 1846, under the terms of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Amritsar,_1846" title="Treaty of Amritsar, 1846">Treaty of Amritsar</a>, the British government sold Kashmir to Maharaja <a href="/wiki/Gulab_Singh" title="Gulab Singh">Gulab Singh</a> and the princely state of Jammu and Kashmir, the second-largest princely state in British India, was created by the <a href="/wiki/Dogra_dynasty" title="Dogra dynasty">Dogra dynasty</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[359]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[360]</a></sup> While in Eastern and Northeastern India, the Hindu and Buddhist states of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cooch_Behar_Kingdom" title="Cooch Behar Kingdom">Cooch Behar Kingdom</a>, <a href="/wiki/Twipra_Kingdom" title="Twipra Kingdom">Twipra Kingdom</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Sikkim" title="Kingdom of Sikkim">Kingdom of Sikkim</a> were annexed by the British and made vassal princely state.
</p><p>After the fall of the <a href="/wiki/Vijayanagara_Empire" title="Vijayanagara Empire">Vijayanagara Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polygar" title="Polygar">Polygar</a> states emerged in Southern India; and managed to weather invasions and flourished until the <a href="/wiki/Polygar_Wars" title="Polygar Wars">Polygar Wars</a>, where they were defeated by the British East India Company forces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364">[361]</a></sup> Around the 18th century, the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Nepal" title="Kingdom of Nepal">Kingdom of Nepal</a> was formed by Rajput rulers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Schmidt2015_365-0"><a href="#cite_note-Schmidt2015-365">[362]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="European_exploration">European exploration</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Colonial_India" title="Colonial India">Colonial India</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gama_route_1.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="715" data-file-width="875" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Gama_route_1.svg/220px-Gama_route_1.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Gama_route_1.svg/330px-Gama_route_1.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Gama_route_1.svg/440px-Gama_route_1.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gama_route_1.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The route followed in <a href="/wiki/Vasco_da_Gama" title="Vasco da Gama">Vasco da Gama</a>'s first voyage (1497–1499).</div></div></div>
<p>In 1498, a Portuguese fleet under <a href="/wiki/Vasco_da_Gama" title="Vasco da Gama">Vasco da Gama</a> discovered a new sea route from Europe to India, which paved the way for direct Indo-European commerce. The Portuguese soon set up trading posts in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Velha_Goa" title="Velha Goa">Velha Goa</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Damaon" title="Damaon">Damaon</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dio_island" title="Dio island">Dio island</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bombay" title="Bombay">Bombay</a>. After their conquest in Goa, the Portuguese instituted the <a href="/wiki/Goa_Inquisition" title="Goa Inquisition">Goa Inquisition</a>, where new Indian converts were punished for suspected heresy against Christianity and non-Christians were condemned for discouraging those considering conversion or for convincing others to renounce Christianity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Elbl2012p12_366-0"><a href="#cite_note-Elbl2012p12-366">[363]</a></sup> Goa remained the main Portuguese territory until it was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_annexation_of_Goa" title="Indian annexation of Goa">annexed by India in 1961</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[364]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (July 2022)">page needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>The next to arrive <a href="/wiki/Dutch_India" title="Dutch India">were the Dutch</a>, with their main base in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ceylon" title="Ceylon">Ceylon</a>. They established ports in <a href="/wiki/Dutch_Malabar" title="Dutch Malabar">Malabar</a>. However, their expansion into India was halted after their defeat in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Colachel" title="Battle of Colachel">Battle of Colachel</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Travancore" title="Travancore">Kingdom of Travancore</a> during the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Travancore-Dutch_War" title="Travancore-Dutch War">Travancore-Dutch War</a>. The Dutch never recovered from the defeat and no longer posed a large colonial threat to India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[365]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[366]</a></sup>
</p><p>The internal conflicts among Indian kingdoms gave opportunities to the European traders to gradually establish political influence and appropriate lands. Following the Dutch, the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British</a>—who set up in the west coast port of <a href="/wiki/Surat" title="Surat">Surat</a> in 1619—and the French both established trading outposts in India. Although these continental European powers controlled various coastal regions of southern and eastern India during the ensuing century, they eventually lost all their territories in India to the British, with the exception of the French outposts of <a href="/wiki/Puducherry_(union_territory)" title="Puducherry (union territory)">Pondichéry</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chandernagore" title="Chandernagore">Chandernagore</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[367]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[368]</a></sup> and the Portuguese colonies of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Goa,_Damaon%26_Diu" title="Goa, Damaon&amp; Diu">Goa, Damaon&amp; Diu</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[369]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="East_India_Company_rule_in_India">East India Company rule in India</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/East_India_Company" title="East India Company">East India Company</a> and <a href="/wiki/Company_rule_in_India" title="Company rule in India">Company rule in India</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:217px;max-width:217px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader">India under <a href="/wiki/Company_rule_in_India" title="Company rule in India">East India Company rule</a></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:215px;max-width:215px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:164px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:India1765and1805b.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="950" data-file-width="1227" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/India1765and1805b.jpg/213px-India1765and1805b.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/India1765and1805b.jpg/320px-India1765and1805b.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/India1765and1805b.jpg/426px-India1765and1805b.jpg 2x" width="213"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">India in 1765 and 1805 showing East India Company Territories in pink.</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:215px;max-width:215px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:165px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:India1837to1857.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="958" data-file-width="1232" decoding="async" height="166" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/India1837to1857.jpg/213px-India1837to1857.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/India1837to1857.jpg/320px-India1837to1857.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/India1837to1857.jpg/426px-India1837to1857.jpg 2x" width="213"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">India in 1837 and 1857 showing East India Company (pink) and other territories</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/East_India_Company" title="East India Company">English East India Company</a> was founded in 1600 as <i>The Company of Merchants of London Trading into the East Indies</i>. It gained a foothold in India with the establishment of a <a href="/wiki/Factory_(trading_post)" title="Factory (trading post)">factory</a> in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Masulipatnam" title="Masulipatnam">Masulipatnam</a> on the Eastern coast of India in 1611 and a grant of rights by the Mughal emperor Jahangir to establish a factory in <a href="/wiki/Surat" title="Surat">Surat</a> in 1612. In 1640, after receiving similar permission from the <a href="/wiki/Vijayanagara_Empire" title="Vijayanagara Empire">Vijayanagara ruler</a> farther south, a second factory was established in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Madras" title="Madras">Madras</a> on the southeastern coast. The <a href="/wiki/Islet" title="Islet">islet</a> of <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bom_Bahia" title="Bom Bahia">Bom Bahia</a></i> in present-day Mumbai (Bombay), was a Portuguese <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Outpost" title="Outpost">outpost</a> not far from Surat, it was presented to <a href="/wiki/Charles_II_of_England" title="Charles II of England">Charles II of England</a> as <a href="/wiki/Dowry" title="Dowry">dowry</a>, in his marriage to <a href="/wiki/Catherine_of_Braganza" title="Catherine of Braganza">Catherine of Braganza</a>, Charles in turn leased Bombay to the Company in 1668. Two decades later, the company established a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trade_post" title="Trade post">trade post</a> in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/River_Ganges" title="River Ganges">River Ganges</a> delta, when a factory was set up in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Calcutta_(Kolkata)" title="Calcutta (Kolkata)">Calcutta (Kolkata)</a>. During this time other companies established by the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_East_India_Company" title="Portuguese East India Company">Portuguese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company" title="Dutch East India Company">Dutch</a>, <a href="/wiki/French_East_India_Company" title="French East India Company">French</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Danish_East_India_Company" title="Danish East India Company">Danish</a> were similarly expanding in the sub-continent.
</p><p>The company's victory under <a href="/wiki/Robert_Clive" title="Robert Clive">Robert Clive</a> in the 1757 <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Plassey" title="Battle of Plassey">Battle of Plassey</a> and another victory in the 1764 <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Buxar" title="Battle of Buxar">Battle of Buxar</a> (in Bihar), consolidated the company's power, and forced emperor <a href="/wiki/Shah_Alam_II" title="Shah Alam II">Shah Alam II</a> to appoint it the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diwan_(title)" title="Diwan (title)">diwan</a></i>, or revenue collector, of Bengal, Bihar, and <a href="/wiki/Odisha" title="Odisha">Orissa</a>. The company thus became the <i>de facto</i> ruler of large areas of the <a href="/wiki/Lower_Gangetic_Plains_moist_deciduous_forests" title="Lower Gangetic Plains moist deciduous forests">lower Gangetic plain</a> by 1773. It also proceeded by degrees to expand its dominions around Bombay and Madras. The <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Mysore_Wars" title="Anglo-Mysore Wars">Anglo-Mysore Wars</a> (1766–99) and the <a class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Anglo-Maratha_Wars_(disambiguation)" title="Anglo-Maratha Wars (disambiguation)">Anglo-Maratha Wars</a> (1772–1818) left it in control of large areas of India south of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sutlej_River" title="Sutlej River">Sutlej River</a>. With the defeat of the <a href="/wiki/Maratha_Empire" title="Maratha Empire">Marathas</a>, no native power represented a threat for the company any longer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[370]</a></sup>
</p><p>The expansion of the company's power chiefly took two forms. The first of these was the outright annexation of Indian states and subsequent direct governance of the underlying regions that collectively came to comprise <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_India" title="British India">British India</a>. The annexed regions included the <a href="/wiki/North-Western_Provinces" title="North-Western Provinces">North-Western Provinces</a> (comprising <a href="/wiki/Rohilkhand" title="Rohilkhand">Rohilkhand</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gorakhpur,_Uttar_Pradesh" title="Gorakhpur, Uttar Pradesh">Gorakhpur</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Doab" title="Doab">Doab</a>) (1801), Delhi (1803), Assam (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ahom_Kingdom" title="Ahom Kingdom">Ahom Kingdom</a> 1828) and <a href="/wiki/Sindh" title="Sindh">Sindh</a> (1843). <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Punjab_region" title="Punjab region">Punjab</a>, <a href="/wiki/North-West_Frontier_Province" title="North-West Frontier Province">North-West Frontier Province</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kashmir" title="Kashmir">Kashmir</a> were annexed after the <a href="/wiki/Second_Anglo-Sikh_War" title="Second Anglo-Sikh War">Anglo-Sikh Wars</a> in 1849–56 (Period of tenure of Marquess of Dalhousie Governor General). However, Kashmir was immediately sold under the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Amritsar,_1846" title="Treaty of Amritsar, 1846">Treaty of Amritsar</a> (1850) to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dogra_Dynasty" title="Dogra Dynasty">Dogra Dynasty</a> of <a href="/wiki/Jammu" title="Jammu">Jammu</a> and thereby became a princely state. In 1854, <a href="/wiki/Berar_Province" title="Berar Province">Berar</a> was annexed along with the state of <a href="/wiki/Oudh_State" title="Oudh State">Oudh</a> two years later.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ludden-expansion_374-0"><a href="#cite_note-ludden-expansion-374">[371]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1021810730" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="mod-gallery mod-gallery-default mod-gallery-center"><div class="main"><div><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional nochecker bordered-images whitebg">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Warren_Hastings_greyscale.jpg" title="Warren Hastings, the first governor-general of Fort William (Bengal) who oversaw the company's territories in India."><img alt="Warren Hastings, the first governor-general of Fort William (Bengal) who oversaw the company's territories in India." data-file-height="774" data-file-width="592" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Warren_Hastings_greyscale.jpg/138px-Warren_Hastings_greyscale.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Warren_Hastings_greyscale.jpg/206px-Warren_Hastings_greyscale.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Warren_Hastings_greyscale.jpg/275px-Warren_Hastings_greyscale.jpg 2x" width="138"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Warren_Hastings" title="Warren Hastings">Warren Hastings</a>, the first governor-general of <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Presidency" title="Bengal Presidency">Fort William (Bengal)</a> who oversaw the company's territories in India.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:59.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:India_1835_2_Mohurs.jpg" title='Gold coin, minted 1835, with obverse showing the bust of William IV, king of United Kingdom from 26 June 1830 to 20 June 1837, and reverse marked "Two mohurs" in English (do ashrafi in Urdu) issued during Company rule in India'><img alt='Gold coin, minted 1835, with obverse showing the bust of William IV, king of United Kingdom from 26 June 1830 to 20 June 1837, and reverse marked "Two mohurs" in English (do ashrafi in Urdu) issued during Company rule in India' data-file-height="2923" data-file-width="5752" decoding="async" height="91" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/India_1835_2_Mohurs.jpg/180px-India_1835_2_Mohurs.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/India_1835_2_Mohurs.jpg/270px-India_1835_2_Mohurs.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/India_1835_2_Mohurs.jpg/360px-India_1835_2_Mohurs.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Gold coin, minted 1835, with obverse showing the bust of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/William_IV_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="William IV of the United Kingdom">William IV</a>, king of United Kingdom from 26 June 1830 to 20 June 1837, and reverse marked "Two <a href="/wiki/Mohur" title="Mohur">mohurs</a>" in English (do <a href="/wiki/Ashrafi" title="Ashrafi">ashrafi</a> in <a href="/wiki/Urdu" title="Urdu">Urdu</a>) issued during <a href="/wiki/Company_rule_in_India" title="Company rule in India">Company rule in India</a>
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:49.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Railway_bridge_bhor_ghaut_incline1855.jpg" title="Photograph (1855) showing the construction of the Bhor Ghaut incline bridge, Bombay; the incline was conceived by George Clark, the Chief Engineer in the East India Company's Government of Bombay."><img alt="Photograph (1855) showing the construction of the Bhor Ghaut incline bridge, Bombay; the incline was conceived by George Clark, the Chief Engineer in the East India Company's Government of Bombay." data-file-height="438" data-file-width="712" decoding="async" height="111" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/1c/Railway_bridge_bhor_ghaut_incline1855.jpg/180px-Railway_bridge_bhor_ghaut_incline1855.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/1c/Railway_bridge_bhor_ghaut_incline1855.jpg/270px-Railway_bridge_bhor_ghaut_incline1855.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/1c/Railway_bridge_bhor_ghaut_incline1855.jpg/360px-Railway_bridge_bhor_ghaut_incline1855.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Photograph (1855) showing the construction of the Bhor Ghaut incline bridge, Bombay; the incline was conceived by George Clark, the Chief Engineer in the East India Company's Government of Bombay.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:43px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ganges_canal_roorkee1860.jpg" title="Watercolor (1863) titled, The Ganges Canal, Roorkee, Saharanpur District (U.P.). The canal was the brainchild of Sir Proby Cautley; construction began in 1840, and the canal was opened by Governor-General Lord Dalhousie in April 1854"><img alt="Watercolor (1863) titled, The Ganges Canal, Roorkee, Saharanpur District (U.P.). The canal was the brainchild of Sir Proby Cautley; construction began in 1840, and the canal was opened by Governor-General Lord Dalhousie in April 1854" data-file-height="674" data-file-width="976" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Ganges_canal_roorkee1860.jpg/180px-Ganges_canal_roorkee1860.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Ganges_canal_roorkee1860.jpg/270px-Ganges_canal_roorkee1860.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Ganges_canal_roorkee1860.jpg/360px-Ganges_canal_roorkee1860.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Watercolor (1863) titled, <i>The <a href="/wiki/Ganges_Canal" title="Ganges Canal">Ganges Canal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roorkee" title="Roorkee">Roorkee</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saharanpur_District" title="Saharanpur District">Saharanpur District</a> (<a href="/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh" title="Uttar Pradesh">U.P.</a>)</i>. The canal was the brainchild of <a href="/wiki/Proby_Cautley" title="Proby Cautley">Sir Proby Cautley</a>; construction began in 1840, and the canal was opened by Governor-General Lord Dalhousie in April 1854
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul></div></div></div>
<p>The second form of asserting power involved treaties in which Indian rulers acknowledged the company's <a href="/wiki/Hegemony" title="Hegemony">hegemony</a> in return for limited internal <a href="/wiki/Autonomy" title="Autonomy">autonomy</a>. Since the company operated under financial constraints, it had to set up <i>political</i> underpinnings for its rule.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-brown-p67_375-0"><a href="#cite_note-brown-p67-375">[372]</a></sup> The most important such support came from the <i><a href="/wiki/Subsidiary_alliance" title="Subsidiary alliance">subsidiary alliances</a></i> with Indian princes during the first 75 years of Company rule.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-brown-p67_375-1"><a href="#cite_note-brown-p67-375">[372]</a></sup> In the early 19th century, the territories of these princes accounted for two-thirds of India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-brown-p67_375-2"><a href="#cite_note-brown-p67-375">[372]</a></sup> When an Indian ruler who was able to secure his territory wanted to enter such an alliance, the company welcomed it as an economical method of indirect rule that did not involve the economic costs of direct administration or the political costs of gaining the support of alien subjects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-brown-68_376-0"><a href="#cite_note-brown-68-376">[373]</a></sup>
</p><p>In return, the company undertook the "defense of these subordinate allies and treated them with traditional respect and marks of honor."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-brown-68_376-1"><a href="#cite_note-brown-68-376">[373]</a></sup> Subsidiary alliances created the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Princely_States" title="Princely States">Princely States</a> of the Hindu <a href="/wiki/Maharaja" title="Maharaja">maharajas</a> and the Muslim <a href="/wiki/Nawab" title="Nawab">nawabs</a>. Prominent among the princely states were <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Cochin" title="Kingdom of Cochin">Cochin</a> (1791), <a href="/wiki/Jaipur_State" title="Jaipur State">Jaipur</a> (1794), <a href="/wiki/Travancore" title="Travancore">Travancore</a> (1795), <a href="/wiki/Hyderabad_State" title="Hyderabad State">Hyderabad</a> (1798), <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Mysore" title="Kingdom of Mysore">Mysore</a> (1799), <a href="/wiki/Cis-Sutlej_states" title="Cis-Sutlej states">Cis-Sutlej Hill States</a> (1815), <a href="/wiki/Central_India_Agency" title="Central India Agency">Central India Agency</a> (1819), <a href="/wiki/Cutch_State" title="Cutch State">Cutch</a> and <a href="/wiki/Baroda_State" title="Baroda State">Gujarat Gaikwad territories</a> (1819), <a href="/wiki/Rajputana" title="Rajputana">Rajputana</a> (1818) and <a href="/wiki/Bahawalpur_(princely_state)" title="Bahawalpur (princely state)">Bahawalpur</a> (1833).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ludden-expansion_374-1"><a href="#cite_note-ludden-expansion-374">[371]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Indian_indenture_system">Indian indenture system</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Indian_indenture_system" title="Indian indenture system">Indian indenture system</a></div>
<p>The Indian indenture system was an ongoing system of indenture, a form of debt bondage, by which 3.5 million Indians were transported to various colonies of European powers to provide labor for the (mainly sugar) plantations. It started from the end of slavery in 1833 and continued until 1920. This resulted in the development of a large <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_diaspora" title="Indian diaspora">Indian diaspora</a> that spread from the Caribbean (e.g. Trinidad and Tobago) to the Pacific Ocean (e.g. <a href="/wiki/Fiji" title="Fiji">Fiji</a>) and the growth of large <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indo-Caribbean" title="Indo-Caribbean">Indo-Caribbean</a> and <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Indo-African" title="Indo-African">Indo-African</a> populations.
</p>
<h2><span id="Modern_period_and_independence_.28after_c._1850_CE.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_period_and_independence_(after_c._1850_CE)">Modern period and independence (after c. 1850 CE)</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Rebellion_of_1857_and_its_consequences">Rebellion of 1857 and its consequences</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Indian_Rebellion_of_1857" title="Indian Rebellion of 1857">Indian Rebellion of 1857</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1021810730" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="mod-gallery mod-gallery-default mod-gallery-center"><div class="main"><div><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional nochecker bordered-images whitebg">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Charles_Canning,_1st_Earl_Canning_-_Project_Gutenberg_eText_16528.jpg" title="Charles Canning, the Governor-General of India during the rebellion."><img alt="Charles Canning, the Governor-General of India during the rebellion." data-file-height="459" data-file-width="350" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Charles_Canning%2C_1st_Earl_Canning_-_Project_Gutenberg_eText_16528.jpg/137px-Charles_Canning%2C_1st_Earl_Canning_-_Project_Gutenberg_eText_16528.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Charles_Canning%2C_1st_Earl_Canning_-_Project_Gutenberg_eText_16528.jpg/206px-Charles_Canning%2C_1st_Earl_Canning_-_Project_Gutenberg_eText_16528.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Charles_Canning%2C_1st_Earl_Canning_-_Project_Gutenberg_eText_16528.jpg/274px-Charles_Canning%2C_1st_Earl_Canning_-_Project_Gutenberg_eText_16528.jpg 2x" width="137"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Charles_Canning,_1st_Earl_Canning" title="Charles Canning, 1st Earl Canning">Charles Canning</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Governor-General_of_India" title="Governor-General of India">Governor-General of India</a> during the rebellion.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dalhousie.jpg" title="Lord Dalhousie, the Governor-General of India from 1848 to 1856, who devised the Doctrine of Lapse."><img alt="Lord Dalhousie, the Governor-General of India from 1848 to 1856, who devised the Doctrine of Lapse." data-file-height="643" data-file-width="452" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Dalhousie.jpg/126px-Dalhousie.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Dalhousie.jpg/190px-Dalhousie.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Dalhousie.jpg/253px-Dalhousie.jpg 2x" width="126"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/James_Broun-Ramsay,_1st_Marquess_of_Dalhousie" title="James Broun-Ramsay, 1st Marquess of Dalhousie">Lord Dalhousie</a>, the Governor-General of India from 1848 to 1856, who devised the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doctrine_of_Lapse" title="Doctrine of Lapse">Doctrine of Lapse</a>.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rani_of_jhansi.jpg" title="Lakshmibai, the Rani of Jhansi, one of the principal leaders of the rebellion who earlier had lost her kingdom as a result of the Doctrine of lapse."><img alt="Lakshmibai, the Rani of Jhansi, one of the principal leaders of the rebellion who earlier had lost her kingdom as a result of the Doctrine of lapse." data-file-height="422" data-file-width="287" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Rani_of_jhansi.jpg/122px-Rani_of_jhansi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Rani_of_jhansi.jpg/183px-Rani_of_jhansi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Rani_of_jhansi.jpg/245px-Rani_of_jhansi.jpg 2x" width="122"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Rani_of_Jhansi" title="Rani of Jhansi">Lakshmibai, the Rani of Jhansi</a>, one of the principal leaders of the rebellion who earlier had lost her kingdom as a result of the <a href="/wiki/Doctrine_of_lapse" title="Doctrine of lapse">Doctrine of lapse</a>.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:19px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bahadur_Shah_II_of_India.jpg" title="Bahadur Shah Zafar the last Mughal Emperor, crowned Emperor of India by the rebels, he was deposed by the British, and died in exile in Burma"><img alt="Bahadur Shah Zafar the last Mughal Emperor, crowned Emperor of India by the rebels, he was deposed by the British, and died in exile in Burma" data-file-height="2227" data-file-width="1810" decoding="async" height="172" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Bahadur_Shah_II_of_India.jpg/140px-Bahadur_Shah_II_of_India.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Bahadur_Shah_II_of_India.jpg/210px-Bahadur_Shah_II_of_India.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Bahadur_Shah_II_of_India.jpg/280px-Bahadur_Shah_II_of_India.jpg 2x" width="140"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Bahadur_Shah_Zafar" title="Bahadur Shah Zafar">Bahadur Shah Zafar</a> the last Mughal Emperor, crowned Emperor of India by the rebels, he was deposed by the British, and died in exile in Burma
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul></div></div></div>
<p>The Indian rebellion of 1857 was a large-scale rebellion by soldiers employed by the British East India Company in northern and central India against the company's rule. The spark that led to the mutiny was the issue of new gunpowder cartridges for the Enfield rifle, which was insensitive to local religious prohibition. The key mutineer was <a href="/wiki/Mangal_Pandey" title="Mangal Pandey">Mangal Pandey</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Saul_David_page_70_377-0"><a href="#cite_note-Saul_David_page_70-377">[374]</a></sup> In addition, the underlying grievances over British taxation, the ethnic gulf between the British officers and their Indian troops and land annexations played a significant role in the rebellion. Within weeks after Pandey's mutiny, dozens of units of the Indian army joined peasant armies in widespread rebellion. The rebel soldiers were later joined by Indian nobility, many of whom had lost titles and domains under the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doctrine_of_Lapse" title="Doctrine of Lapse">Doctrine of Lapse</a> and felt that the company had interfered with a traditional system of inheritance. Rebel leaders such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nana_Sahib" title="Nana Sahib">Nana Sahib</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Rani_of_Jhansi" title="Rani of Jhansi">Rani of Jhansi</a> belonged to this group.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[375]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the outbreak of the mutiny in <a href="/wiki/Meerut" title="Meerut">Meerut</a>, the rebels very quickly reached <a href="/wiki/Delhi" title="Delhi">Delhi</a>. The rebels had also captured large tracts of the <a href="/wiki/North-Western_Provinces" title="North-Western Provinces">North-Western Provinces</a> and <a href="/wiki/Awadh" title="Awadh">Awadh</a> (Oudh). Most notably, in Awadh, the rebellion took on the attributes of a patriotic revolt against British presence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[376]</a></sup> However, the British East India Company mobilised rapidly with the assistance of friendly <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Princely_states" title="Princely states">Princely states</a>, but it took the British the remainder of 1857 and the better part of 1858 to suppress the rebellion. Due to the rebels being poorly equipped and having no outside support or funding, they were brutally subdued by the British.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[377]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the aftermath, all power was transferred from the British East India Company to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Crown" title="British Crown">British Crown</a>, which began to administer most of India as a number of provinces. The Crown controlled the company's lands directly and had considerable indirect influence over the rest of India, which consisted of the Princely states ruled by local royal families. There were officially 565 princely states in 1947, but only 21 had actual state governments, and only three were large (Mysore, Hyderabad, and Kashmir). They were absorbed into the independent nation in 1947–48.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[378]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="British_Raj_.281858.E2.80.931947.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="British_Raj_(1858–1947)">British Raj (1858–1947)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British Raj</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader">British Raj</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:290px;max-width:290px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:235px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:British_Indian_Empire_1909_Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1223" data-file-width="1498" decoding="async" height="235" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/British_Indian_Empire_1909_Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India.jpg/288px-British_Indian_Empire_1909_Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/British_Indian_Empire_1909_Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India.jpg/432px-British_Indian_Empire_1909_Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/British_Indian_Empire_1909_Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India.jpg/576px-British_Indian_Empire_1909_Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India.jpg 2x" width="288"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">The British Indian Empire in 1909. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_India" title="British India">British India</a> is shown in pink; the  <a href="/wiki/Princely_state" title="Princely state">princely states</a> in yellow.</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:290px;max-width:290px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:145px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Victoriaterminus1903.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="493" data-file-width="976" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Victoriaterminus1903.JPG/288px-Victoriaterminus1903.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Victoriaterminus1903.JPG/432px-Victoriaterminus1903.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Victoriaterminus1903.JPG/576px-Victoriaterminus1903.JPG 2x" width="288"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">A 1903 stereographic image of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Victoria_Terminus" title="Victoria Terminus">Victoria Terminus</a> a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Terminal_train_station" title="Terminal train station">terminal train station</a>, in Mumbai, completed in 1887, and now a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>After 1857, the colonial government strengthened and expanded its infrastructure via the court system, legal procedures, and statutes. The <a href="/wiki/Indian_Penal_Code" title="Indian Penal Code">Indian Penal Code</a> came into being.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[379]</a></sup> In education, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Thomas_Babington_Macaulay,_1st_Baron_Macaulay" title="Thomas Babington Macaulay, 1st Baron Macaulay">Thomas Babington Macaulay</a> had made schooling a priority for the Raj in his famous minute of February 1835 and succeeded in implementing the use of English as the medium of instruction. By 1890 some 60,000 Indians had matriculated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[380]</a></sup> The Indian economy grew at about 1% per year from 1880 to 1920, and the population also grew at 1%. However, from 1910s Indian private industry began to grow significantly. India built a modern railway system in the late 19th century which was the fourth largest in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[381]</a></sup> The British Raj invested heavily in infrastructure, including canals and irrigation systems in addition to railways, telegraphy, roads and ports.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[382]</a></sup> However, historians have been bitterly divided on issues of economic history, with the Nationalist school arguing that India was poorer at the end of British rule than at the beginning and that impoverishment occurred because of the British.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[383]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1905, <a href="/wiki/George_Curzon,_1st_Marquess_Curzon_of_Kedleston" title="George Curzon, 1st Marquess Curzon of Kedleston">Lord Curzon</a> <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_Bengal_(1905)" title="Partition of Bengal (1905)">split the large province of Bengal</a> into a largely Hindu western half and "Eastern Bengal and Assam", a largely Muslim eastern half. The British goal was said to be for efficient administration but the people of Bengal were outraged at the apparent "divide and rule" strategy. It also marked the beginning of the organised anti-colonial movement. When the Liberal party in Britain came to power in 1906, he was removed. Bengal was reunified in 1911. The new Viceroy Gilbert Minto and the new Secretary of State for India <a href="/wiki/John_Morley" title="John Morley">John Morley</a> consulted with Congress leaders on political reforms. The <a href="/wiki/Indian_Councils_Act_1909" title="Indian Councils Act 1909">Morley-Minto reforms of 1909</a> provided for Indian membership of the provincial executive councils as well as the Viceroy's executive council. The Imperial Legislative Council was enlarged from 25 to 60 members and separate communal representation for Muslims was established in a dramatic step towards representative and responsible government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[384]</a></sup> Several socio-religious organisations came into being at that time. Muslims set up the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All_India_Muslim_League" title="All India Muslim League">All India Muslim League</a> in 1906. It was not a mass party but was designed to protect the interests of the aristocratic Muslims. It was internally divided by conflicting loyalties to Islam, the British, and India, and by distrust of Hindus.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The <a href="/wiki/Hindu_Mahasabha" title="Hindu Mahasabha">Hindu Mahasabha</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rashtriya_Swayamsevak_Sangh" title="Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh">Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh</a> (RSS) sought to represent Hindu interests though the latter always claimed it to be a "cultural" organisation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[385]</a></sup> Sikhs founded the <a href="/wiki/Shiromani_Akali_Dal" title="Shiromani Akali Dal">Shiromani Akali Dal</a> in 1920.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[386]</a></sup> However, the largest and oldest political party <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Congress" title="Indian National Congress">Indian National Congress</a>, founded in 1885, attempted to keep a distance from the socio-religious movements and identity politics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[387]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1021810730" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="mod-gallery mod-gallery-default mod-gallery-center"><div class="main"><div><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional nochecker bordered-images whitebg">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:36px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:VictoriaQueen1862Empress1886.jpg" title="Two silver rupee coins issued by the British Raj in 1862 and 1886 respectively, the first in obverse showing a bust of Victoria, Queen, the second of Victoria, Empress. Victoria became Empress of India in 1876."><img alt="Two silver rupee coins issued by the British Raj in 1862 and 1886 respectively, the first in obverse showing a bust of Victoria, Queen, the second of Victoria, Empress. Victoria became Empress of India in 1876." data-file-height="803" data-file-width="817" decoding="async" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/VictoriaQueen1862Empress1886.jpg/140px-VictoriaQueen1862Empress1886.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/VictoriaQueen1862Empress1886.jpg/210px-VictoriaQueen1862Empress1886.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/VictoriaQueen1862Empress1886.jpg/280px-VictoriaQueen1862Empress1886.jpg 2x" width="140"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Two silver rupee coins issued by the British Raj in 1862 and 1886 respectively, the first in obverse showing a bust of <a href="/wiki/Queen_Victoria" title="Queen Victoria">Victoria, Queen</a>, the second of Victoria, Empress.  Victoria became <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Empress_of_India" title="Empress of India">Empress of India</a> in 1876.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:24.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sir_R._Ross_on_steps_of_laboratory_in_Calcutta,_1898_Wellcome_L0011943.jpg" title="Ronald Ross, left, at Cunningham's laboratory of Presidency Hospital in Calcutta, where the transmission of malaria by mosquitoes was discovered, winning Ross the second Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine in 1902."><img alt="Ronald Ross, left, at Cunningham's laboratory of Presidency Hospital in Calcutta, where the transmission of malaria by mosquitoes was discovered, winning Ross the second Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine in 1902." data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="1332" decoding="async" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Sir_R._Ross_on_steps_of_laboratory_in_Calcutta%2C_1898_Wellcome_L0011943.jpg/140px-Sir_R._Ross_on_steps_of_laboratory_in_Calcutta%2C_1898_Wellcome_L0011943.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Sir_R._Ross_on_steps_of_laboratory_in_Calcutta%2C_1898_Wellcome_L0011943.jpg/210px-Sir_R._Ross_on_steps_of_laboratory_in_Calcutta%2C_1898_Wellcome_L0011943.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Sir_R._Ross_on_steps_of_laboratory_in_Calcutta%2C_1898_Wellcome_L0011943.jpg/280px-Sir_R._Ross_on_steps_of_laboratory_in_Calcutta%2C_1898_Wellcome_L0011943.jpg 2x" width="140"/></a></div></div>

</p>
</div>

</p>
