<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Indian_Renaissance">Indian Renaissance</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British Raj</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Renaissance" title="Bengali Renaissance">Bengali Renaissance</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1021810730" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="mod-gallery mod-gallery-default mod-gallery-center"><div class="main"><div><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional nochecker bordered-images whitebg">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Syed_Ahmed_Khan.jpg" title="Sir Syed Ahmad Khan (1817–1898), the author of Causes of the Indian Mutiny, was the founder of Muhammadan Anglo-Oriental College, later the Aligarh Muslim University."><img alt="Sir Syed Ahmad Khan (1817–1898), the author of Causes of the Indian Mutiny, was the founder of Muhammadan Anglo-Oriental College, later the Aligarh Muslim University." data-file-height="958" data-file-width="599" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Syed_Ahmed_Khan.jpg/112px-Syed_Ahmed_Khan.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Syed_Ahmed_Khan.jpg/169px-Syed_Ahmed_Khan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Syed_Ahmed_Khan.jpg/225px-Syed_Ahmed_Khan.jpg 2x" width="112"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Sir <a href="/wiki/Syed_Ahmad_Khan" title="Syed Ahmad Khan">Syed Ahmad Khan</a> (1817–1898), the author of <i>Causes of the Indian Mutiny</i>, was the founder of <a href="/wiki/Muhammadan_Anglo-Oriental_College" title="Muhammadan Anglo-Oriental College">Muhammadan Anglo-Oriental College</a>, later the <a href="/wiki/Aligarh_Muslim_University" title="Aligarh Muslim University">Aligarh Muslim University</a>.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pandita_Ramabai_Sarasvati_1858-1922_front-page-portrait.jpg" title="Pandita Ramabai (1858–1922) was a social reformer, and a pioneer in the education and emancipation of women in India."><img alt="Pandita Ramabai (1858–1922) was a social reformer, and a pioneer in the education and emancipation of women in India." data-file-height="1545" data-file-width="1125" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Pandita_Ramabai_Sarasvati_1858-1922_front-page-portrait.jpg/131px-Pandita_Ramabai_Sarasvati_1858-1922_front-page-portrait.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Pandita_Ramabai_Sarasvati_1858-1922_front-page-portrait.jpg/196px-Pandita_Ramabai_Sarasvati_1858-1922_front-page-portrait.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Pandita_Ramabai_Sarasvati_1858-1922_front-page-portrait.jpg/262px-Pandita_Ramabai_Sarasvati_1858-1922_front-page-portrait.jpg 2x" width="131"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Pandita_Ramabai" title="Pandita Ramabai">Pandita Ramabai</a> (1858–1922) was a <a href="/wiki/Reform_movement" title="Reform movement">social reformer</a>, and a pioneer in the education and emancipation of women in India.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rabindranath_Tagore_unknown_location.jpg" title="Rabindranath Tagore (1861–1941) was a Bengali language poet, short-story writer, and playwright, and in addition a music composer and painter, who won the Nobel prize for Literature in 1913."><img alt="Rabindranath Tagore (1861–1941) was a Bengali language poet, short-story writer, and playwright, and in addition a music composer and painter, who won the Nobel prize for Literature in 1913." data-file-height="1319" data-file-width="996" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Rabindranath_Tagore_unknown_location.jpg/136px-Rabindranath_Tagore_unknown_location.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Rabindranath_Tagore_unknown_location.jpg/204px-Rabindranath_Tagore_unknown_location.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Rabindranath_Tagore_unknown_location.jpg/272px-Rabindranath_Tagore_unknown_location.jpg 2x" width="136"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Rabindranath_Tagore" title="Rabindranath Tagore">Rabindranath Tagore</a> (1861–1941) was a <a href="/wiki/Bengali_language" title="Bengali language">Bengali language</a> poet, short-story writer, and playwright, and in addition a music composer and painter, who won the Nobel prize for Literature in 1913.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Srinivasa_Ramanujan_-_OPC_-_2_(cleaned).jpg" title="Srinivasa Ramanujan (1887–1920) was an Indian mathematician who made seminal contributions to number theory."><img alt="Srinivasa Ramanujan (1887–1920) was an Indian mathematician who made seminal contributions to number theory." data-file-height="750" data-file-width="576" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Srinivasa_Ramanujan_-_OPC_-_2_%28cleaned%29.jpg/138px-Srinivasa_Ramanujan_-_OPC_-_2_%28cleaned%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Srinivasa_Ramanujan_-_OPC_-_2_%28cleaned%29.jpg/207px-Srinivasa_Ramanujan_-_OPC_-_2_%28cleaned%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Srinivasa_Ramanujan_-_OPC_-_2_%28cleaned%29.jpg/276px-Srinivasa_Ramanujan_-_OPC_-_2_%28cleaned%29.jpg 2x" width="138"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Srinivasa_Ramanujan" title="Srinivasa Ramanujan">Srinivasa Ramanujan</a> (1887–1920) was an Indian mathematician who made seminal contributions to <a href="/wiki/Number_theory" title="Number theory">number theory</a>.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Renaissance" title="Bengali Renaissance">Bengali Renaissance</a> refers to a social reform movement, dominated by <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Hindus" title="Bengali Hindus">Bengali Hindus</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Bengal" title="Bengal">Bengal region</a> of the Indian subcontinent during the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, a period of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_India" title="British India">British rule</a>. Historian <a href="/wiki/Nitish_Sengupta" title="Nitish Sengupta">Nitish Sengupta</a> describes the renaissance as having started with reformer and humanitarian <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Raja_Ram_Mohan_Roy" title="Raja Ram Mohan Roy">Raja Ram Mohan Roy</a> (1775–1833), and ended with Asia's first Nobel laureate <a href="/wiki/Rabindranath_Tagore" title="Rabindranath Tagore">Rabindranath Tagore</a> (1861–1941).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[388]</a></sup> This flowering of religious and social reformers, scholars, and writers is described by historian <a href="/wiki/David_Kopf" title="David Kopf">David Kopf</a> as "one of the most creative periods in Indian history."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[389]</a></sup>
</p><p>During this period, Bengal witnessed an <a href="/wiki/Intellectual" title="Intellectual">intellectual</a> awakening that is in some way similar to the <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a>. This movement questioned existing orthodoxies, particularly with respect to women, marriage, the <a href="/wiki/Dowry" title="Dowry">dowry</a> system, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caste_system" title="Caste system">caste system</a>, and religion. One of the earliest <a href="/wiki/Social_movement" title="Social movement">social movements</a> that emerged during this time was the <a href="/wiki/Young_Bengal" title="Young Bengal">Young Bengal</a> movement, which espoused <a href="/wiki/Rationalism" title="Rationalism">rationalism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">atheism</a> as the common denominators of civil conduct among upper caste educated Hindus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[390]</a></sup> It played an important role in reawakening Indian minds and intellect across the Indian subcontinent.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Famines">Famines</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Famine_in_India" title="Famine in India">Famine in India</a> and <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_major_famines_in_India_during_British_rule" title="Timeline of major famines in India during British rule">Timeline of major famines in India during British rule</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Demographics_of_India" title="Demographics of India">Demographics of India</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1021810730" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="mod-gallery mod-gallery-default mod-gallery-center"><div class="main"><div><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional nochecker bordered-images whitebg">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">

<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Map of famines in India 1800–1885
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:39.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bellary_Zilla,Great_Famine_of_1876%E2%80%9378..jpg" title="Engraving from The Graphic, October 1877, showing the plight of animals as well as humans in Bellary district, Madras Presidency, British India during the Great Famine of 1876–1878."><img alt="Engraving from The Graphic, October 1877, showing the plight of animals as well as humans in Bellary district, Madras Presidency, British India during the Great Famine of 1876–1878." data-file-height="1362" data-file-width="1878" decoding="async" height="131" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Bellary_Zilla%2CGreat_Famine_of_1876%E2%80%9378..jpg/180px-Bellary_Zilla%2CGreat_Famine_of_1876%E2%80%9378..jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Bellary_Zilla%2CGreat_Famine_of_1876%E2%80%9378..jpg/270px-Bellary_Zilla%2CGreat_Famine_of_1876%E2%80%9378..jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Bellary_Zilla%2CGreat_Famine_of_1876%E2%80%9378..jpg/360px-Bellary_Zilla%2CGreat_Famine_of_1876%E2%80%9378..jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Engraving from <i><a href="/wiki/The_Graphic" title="The Graphic">The Graphic</a></i>, October 1877, showing the plight of animals as well as humans in <a href="/wiki/Bellary_district" title="Bellary district">Bellary district</a>, <a href="/wiki/Madras_Presidency" title="Madras Presidency">Madras Presidency</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_India" title="British India">British India</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Great_Famine_of_1876%E2%80%931878" title="Great Famine of 1876–1878">Great Famine of 1876–1878</a>.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:FamineReliefAhmedabad1901.jpg" title="Government famine relief, Ahmedabad, India, during the Indian famine of 1899–1900."><img alt="Government famine relief, Ahmedabad, India, during the Indian famine of 1899–1900." data-file-height="660" data-file-width="608" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/FamineReliefAhmedabad1901.jpg/166px-FamineReliefAhmedabad1901.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/FamineReliefAhmedabad1901.jpg/249px-FamineReliefAhmedabad1901.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/FamineReliefAhmedabad1901.jpg/332px-FamineReliefAhmedabad1901.jpg 2x" width="166"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Government famine relief, Ahmedabad, India, during the <a href="/wiki/Indian_famine_of_1899%E2%80%931900" title="Indian famine of 1899–1900">Indian famine of 1899–1900</a>.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:52.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:OrphansWhoSurvivedBengalFamine1943.jpg" title="A picture of orphans who survived the Bengal famine of 1943"><img alt="A picture of orphans who survived the Bengal famine of 1943" data-file-height="701" data-file-width="1203" decoding="async" height="105" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/OrphansWhoSurvivedBengalFamine1943.jpg/180px-OrphansWhoSurvivedBengalFamine1943.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/OrphansWhoSurvivedBengalFamine1943.jpg/270px-OrphansWhoSurvivedBengalFamine1943.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/OrphansWhoSurvivedBengalFamine1943.jpg/360px-OrphansWhoSurvivedBengalFamine1943.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>A picture of orphans who survived the <a href="/wiki/Bengal_famine_of_1943" title="Bengal famine of 1943">Bengal famine of 1943</a>
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul></div></div></div>
<p>During <a href="/wiki/Company_rule_in_India" title="Company rule in India">British East India Company</a> and <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British Crown</a> rule, India experienced some of deadliest ever recorded <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Famines_in_India" title="Famines in India">famines</a>. These famines, usually resulting from crop failures due to <a href="/wiki/El_Ni%C3%B1o" title="El Niño">El Niño</a> and often exacerbated by policies of the colonial government,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-davis_394-0"><a href="#cite_note-davis-394">[391]</a></sup> included the <a href="/wiki/Great_Famine_of_1876%E2%80%931878" title="Great Famine of 1876–1878">Great Famine of 1876–1878</a> in which 6.1 million to 10.3 million people died,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[392]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Great_Bengal_famine_of_1770" title="Great Bengal famine of 1770">Great Bengal famine of 1770</a> where between 1 and 10 million people died,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[393]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[394]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Indian_famine_of_1899%E2%80%931900" title="Indian famine of 1899–1900">Indian famine of 1899–1900</a> in which 1.25 to 10 million people died,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-davis_394-1"><a href="#cite_note-davis-394">[391]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Bengal_famine_of_1943" title="Bengal famine of 1943">Bengal famine of 1943</a> where between 2.1 and 3.8 million people died.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[395]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Third_plague_pandemic" title="Third plague pandemic">Third plague pandemic</a> in the mid-19th century killed 10 million people in India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[396]</a></sup> Despite persistent diseases and famines, the population of the Indian subcontinent, which stood at up to 200 million in 1750,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[397]</a></sup> had reached 389 million by 1941.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[398]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="World_War_I">World War I</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Indian_Army_during_World_War_I" title="Indian Army during World War I">Indian Army during World War I</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1021810730" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="mod-gallery mod-gallery-default mod-gallery-center"><div class="main"><div><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional nochecker bordered-images whitebg">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:53.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hodsons_Horse_France_1917_IWM_Q_2061.jpg" title="Indian Cavalry on the Western front 1914."><img alt="Indian Cavalry on the Western front 1914." data-file-height="2480" data-file-width="3369" decoding="async" height="103" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Hodsons_Horse_France_1917_IWM_Q_2061.jpg/140px-Hodsons_Horse_France_1917_IWM_Q_2061.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Hodsons_Horse_France_1917_IWM_Q_2061.jpg/210px-Hodsons_Horse_France_1917_IWM_Q_2061.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Hodsons_Horse_France_1917_IWM_Q_2061.jpg/280px-Hodsons_Horse_France_1917_IWM_Q_2061.jpg 2x" width="140"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Indian Cavalry on the Western front 1914.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:61.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2nd_Indian_Cav_Div.jpg" title="Indian cavalry from the Deccan Horse during the Battle of Bazentin Ridge in 1916."><img alt="Indian cavalry from the Deccan Horse during the Battle of Bazentin Ridge in 1916." data-file-height="1870" data-file-width="3011" decoding="async" height="87" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/2nd_Indian_Cav_Div.jpg/140px-2nd_Indian_Cav_Div.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/2nd_Indian_Cav_Div.jpg/210px-2nd_Indian_Cav_Div.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/2nd_Indian_Cav_Div.jpg/280px-2nd_Indian_Cav_Div.jpg 2x" width="140"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Indian cavalry from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Deccan_Horse" title="Deccan Horse">Deccan Horse</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Bazentin_Ridge" title="Battle of Bazentin Ridge">Battle of Bazentin Ridge</a> in 1916.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:67px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Indian_Army_QF_3.7_inch_gun_battery_Jerusalem_1917.jpg" title="Indian Army gunners (probably 39th Battery) with 3.7-inch mountain howitzers, Jerusalem 1917."><img alt="Indian Army gunners (probably 39th Battery) with 3.7-inch mountain howitzers, Jerusalem 1917." data-file-height="762" data-file-width="1400" decoding="async" height="76" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Indian_Army_QF_3.7_inch_gun_battery_Jerusalem_1917.jpg/140px-Indian_Army_QF_3.7_inch_gun_battery_Jerusalem_1917.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Indian_Army_QF_3.7_inch_gun_battery_Jerusalem_1917.jpg/210px-Indian_Army_QF_3.7_inch_gun_battery_Jerusalem_1917.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Indian_Army_QF_3.7_inch_gun_battery_Jerusalem_1917.jpg/280px-Indian_Army_QF_3.7_inch_gun_battery_Jerusalem_1917.jpg 2x" width="140"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Indian Army gunners (probably 39th Battery) with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/3.7-inch_mountain_howitzer" title="3.7-inch mountain howitzer">3.7-inch mountain howitzers</a>, Jerusalem 1917.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:17.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:India_Gate_in_New_Delhi_03-2016.jpg" title="India Gate is a memorial to 70,000 soldiers of the British Indian Army who died in the period 1914–21 in the First World War."><img alt="India Gate is a memorial to 70,000 soldiers of the British Indian Army who died in the period 1914–21 in the First World War." data-file-height="4000" data-file-width="3200" decoding="async" height="175" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/India_Gate_in_New_Delhi_03-2016.jpg/140px-India_Gate_in_New_Delhi_03-2016.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/India_Gate_in_New_Delhi_03-2016.jpg/210px-India_Gate_in_New_Delhi_03-2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/India_Gate_in_New_Delhi_03-2016.jpg/280px-India_Gate_in_New_Delhi_03-2016.jpg 2x" width="140"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>India Gate is a memorial to 70,000 soldiers of the <a href="/wiki/British_Indian_Army" title="British Indian Army">British Indian Army</a> who died in the period 1914–21 in the <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">First World War</a>.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul></div></div></div>
<p>During <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>, over 800,000 volunteered for the army, and more than 400,000 volunteered for non-combat roles, compared with the pre-war annual recruitment of about 15,000 men.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[399]</a></sup> The Army saw action on the <a href="/wiki/Western_Front_(World_War_I)" title="Western Front (World War I)">Western Front</a> within a month of the start of the war at the <a href="/wiki/First_Battle_of_Ypres" title="First Battle of Ypres">First Battle of Ypres</a>. After a year of front-line duty, sickness and casualties had reduced the Indian Corps to the point where it had to be withdrawn. Nearly 700,000 Indians fought the Turks in the Mesopotamian campaign. Indian formations were also sent to East Africa, Egypt, and Gallipoli.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[400]</a></sup>
</p><p>Indian Army and <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Service_Troops" title="Imperial Service Troops">Imperial Service Troops</a> fought during the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sinai_and_Palestine_Campaign" title="Sinai and Palestine Campaign">Sinai and Palestine Campaign</a>'s <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sinai_and_Palestine_Campaign#Suez_Canal_Campaign_(1915–1916)" title="Sinai and Palestine Campaign">defence of the Suez Canal</a> in 1915, at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Romani" title="Battle of Romani">Romani</a> in 1916 and to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_Jerusalem_(1917)" title="Battle of Jerusalem (1917)">Jerusalem</a> in 1917. India units <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Jordan_Valley_(1918)" title="Occupation of the Jordan Valley (1918)">occupied the Jordan Valley</a> and after the <a href="/wiki/German_spring_offensive" title="German spring offensive">German spring offensive</a> they became the major force in the <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Expeditionary_Force" title="Egyptian Expeditionary Force">Egyptian Expeditionary Force</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Megiddo_(1918)" title="Battle of Megiddo (1918)">Battle of Megiddo</a> and in the <a href="/wiki/Desert_Mounted_Corps" title="Desert Mounted Corps">Desert Mounted Corps</a>' advance to <a href="/wiki/Damascus" title="Damascus">Damascus</a> and on to <a href="/wiki/Aleppo" title="Aleppo">Aleppo</a>. Other divisions remained in India guarding the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North-West_Frontier_(military_history)" title="North-West Frontier (military history)">North-West Frontier</a> and fulfilling internal security obligations.
</p><p>One million Indian troops served abroad during the war. In total, 74,187 died,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CWrepdirect_404-0"><a href="#cite_note-CWrepdirect-404">[401]</a></sup> and another 67,000 were wounded.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESumner20017_405-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESumner20017-405">[402]</a></sup> The roughly 90,000 soldiers who died fighting in World War I and the <a href="/wiki/Third_Anglo-Afghan_War" title="Third Anglo-Afghan War">Afghan Wars</a> are commemorated by the <a href="/wiki/India_Gate" title="India Gate">India Gate</a>.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="World_War_II">World War II</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/India_in_World_War_II" title="India in World War II">India in World War II</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1021810730" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="mod-gallery mod-gallery-default mod-gallery-center"><div class="main"><div><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional nochecker bordered-images whitebg">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:52.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Monty,_wavvel,_auk.jpg" title="General Claude Auchinleck (right), Commander-in-Chief of the Indian Army, with the then Viceroy Wavell (centre) and General Montgomery (left)"><img alt="General Claude Auchinleck (right), Commander-in-Chief of the Indian Army, with the then Viceroy Wavell (centre) and General Montgomery (left)" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="105" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Monty%2C_wavvel%2C_auk.jpg/140px-Monty%2C_wavvel%2C_auk.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Monty%2C_wavvel%2C_auk.jpg/210px-Monty%2C_wavvel%2C_auk.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Monty%2C_wavvel%2C_auk.jpg/280px-Monty%2C_wavvel%2C_auk.jpg 2x" width="140"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>General <a href="/wiki/Claude_Auchinleck" title="Claude Auchinleck">Claude Auchinleck</a> (right), Commander-in-Chief of the Indian Army, with the then <a href="/wiki/Governor-General_of_India" title="Governor-General of India">Viceroy</a> <a href="/wiki/Archibald_Wavell,_1st_Earl_Wavell" title="Archibald Wavell, 1st Earl Wavell">Wavell</a> (centre) and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bernard_Law_Montgomery,_1st_Viscount_Montgomery_of_Alamein" title="Bernard Law Montgomery, 1st Viscount Montgomery of Alamein">General Montgomery</a> (left)
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:56px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Indian_women_training_for_air_raid_precautions_(ARP)_duties_in_Bombay,_1942._IND1492.jpg" title="Indian women training for Air Raid Precautions (ARP) duties in Bombay, 1942"><img alt="Indian women training for Air Raid Precautions (ARP) duties in Bombay, 1942" data-file-height="1739" data-file-width="2480" decoding="async" height="98" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Indian_women_training_for_air_raid_precautions_%28ARP%29_duties_in_Bombay%2C_1942._IND1492.jpg/140px-Indian_women_training_for_air_raid_precautions_%28ARP%29_duties_in_Bombay%2C_1942._IND1492.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Indian_women_training_for_air_raid_precautions_%28ARP%29_duties_in_Bombay%2C_1942._IND1492.jpg/210px-Indian_women_training_for_air_raid_precautions_%28ARP%29_duties_in_Bombay%2C_1942._IND1492.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Indian_women_training_for_air_raid_precautions_%28ARP%29_duties_in_Bombay%2C_1942._IND1492.jpg/280px-Indian_women_training_for_air_raid_precautions_%28ARP%29_duties_in_Bombay%2C_1942._IND1492.jpg 2x" width="140"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Indian women training for <a href="/wiki/Air_Raid_Precautions" title="Air Raid Precautions">Air Raid Precautions</a> (ARP) duties in Bombay, 1942
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:57px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:INDIAN_TROOPS_IN_BURMA,_1944.jpg" title="Indian infantrymen of the 7th Rajput Regiment about to go on patrol on the Arakan front in Burma, 1944."><img alt="Indian infantrymen of the 7th Rajput Regiment about to go on patrol on the Arakan front in Burma, 1944." data-file-height="550" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="96" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/INDIAN_TROOPS_IN_BURMA%2C_1944.jpg/140px-INDIAN_TROOPS_IN_BURMA%2C_1944.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/INDIAN_TROOPS_IN_BURMA%2C_1944.jpg/210px-INDIAN_TROOPS_IN_BURMA%2C_1944.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/INDIAN_TROOPS_IN_BURMA%2C_1944.jpg/280px-INDIAN_TROOPS_IN_BURMA%2C_1944.jpg 2x" width="140"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Indian infantrymen of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/7th_Rajput_Regiment" title="7th Rajput Regiment">7th Rajput Regiment</a> about to go on patrol on the <a href="/wiki/Arakan_Campaign_1942%E2%80%9343" title="Arakan Campaign 1942–43">Arakan front</a> in Burma, 1944.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:51.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:VictoryWorldWar2BritishRaj.jpg" title='The stamp series "Victory" issued by the Government of British India to commemorate allied victory in World War II.'><img alt='The stamp series "Victory" issued by the Government of British India to commemorate allied victory in World War II.' data-file-height="896" data-file-width="1176" decoding="async" height="107" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/VictoryWorldWar2BritishRaj.jpg/140px-VictoryWorldWar2BritishRaj.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/VictoryWorldWar2BritishRaj.jpg/210px-VictoryWorldWar2BritishRaj.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/VictoryWorldWar2BritishRaj.jpg/280px-VictoryWorldWar2BritishRaj.jpg 2x" width="140"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>The stamp series "Victory" issued by the Government of British India to commemorate allied victory in World War II.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British India</a> officially declared war on <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a> in September 1939.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kux_406-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kux-406">[403]</a></sup> The British Raj, as part of the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allied Nations</a>, sent over two and a half million volunteer soldiers to fight under British command against the <a href="/wiki/Axis_powers" title="Axis powers">Axis powers</a>. Additionally, several Indian Princely States provided large donations to support the Allied campaign during the War. India also provided the base for American operations in support of China in the <a href="/wiki/China_Burma_India_Theater" title="China Burma India Theater">China Burma India Theatre</a>.
</p><p>Indians fought with distinction throughout the world, including in the <a href="/wiki/European_theatre_of_World_War_II" title="European theatre of World War II">European theatre against Germany</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North_African_Campaign" title="North African Campaign">in North Africa against Germany and Italy</a>, against the Italians in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/East_African_Campaign_(World_War_II)" title="East African Campaign (World War II)">East Africa</a>, in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Syria-Lebanon_Campaign" title="Syria-Lebanon Campaign">the Middle East</a> against the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vichy_French" title="Vichy French">Vichy French</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/South-East_Asian_theatre_of_World_War_II" title="South-East Asian theatre of World War II">South Asian region defending India against the Japanese and fighting the Japanese in Burma</a>. Indians also aided in liberating British colonies such as Singapore and Hong Kong after the Japanese surrender in August 1945. Over 87,000 soldiers from the subcontinent died in World War II.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Congress" title="Indian National Congress">Indian National Congress</a>, denounced Nazi Germany but would not fight it or anyone else until India was independent. Congress launched the <a href="/wiki/Quit_India_Movement" title="Quit India Movement">Quit India Movement</a> in August 1942, refusing to co-operate in any way with the government until independence was granted. The government was ready for this move. It immediately arrested over 60,000 national and local Congress leaders. The <a href="/wiki/All-India_Muslim_League" title="All-India Muslim League">Muslim League</a> rejected the Quit India movement and worked closely with the Raj authorities.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Subhas_Chandra_Bose" title="Subhas Chandra Bose">Subhas Chandra Bose</a> (also called <i>Netaji</i>) broke with Congress and tried to form a military alliance with Germany or Japan to gain independence. The Germans assisted Bose in the formation of the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Legion" title="Indian Legion">Indian Legion</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMüller200955_407-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMüller200955-407">[404]</a></sup> however, it was Japan that helped him revamp the <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Army" title="Indian National Army">Indian National Army</a> (INA), after the <a href="/wiki/First_Indian_National_Army" title="First Indian National Army">First Indian National Army</a> under <a href="/wiki/Mohan_Singh_(general)" title="Mohan Singh (general)">Mohan Singh</a> was dissolved. The INA fought under Japanese direction, mostly in Burma.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fayviiii_408-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fayviiii-408">[405]</a></sup> Bose also headed the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Provisional_Government_of_Free_India" title="Provisional Government of Free India">Provisional Government of Free India</a> (or <a href="/wiki/Azad_Hind" title="Azad Hind">Azad Hind</a>), a government-in-exile based in Singapore.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sarkar410_409-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sarkar410-409">[406]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[407]</a></sup> The government of Azad Hind had its own currency, court, and civil code; and in the eyes of some Indians its existence gave a greater legitimacy to the independence struggle against the British.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>By 1942, neighbouring <a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Burma</a> was invaded by Japan, which by then had already captured the Indian territory of <a href="/wiki/Andaman_and_Nicobar_Islands" title="Andaman and Nicobar Islands">Andaman and Nicobar Islands</a>. Japan gave nominal control of the islands to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Provisional_Government_of_Free_India" title="Provisional Government of Free India">Provisional Government of Free India</a> on 21 October 1943, and in the following March, the <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Army" title="Indian National Army">Indian National Army</a> with the help of Japan crossed into India and advanced as far as <a href="/wiki/Kohima" title="Kohima">Kohima</a> in <a href="/wiki/Nagaland" title="Nagaland">Nagaland</a>. This advance on the mainland of the Indian subcontinent reached its farthest point on Indian territory, retreating from the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Kohima" title="Battle of Kohima">Battle of Kohima</a> in June and from <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Imphal" title="Battle of Imphal">that of Imphal</a> on 3 July 1944.
</p><p>The region of Bengal in British India <a href="/wiki/Bengal_famine_of_1943" title="Bengal famine of 1943">suffered a devastating famine during 1940–1943</a>. An estimated 2.1–3 million died from the famine, frequently characterised as "man-made",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[408]</a></sup> with most sources asserting that wartime <a href="/wiki/Colonization" title="Colonization">colonial</a> policies exacerbated the crisis.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[409]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Indian_independence_movement_.281885.E2.80.931947.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Indian_independence_movement_(1885–1947)">Indian independence movement (1885–1947)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Indian_independence_movement" title="Indian independence movement">Indian independence movement</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_independence_activists" title="Indian independence activists">Indian independence activists</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Movement" title="Pakistan Movement">Pakistan Movement</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1021810730" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="mod-gallery mod-gallery-default mod-gallery-center"><div class="main"><div><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional nochecker bordered-images whitebg">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:59px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:1st_INC1885.jpg" title="The first session of the Indian National Congress in 1885. A. O. Hume, the founder, is shown in the middle (third row from the front). The Congress was the first modern nationalist movement to emerge in the British Empire in Asia and Africa.[410]"><img alt="The first session of the Indian National Congress in 1885. A. O. Hume, the founder, is shown in the middle (third row from the front). The Congress was the first modern nationalist movement to emerge in the British Empire in Asia and Africa.[410]" data-file-height="696" data-file-width="1060" decoding="async" height="92" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/1st_INC1885.jpg/140px-1st_INC1885.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/1st_INC1885.jpg/210px-1st_INC1885.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/1st_INC1885.jpg/280px-1st_INC1885.jpg 2x" width="140"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>The first session of the <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Congress" title="Indian National Congress">Indian National Congress</a> in 1885.  <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/A._O._Hume" title="A. O. Hume">A. O. Hume</a>, the founder, is shown in the middle (third row from the front).  The Congress was the first modern nationalist movement to emerge in the British Empire in Asia and Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Marshall2001_413-0"><a href="#cite_note-Marshall2001-413">[410]</a></sup>
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Surya_Sen_before_1934.jpg" title="Surya Sen, leader of the Chittagong armoury raid, a raid on 18 April 1930 on the armoury of police and auxiliary forces in Chittagong, Bengal, now Bangladesh"><img alt="Surya Sen, leader of the Chittagong armoury raid, a raid on 18 April 1930 on the armoury of police and auxiliary forces in Chittagong, Bengal, now Bangladesh" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="568" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Surya_Sen_before_1934.jpg/128px-Surya_Sen_before_1934.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Surya_Sen_before_1934.jpg/192px-Surya_Sen_before_1934.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Surya_Sen_before_1934.jpg/255px-Surya_Sen_before_1934.jpg 2x" width="128"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Surya_Sen" title="Surya Sen">Surya Sen</a>, leader of the <a href="/wiki/Chittagong_armoury_raid" title="Chittagong armoury raid">Chittagong armoury raid</a>, a raid on 18 April 1930 on the armoury of police and auxiliary forces in <a href="/wiki/Chittagong" title="Chittagong">Chittagong</a>, Bengal, now Bangladesh
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bhagat_Singh%27s_execution_Lahore_Tribune_Front_page.jpg" title="Front page of the Tribune (25 March 1931), reporting the execution of Bhagat Singh, Rajguru and Sukhdev by the British for the murder of 21-year-old police officer J. P. Saunders. Bhagat Singh quickly became a folk hero of the Indian independence movement."><img alt="Front page of the Tribune (25 March 1931), reporting the execution of Bhagat Singh, Rajguru and Sukhdev by the British for the murder of 21-year-old police officer J. P. Saunders. Bhagat Singh quickly became a folk hero of the Indian independence movement." data-file-height="574" data-file-width="400" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Bhagat_Singh%27s_execution_Lahore_Tribune_Front_page.jpg/125px-Bhagat_Singh%27s_execution_Lahore_Tribune_Front_page.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Bhagat_Singh%27s_execution_Lahore_Tribune_Front_page.jpg/188px-Bhagat_Singh%27s_execution_Lahore_Tribune_Front_page.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Bhagat_Singh%27s_execution_Lahore_Tribune_Front_page.jpg/251px-Bhagat_Singh%27s_execution_Lahore_Tribune_Front_page.jpg 2x" width="125"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Front page of the <i>Tribune</i> (25 March 1931), reporting the execution of <a href="/wiki/Bhagat_Singh" title="Bhagat Singh">Bhagat Singh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shivaram_Rajguru" title="Shivaram Rajguru">Rajguru</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sukhdev_Thapar" title="Sukhdev Thapar">Sukhdev</a> by the British for the murder of 21-year-old police officer J. P. Saunders. Bhagat Singh quickly became a folk hero of the Indian independence movement.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 175px"><div style="width: 175px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 170px;"><div style="margin:53px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nehru_gandhi.jpg" title="From the late 19th century, and especially after 1920, under the leadership of Mahatma Gandhi (right), the Congress became the principal leader of the Indian independence movement.[411] Gandhi is shown here with Jawaharlal Nehru, later the first prime minister of India."><img alt="From the late 19th century, and especially after 1920, under the leadership of Mahatma Gandhi (right), the Congress became the principal leader of the Indian independence movement.[411] Gandhi is shown here with Jawaharlal Nehru, later the first prime minister of India." data-file-height="314" data-file-width="421" decoding="async" height="104" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Nehru_gandhi.jpg/140px-Nehru_gandhi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Nehru_gandhi.jpg/210px-Nehru_gandhi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Nehru_gandhi.jpg/280px-Nehru_gandhi.jpg 2x" width="140"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>From the late 19th century, and especially after 1920, under the leadership of <a href="/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi" title="Mahatma Gandhi">Mahatma Gandhi</a> (right), the Congress became the principal leader of the <a href="/wiki/Indian_independence_movement" title="Indian independence movement">Indian independence movement</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-research_414-0"><a href="#cite_note-research-414">[411]</a></sup>  Gandhi is shown here with <a href="/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru" title="Jawaharlal Nehru">Jawaharlal Nehru</a>, later the first prime minister of India.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul></div></div></div>
<p>The numbers of British in India were small,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[412]</a></sup> yet they were able to rule 52% of the Indian subcontinent directly and exercise considerable leverage over the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Princely_states" title="Princely states">princely states</a> that accounted for 48% of the area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Markovits2004_416-0"><a href="#cite_note-Markovits2004-416">[413]</a></sup>
</p><p>One of the most important events of the 19th century was the rise of Indian nationalism,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Modern_India,_Bipin_Chandra,_p.76_417-0"><a href="#cite_note-Modern_India,_Bipin_Chandra,_p.76-417">[414]</a></sup> leading Indians to seek first "self-rule" and later "complete independence". However, historians are divided over the causes of its rise. Probable reasons include a "clash of interests of the Indian people with British interests",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Modern_India,_Bipin_Chandra,_p.76_417-1"><a href="#cite_note-Modern_India,_Bipin_Chandra,_p.76-417">[414]</a></sup> "racial discriminations",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[415]</a></sup> and "the revelation of India's past".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[416]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first step toward Indian self-rule was the appointment of <a href="/wiki/Councillor" title="Councillor">councillors</a> to advise the British <a href="/wiki/Viceroy" title="Viceroy">viceroy</a> in 1861 and the first Indian was appointed in 1909. Provincial Councils with Indian members were also set up. The councillors' participation was subsequently widened into legislative councils. The British built a large <a href="/wiki/British_Indian_Army" title="British Indian Army">British Indian Army</a>, with the senior officers all British and many of the troops from small minority groups such as <a href="/wiki/Gurkha" title="Gurkha">Gurkhas</a> from Nepal and <a href="/wiki/Sikhs" title="Sikhs">Sikhs</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-business-standard_420-0"><a href="#cite_note-business-standard-420">[417]</a></sup> The civil service was increasingly filled with natives at the lower levels, with the British holding the more senior positions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[418]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Bal_Gangadhar_Tilak" title="Bal Gangadhar Tilak">Bal Gangadhar Tilak</a>, an Indian nationalist leader, declared <a href="/wiki/Swaraj" title="Swaraj">Swaraj</a> (home rule) as the destiny of the nation. His popular sentence "Swaraj is my birthright, and I shall have it"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-google6_422-0"><a href="#cite_note-google6-422">[419]</a></sup> became the source of inspiration for Indians. Tilak was backed by rising public leaders like <a href="/wiki/Bipin_Chandra_Pal" title="Bipin Chandra Pal">Bipin Chandra Pal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lala_Lajpat_Rai" title="Lala Lajpat Rai">Lala Lajpat Rai</a>, who held the same point of view, notably they advocated the <a href="/wiki/Swadeshi_movement" title="Swadeshi movement">Swadeshi movement</a> involving the boycott of all imported items and the use of Indian-made goods;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chandra2016p128_423-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chandra2016p128-423">[420]</a></sup> the triumvirate were popularly known as <a href="/wiki/Lal_Bal_Pal" title="Lal Bal Pal">Lal Bal Pal</a>. Under them, India's three big provinces – <a href="/wiki/Maharashtra" title="Maharashtra">Maharashtra</a>, Bengal and <a href="/wiki/Punjab_Province_(British_India)" title="Punjab Province (British India)">Punjab</a> shaped the demand of the people and India's nationalism.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> In 1907, the Congress was split into two factions: The radicals, led by Tilak, advocated civil agitation and direct revolution to overthrow the British Empire and the abandonment of all things British. The moderates, led by leaders like <a href="/wiki/Dadabhai_Naoroji" title="Dadabhai Naoroji">Dadabhai Naoroji</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gopal_Krishna_Gokhale" title="Gopal Krishna Gokhale">Gopal Krishna Gokhale</a>, on the other hand, wanted reform within the framework of British rule.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chandra2016p128_423-1"><a href="#cite_note-Chandra2016p128-423">[420]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_Bengal_(1905)" title="Partition of Bengal (1905)">partition of Bengal in 1905</a> further increased the <a href="/wiki/Revolutionary_movement_for_Indian_independence" title="Revolutionary movement for Indian independence">revolutionary movement for Indian independence</a>. The disenfranchisement lead some to take violent action.
</p><p>The British themselves adopted a "carrot and stick" approach in recognition of India's support during the First World War and in response to renewed nationalist demands. The means of achieving the proposed measure were later enshrined in the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_India_Act_1919" title="Government of India Act 1919">Government of India Act 1919</a>, which introduced the principle of a dual mode of administration, or diarchy, in which elected Indian legislators and appointed British officials shared power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[421]</a></sup> In 1919, Colonel <a href="/wiki/Reginald_Dyer" title="Reginald Dyer">Reginald Dyer</a> ordered his troops to fire their weapons on peaceful protestors, including unarmed women and children, resulting in the <a href="/wiki/Jallianwala_Bagh_massacre" title="Jallianwala Bagh massacre">Jallianwala Bagh massacre</a>; which led to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Non-cooperation_Movement" title="Non-cooperation Movement">Non-cooperation Movement</a> of 1920–1922. The massacre was a decisive episode towards the end of British rule in India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425">[422]</a></sup>
</p><p>From 1920 leaders such as <a href="/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi" title="Mahatma Gandhi">Mahatma Gandhi</a> began highly popular mass movements to campaign against the British Raj using largely peaceful methods. The Gandhi-led independence movement opposed the British rule using non-violent methods like <a href="/wiki/Non-cooperation_movement" title="Non-cooperation movement">non-co-operation</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dandi_March" title="Dandi March">civil disobedience</a> and <a href="/wiki/Swadeshi_movement" title="Swadeshi movement">economic resistance</a>. However, <a href="/wiki/Revolutionary_movement_for_Indian_independence" title="Revolutionary movement for Indian independence">revolutionary activities</a> against the British rule took place throughout the Indian subcontinent and some others adopted a militant approach like the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindustan_Republican_Association" title="Hindustan Republican Association">Hindustan Republican Association</a>, founded by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chandrasekhar_Azad" title="Chandrasekhar Azad">Chandrasekhar Azad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bhagat_Singh" title="Bhagat Singh">Bhagat Singh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sukhdev_Thapar" title="Sukhdev Thapar">Sukhdev Thapar</a> and others, that sought to overthrow British rule by armed struggle.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/All_India_Azad_Muslim_Conference" title="All India Azad Muslim Conference">All India Azad Muslim Conference</a> gathered in Delhi in April 1940 to voice its support for an <a href="/wiki/Opposition_to_the_partition_of_India" title="Opposition to the partition of India">independent and united India</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-QasmiRobb2017_426-0"><a href="#cite_note-QasmiRobb2017-426">[423]</a></sup> Its members included several Islamic organisations in India, as well as 1400 nationalist Muslim delegates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Haq1970_427-0"><a href="#cite_note-Haq1970-427">[424]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ahmed2016_428-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ahmed2016-428">[425]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ali2017_429-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ali2017-429">[426]</a></sup> The pro-separatist All-India Muslim League worked to try to silence those nationalist Muslims who stood against the partition of India, often using "intimidation and coercion".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ahmed2016_428-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ahmed2016-428">[425]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ali2017_429-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ali2017-429">[426]</a></sup> The murder of the All India Azad Muslim Conference leader <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Allah_Bakhsh_Soomro" title="Allah Bakhsh Soomro">Allah Bakhsh Soomro</a> also made it easier for the pro-separatist All-India Muslim League to demand the creation of a Pakistan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ali2017_429-2"><a href="#cite_note-Ali2017-429">[426]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="After_World_War_II_.28c._1946.E2.80.931947.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="After_World_War_II_(c._1946–1947)">After World War II (c. 1946–1947)</span></h4>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1062260506">.mw-parser-output .quotebox{background-color:#F9F9F9;border:1px solid #aaa;box-sizing:border-box;padding:10px;font-size:88%;max-width:100%}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatleft{margin:.5em 1.4em .8em 0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatright{margin:.5em 0 .8em 1.4em}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.centered{overflow:hidden;position:relative;margin:.5em auto .8em auto}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatleft span,.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatright span{font-style:inherit}.mw-parser-output .quotebox>blockquote{margin:0;padding:0;border-left:0;font-family:inherit;font-size:inherit}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-title{background-color:#F9F9F9;text-align:center;font-size:110%;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote>:first-child{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote:last-child>:last-child{margin-bottom:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote.quoted:before{font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;font-weight:bold;font-size:large;color:gray;content:" “ ";vertical-align:-45%;line-height:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote.quoted:after{font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;font-weight:bold;font-size:large;color:gray;content:" ” ";line-height:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .left-aligned{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .right-aligned{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .center-aligned{text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .quote-title,.mw-parser-output .quotebox .quotebox-quote{display:block}.mw-parser-output .quotebox cite{display:block;font-style:normal}@media screen and (max-width:640px){.mw-parser-output .quotebox{width:100%!important;margin:0 0 .8em!important;float:none!important}}</style><div class="quotebox pullquote floatright" style="width:15em; border-width: 1px; font-size: 85%; background-color: #D0F0C0;">
<blockquote class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style="">
<p>"A moment comes, which comes but rarely in history, when we step out from the old to the new; when an age ends; and when the soul of a nation long suppressed finds utterance."
</p>
</blockquote>
<p><cite class="right-aligned" style=""> — From, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tryst_with_destiny" title="Tryst with destiny">Tryst with destiny</a>, a speech given by <a href="/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru" title="Jawaharlal Nehru">Jawaharlal Nehru</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Constituent_Assembly_of_India" title="Constituent Assembly of India">Constituent Assembly of India</a> on the eve of independence, 14 August 1947.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Great_Speeches_430-0"><a href="#cite_note-Great_Speeches-430">[427]</a></sup></cite>
</p>
</div>
<p>In January 1946, several mutinies broke out in the armed services, starting with that of RAF servicemen frustrated with their slow repatriation to <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">Britain</a>. The mutinies came to a head with <a href="/wiki/Royal_Indian_Navy_mutiny" title="Royal Indian Navy mutiny">mutiny of the Royal Indian Navy</a> in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bombay" title="Bombay">Bombay</a> in February 1946, followed by others in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Calcutta" title="Calcutta">Calcutta</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Madras" title="Madras">Madras</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Karachi" title="Karachi">Karachi</a>. The mutinies were rapidly suppressed. Also in early 1946, new elections were called and <a href="/wiki/Congress" title="Congress">Congress</a> candidates won in eight of the eleven provinces.
</p><p>Late in 1946, the Labour government decided to end British rule of India, and in early 1947 it announced its intention of transferring power no later than June 1948 and participating in the formation of an <a href="/wiki/Interim_Government_of_India" title="Interim Government of India">interim government</a>.
</p><p>Along with the desire for independence, tensions between Hindus and Muslims had also been developing over the years. The Muslims had always been a minority within the Indian subcontinent, and the prospect of an exclusively Hindu government made them wary of independence; they were as inclined to mistrust Hindu rule as they were to resist the foreign Raj.
</p><p>Muslim League leader <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_Jinnah" title="Muhammad Ali Jinnah">Muhammad Ali Jinnah</a> proclaimed 16 August 1946 as <a href="/wiki/Direct_Action_Day" title="Direct Action Day">Direct Action Day</a>, with the stated goal of highlighting, peacefully, the demand for a Muslim homeland in British India, which resulted in the outbreak of the cycle of violence that would be later called the "<a href="/wiki/Direct_Action_Day" title="Direct Action Day">Great Calcutta Killing of August 1946</a>". The communal violence spread to <a href="/wiki/Bihar" title="Bihar">Bihar</a> (where Muslims were attacked by Hindus), to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Noakhali" title="Noakhali">Noakhali</a> in Bengal (where Hindus were targeted by Muslims), in <a href="/wiki/Garhmukteshwar" title="Garhmukteshwar">Garhmukteshwar</a> in the <a href="/wiki/United_Provinces_of_Agra_and_Oudh" title="United Provinces of Agra and Oudh">United Provinces</a> (where Muslims were attacked by Hindus), and on to <a href="/wiki/Rawalpindi" title="Rawalpindi">Rawalpindi</a> in March 1947 in which Hindus were attacked or driven out by Muslims.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Literacy_India_1901_2011_Detail.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="526" data-file-width="615" decoding="async" height="188" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Literacy_India_1901_2011_Detail.png/220px-Literacy_India_1901_2011_Detail.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Literacy_India_1901_2011_Detail.png/330px-Literacy_India_1901_2011_Detail.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Literacy_India_1901_2011_Detail.png/440px-Literacy_India_1901_2011_Detail.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Literacy_India_1901_2011_Detail.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Literacy_in_India" title="Literacy in India">Literacy in India</a> grew very slowly until independence in 1947. An acceleration in the rate of literacy growth occurred in the 1991–2001 period.</div></div></div>
<h3><span id="Independence_and_partition_.28c._1947.E2.80.93present.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Independence_and_partition_(c._1947–present)">Independence and partition (c. 1947–present)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_India" title="Partition of India">Partition of India</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)" title="History of India (1947–present)">History of India (1947–present)</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Pakistan_(1947%E2%80%93present)" title="History of Pakistan (1947–present)">History of Pakistan (1947–present)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Bangladesh" title="History of Bangladesh">History of Bangladesh</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1021810730" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="mod-gallery mod-gallery-default mod-gallery-center"><div class="main"><div><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional nochecker bordered-images whitebg">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:32px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Brit_IndianEmpireReligions3.jpg" title="A map of the prevailing religions of the British Indian empire based on district-wise majorities based on the Indian census of 1909, and published in the Imperial Gazetteer of India. The partition of the Punjab and Bengal was based on such majorities."><img alt="A map of the prevailing religions of the British Indian empire based on district-wise majorities based on the Indian census of 1909, and published in the Imperial Gazetteer of India. The partition of the Punjab and Bengal was based on such majorities." data-file-height="1241" data-file-width="1534" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Brit_IndianEmpireReligions3.jpg/180px-Brit_IndianEmpireReligions3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Brit_IndianEmpireReligions3.jpg/270px-Brit_IndianEmpireReligions3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Brit_IndianEmpireReligions3.jpg/360px-Brit_IndianEmpireReligions3.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>A map of the prevailing religions of the British Indian empire based on district-wise majorities based on the Indian census of 1909, and published in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India" title="Imperial Gazetteer of India">Imperial Gazetteer of India</a>.  The partition of the <a href="/wiki/Punjab" title="Punjab">Punjab</a> and Bengal was based on such majorities.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:31px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_Badshah_Khan_in_Bela_Bihar_1947.jpg" title="Gandhi touring Bela, Bihar, a village struck by religious rioting in March 1947. On the right is Khan Abdul Gaffar Khan."><img alt="Gandhi touring Bela, Bihar, a village struck by religious rioting in March 1947. On the right is Khan Abdul Gaffar Khan." data-file-height="287" data-file-width="350" decoding="async" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Gandhi_Badshah_Khan_in_Bela_Bihar_1947.jpg/180px-Gandhi_Badshah_Khan_in_Bela_Bihar_1947.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Gandhi_Badshah_Khan_in_Bela_Bihar_1947.jpg/270px-Gandhi_Badshah_Khan_in_Bela_Bihar_1947.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/dd/Gandhi_Badshah_Khan_in_Bela_Bihar_1947.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Gandhi touring <a href="/wiki/Bela,_Bihar" title="Bela, Bihar">Bela, Bihar</a>, a village struck by religious rioting in March 1947. On the right is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Khan_Abdul_Gaffar_Khan" title="Khan Abdul Gaffar Khan">Khan Abdul Gaffar Khan</a>.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215px"><div style="width: 215px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 210px;"><div style="margin:50px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lord_Mountbatten_swears_in_Jawaharlal_Nehru_as_the_first_Prime_Minister_of_free_India_on_Aug_15,_1947.jpg" title="Jawaharlal Nehru being sworn in as the first prime minister of independent India by viceroy Lord Louis Mountbatten at 8:30 AM 15 August 1947."><img alt="Jawaharlal Nehru being sworn in as the first prime minister of independent India by viceroy Lord Louis Mountbatten at 8:30 AM 15 August 1947." data-file-height="406" data-file-width="667" decoding="async" height="110" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Lord_Mountbatten_swears_in_Jawaharlal_Nehru_as_the_first_Prime_Minister_of_free_India_on_Aug_15%2C_1947.jpg/180px-Lord_Mountbatten_swears_in_Jawaharlal_Nehru_as_the_first_Prime_Minister_of_free_India_on_Aug_15%2C_1947.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Lord_Mountbatten_swears_in_Jawaharlal_Nehru_as_the_first_Prime_Minister_of_free_India_on_Aug_15%2C_1947.jpg/270px-Lord_Mountbatten_swears_in_Jawaharlal_Nehru_as_the_first_Prime_Minister_of_free_India_on_Aug_15%2C_1947.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Lord_Mountbatten_swears_in_Jawaharlal_Nehru_as_the_first_Prime_Minister_of_free_India_on_Aug_15%2C_1947.jpg/360px-Lord_Mountbatten_swears_in_Jawaharlal_Nehru_as_the_first_Prime_Minister_of_free_India_on_Aug_15%2C_1947.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru" title="Jawaharlal Nehru">Jawaharlal Nehru</a> being sworn in as the first prime minister of independent India by viceroy <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lord_Louis_Mountbatten" title="Lord Louis Mountbatten">Lord Louis Mountbatten</a> at 8:30 AM 15 August 1947.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul></div></div></div>
<p>In August 1947, the British Indian Empire was <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_India" title="Partition of India">partitioned</a> into the <a href="/wiki/Dominion_of_India" title="Dominion of India">Union of India</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dominion_of_Pakistan" title="Dominion of Pakistan">Dominion of Pakistan</a>. In particular, the partition of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Punjab_(British_India)" title="Punjab (British India)">Punjab</a> and Bengal led to rioting between Hindus, Muslims, and Sikhs in these provinces and spread to other nearby regions, leaving some 500,000 dead. The police and army units were largely ineffective. The British officers were gone, and the units were beginning to tolerate if not actually indulge in violence against their religious enemies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[428]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-symonds_432-0"><a href="#cite_note-symonds-432">[429]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Abid2014_433-0"><a href="#cite_note-Abid2014-433">[430]</a></sup> Also, this period saw one of the largest mass migrations anywhere in modern history, with a total of 12 million Hindus, Sikhs and Muslims moving between the newly created nations of India and Pakistan (which gained independence on 15 and 14 August 1947 respectively).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-symonds_432-1"><a href="#cite_note-symonds-432">[429]</a></sup> In 1971, <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a>, formerly <a href="/wiki/East_Pakistan" title="East Pakistan">East Pakistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/East_Bengal" title="East Bengal">East Bengal</a>, seceded from Pakistan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Raghavan2013_434-0"><a href="#cite_note-Raghavan2013-434">[431]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Historiography">Historiography</span></h2>
<p>In recent decades there have been four main schools of <a href="/wiki/Historiography" title="Historiography">historiography</a> in how historians study India: Cambridge, Nationalist, Marxist, and subaltern. The once common "Orientalist" approach, with its image of a sensuous, inscrutable, and wholly spiritual India, has died out in serious scholarship.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[432]</a></sup>
</p><p>The "<a href="/wiki/Cambridge_School_of_historiography" title="Cambridge School of historiography">Cambridge School</a>", led by Anil Seal,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[433]</a></sup> Gordon Johnson,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437">[434]</a></sup> Richard Gordon, and David A. Washbrook,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-438"><a href="#cite_note-438">[435]</a></sup> downplays ideology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439">[436]</a></sup> However, this school of historiography is criticised for western bias or <a href="/wiki/Eurocentrism" title="Eurocentrism">Eurocentrism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-google7_440-0"><a href="#cite_note-google7-440">[437]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Nationalist school has focused on Congress, Gandhi, Nehru and high level politics. It highlighted the Mutiny of 1857 as a war of liberation, and Gandhi's 'Quit India' begun in 1942, as defining historical events. This school of historiography has received criticism for <a href="/wiki/Elitism" title="Elitism">Elitism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[438]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Marxists have focused on studies of economic development, landownership, and class conflict in precolonial India and of deindustrialisation during the colonial period. The Marxists portrayed Gandhi's movement as a device of the bourgeois elite to harness popular, potentially revolutionary forces for its own ends. Again, the Marxists are accused of being "too much" ideologically influenced.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[439]</a></sup>
</p><p>The "subaltern school", was begun in the 1980s by <a href="/wiki/Ranajit_Guha" title="Ranajit Guha">Ranajit Guha</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gyan_Prakash" title="Gyan Prakash">Gyan Prakash</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[440]</a></sup> It focuses attention away from the elites and politicians to "history from below", looking at the peasants using folklore, poetry, riddles, proverbs, songs, oral history and methods inspired by anthropology. It focuses on the colonial era before 1947 and typically emphasises caste and downplays class, to the annoyance of the Marxist school.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[441]</a></sup>
</p><p>More recently, Hindu nationalists have created a version of history to support their demands for <a href="/wiki/Hindutva#Views_on_Indian_history" title="Hindutva"><i>Hindutva</i></a> ('Hinduness') in Indian society. This school of thought is still in the process of development.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[442]</a></sup> In March 2012, <a href="/wiki/Diana_L._Eck" title="Diana L. Eck">Diana L. Eck</a>, professor of Comparative Religion and Indian Studies at <a href="/wiki/Harvard_University" title="Harvard University">Harvard University</a>, authored in her book <i>India: A Sacred Geography</i>, that the idea of India dates to a much earlier time than the British or the Mughals; it was not just a cluster of regional identities and it was not ethnic or racial.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446"><a href="#cite_note-446">[443]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447"><a href="#cite_note-447">[444]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448">[445]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449"><a href="#cite_note-449">[446]</a></sup>
</p>

<li id="cite_note-DavidMcNiven2018-28"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-DavidMcNiven2018_28-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFTaçon2018"><a href="/wiki/Paul_Ta%C3%A7on" title="Paul Taçon">Taçon, Paul S.C.</a> (17 October 2018). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=tXFyDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA181" rel="nofollow">"The Rock Art of South and East Asia"</a>. (eds.). <i>The Oxford Handbook of the Archaeology and Anthropology of Rock Art</i>. <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>. pp. 181–. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-084495-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-084495-0"><bdi>978-0-19-084495-0</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=The+Rock+Art+of+South+and+East+Asia&amp;rft.btitle=The+Oxford+Handbook+of+the+Archaeology+and+Anthropology+of+Rock+Art&amp;rft.pages=181-&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2018-10-17&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-084495-0&amp;rft.aulast=Ta%C3%A7on&amp;rft.aufirst=Paul+S.C.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DtXFyDwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA181&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Mithen2006-29"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Mithen2006_29-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMithen2006"><a href="/wiki/Steven_Mithen" title="Steven Mithen">Mithen, Steven J.</a> (2006). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=NVygmardAA4C&amp;pg=PA411" rel="nofollow"><i>After the Ice: A Global Human History, 20,000–5000 BC</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/Harvard_University_Press" title="Harvard University Press">Harvard University Press</a>. pp. 411–. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-674-01999-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-674-01999-7"><bdi>978-0-674-01999-7</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=After+the+Ice%3A+A+Global+Human+History%2C+20%2C000%E2%80%935000+BC&amp;rft.pages=411-&amp;rft.pub=Harvard+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-674-01999-7&amp;rft.aulast=Mithen&amp;rft.aufirst=Steven+J.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DNVygmardAA4C%26pg%3DPA411&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-Dyson2018-4-5-44"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Dyson2018-4-5_44-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFDyson2018"><a href="/wiki/Tim_Dyson" title="Tim Dyson">Dyson, Tim</a> (2018). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3TRtDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA4" rel="nofollow"><i>A Population History of India: From the First Modern People to the Present Day</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>. pp. 4–5. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-882905-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-882905-8"><bdi>978-0-19-882905-8</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+Population+History+of+India%3A+From+the+First+Modern+People+to+the+Present+Day&amp;rft.pages=4-5&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-882905-8&amp;rft.aulast=Dyson&amp;rft.aufirst=Tim&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D3TRtDwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA4&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-61"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-61">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFStein2010"><a href="/wiki/Burton_Stein" title="Burton Stein">Stein, Burton</a> (2010). <li id="cite_note-lanman1912-79"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-lanman1912_79-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFLanman1912"><a href="/wiki/Charles_Rockwell_Lanman" title="Charles Rockwell Lanman">Lanman, Charles Rockwell</a> (1912) [First published 1884]. <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/stream/sanskritreaderwi00lanmiala#page/158/mode/1up" rel="nofollow"><i>A Sanskrit reader: with vocabulary and notes</i></a>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-potter1974-80"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-potter1974_80-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFPotterSargent1974"><a href="/wiki/Stephen_Potter" title="Stephen Potter">Potter, Stephen</a>; Sargent, Laurens Christopher (1974). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=8SNDAAAAIAAJ" rel="nofollow"><i>Pedigree: The Origins of Words from Nature</i></a>.
