</li>
<li id="cite_note-81"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-81">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBasu2013">Basu, Abhijit (2013). <i>Marvels and Mysteries of the Mahabharata</i>. <a href="/wiki/Leadstart_publishing" title="Leadstart publishing">Leadstart publishing</a>. p. 153. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-93-84027-47-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-93-84027-47-6"><bdi>978-93-84027-47-6</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Marvels+and+Mysteries+of+the+Mahabharata&amp;rft.pages=153&amp;rft.pub=Leadstart+publishing&amp;rft.date=2013&amp;rft.isbn=978-93-84027-47-6&amp;rft.aulast=Basu&amp;rft.aufirst=Abhijit&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Witzel_1995-82"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Witzel_1995_82-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Witzel_1995_82-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Witzel_1995_82-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Witzel_1995_82-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Witzel_1995_82-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFWitzel1995"><a href="/wiki/Michael_Witzel" title="Michael Witzel">Witzel, Michael</a> (1995). <a class="external text" href="https://crossasia-journals.ub.uni-heidelberg.de/index.php/ejvs/article/view/823/913" rel="nofollow">"Early Sanskritization. Origins and Development of the Kuru State"</a>. <i>Electronic Journal of Vedic Studies</i>. <b>1</b> (4): 1–26. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.11588%2Fejvs.1995.4.823" rel="nofollow">10.11588/ejvs.1995.4.823</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Electronic+Journal+of+Vedic+Studies&amp;rft.atitle=Early+Sanskritization.+Origins+and+Development+of+the+Kuru+State&amp;rft.volume=1&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.pages=1-26&amp;rft.date=1995&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.11588%2Fejvs.1995.4.823&amp;rft.aulast=Witzel&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fcrossasia-journals.ub.uni-heidelberg.de%2Findex.php%2Fejvs%2Farticle%2Fview%2F823%2F913&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-94"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-94">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFOlivelle2008"><a href="/wiki/Patrick_Olivelle" title="Patrick Olivelle">Olivelle, Patrick</a> (2008). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/upanisads00oliv/page/" rel="nofollow"><i>Upaniṣads</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>. pp. <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/upanisads00oliv/page/" rel="nofollow">xxiv–xxix</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-954025-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-954025-9"><bdi>978-0-19-954025-9</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Upani%E1%B9%A3ads&amp;rft.pages=xxiv-xxix&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-954025-9&amp;rft.aulast=Olivelle&amp;rft.aufirst=Patrick&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fupanisads00oliv%2Fpage%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-95"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-95">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMeltonBaumann2010"><a href="/wiki/J._Gordon_Melton" title="J. Gordon Melton">Melton, J. Gordon</a>; Baumann, Martin (21 September 2010). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=v2yiyLLOj88C&amp;pg=PA1324" rel="nofollow"><i>Religions of the World, Second Edition: A Comprehensive Encyclopedia of Beliefs and Practices</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/ABC-Clio" title="ABC-Clio">ABC-Clio</a>. p. 1324. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-59884-204-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-59884-204-3"><bdi>978-1-59884-204-3</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Religions+of+the+World%2C+Second+Edition%3A+A+Comprehensive+Encyclopedia+of+Beliefs+and+Practices&amp;rft.pages=1324&amp;rft.pub=ABC-Clio&amp;rft.date=2010-09-21&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-59884-204-3&amp;rft.aulast=Melton&amp;rft.aufirst=J.+Gordon&amp;rft.au=Baumann%2C+Martin&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dv2yiyLLOj88C%26pg%3DPA1324&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-96"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-96">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Flood, Gavin. Olivelle, Patrick. 2003. <i>The Blackwell Companion to Hinduism</i>. Malden: Blackwell. pp. 273–274. "The second half of the first millennium BC was the period that created many of the ideological and institutional elements that characterize later Indian religions. The renouncer tradition played a central role during this formative period of Indian religious history. ... Some of the fundamental values and beliefs that we generally associate with Indian religions in general and Hinduism, in particular, were in part the creation of the renouncer tradition. These include the two pillars of Indian theologies: samsara—the belief that life in this world is one of suffering and subject to repeated deaths and births (rebirth); moksa/nirvana—the goal of human existence....."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-97"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-97">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Laumakis, Stephen. <i>An Introduction to Buddhist philosophy</i>. 2008. p. 4</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-98"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-98">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Mary Pat Fisher (1997) In: <i>Living Religions: An Encyclopedia of the World's Faiths</i> I.B. Tauris : London <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1-86064-148-2" title="Special:BookSources/1-86064-148-2">1-86064-148-2</a> – <i> Jainism's major teacher is the Mahavira, a contemporary of the Buddha, and who died approximately 526 BC</i>. p. 114</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-99"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-99">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Mary Pat Fisher (1997) In: <i>Living Religions: An Encyclopedia of the World's Faiths</i> I.B. Tauris : London <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1-86064-148-2" title="Special:BookSources/1-86064-148-2">1-86064-148-2</a> '"The extreme antiquity of Jainism as a non-Vedic, indigenous Indian religion is well documented. Ancient Hindu and Buddhist scriptures refer to Jainism as an existing tradition which began long before Mahavira." p. 115</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-100"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-100">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFValmiki1990"><a href="/wiki/Valmiki" title="Valmiki">Valmiki</a> (10 April 1990).  <a href="/wiki/Robert_P._Goldman" title="Robert P. GGKEY:HYY6LT5CFT0.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Republics+in+ancient+India&amp;rft.pages=93-&amp;rft.pub=Brill+Archive&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DzcoUAAAAIAAJ%26pg%3DPA93&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-153"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-153">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFRunion2007">Runion, Meredith L. (2007). <span class="cs1-lock-limited" title="Free access subject to limited trial, subscription normally required"><a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/historyafghanist00runi_653" rel="nofollow"><i>The history of Afghanistan</i></a></span>. Westport: Greenwood Press. p. <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/historyafghanist00runi_653/page/n66" rel="nofollow">46</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-313-33798-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-313-33798-7"><bdi>978-0-313-33798-7</bdi></a>. <q>The Yuezhi people conquered Bactria in the second century BCE. and divided the country into five chiefdoms, one of which would become the Kushan Empire. Recognizing the importance of unification, these five tribes combined under the one dominate Kushan tribe, and the primary rulers descended from the Yuezhi.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+history+of+Afghanistan&amp;rft.place=Westport&amp;rft.pages=46&amp;rft.pub=Greenwood+Press&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-313-33798-7&amp;rft.aulast=Runion&amp;rft.aufirst=Meredith+L.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fhistoryafghanist00runi_653&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-liu156-154"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-liu156_154-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFLiu2001">Liu, Xinrui (2001).  Adas, Michael (ed.). <i>Agricultural and pastoral societies in ancient and classical history</i>. Philadelphia: Temple University Press. p. 156. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-56639-832-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-56639-832-9"><bdi>978-1-56639-832-9</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Agricultural+and+pastoral+societies+in+ancient+and+classical+history&amp;rft.place=Philadelphia&amp;rft.pages=156&amp;rft.pub=Temple+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-56639-832-9&amp;rft.aulast=Liu&amp;rft.aufirst=Xinrui&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-155"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-155">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="http://www.kushan.org/general/other/part1.htm" rel="nofollow"><i>Buddhist Records of the Western World</i></a> Si-Yu-Ki, (Tr. Samuel Beal: Travels of Fa-Hian, The Mission of Sung-Yun and Hwei-Sing, Books 1–5), Kegan Paul, Trench, Trubner &amp; Co. Ltd. London. 1906 and Hill (2009), pp. 29, 318–350</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-156"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-156">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">which began about 127 CE. "Falk 2001, pp. 121–136", Falk (2001), pp. 121–136, Falk, Harry (2004), pp. 167–176 and Hill (2009), pp. 29, 33, 368–371.</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-Madan-171"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Madan_171-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFGopal1990">Gopal, Madan (1990).  K.S. Gautam (ed.). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/indiathroughages00mada" rel="nofollow"><i>India through the ages</i></a>. Publication Division, Ministry of Information and Broadcasting, Government of India. p. <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/indiathroughages00mada/page/173" rel="nofollow">173</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=India+through+the+ages&amp;rft.pages=173&amp;rft.pub=Publication+Division%2C+Ministry+of+Information+and+Broadcasting%2C+Government+of+India&amp;rft.date=1990&amp;rft.aulast=Gopal&amp;rft.aufirst=Madan&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Findiathroughages00mada&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-172"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-172">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The precise number varies according to whether or not some barely started excavations, such as cave 15A, are counted. <a class="external text" href="http://asi.nic.in/asi_monu_whs_ajanta.asp" rel="nofollow">The ASI say</a> "In all, total 30 excavations were hewn out of rock which also include an unfinished one", UNESCO and Spink "about 30". The controversies over the end date of excavation is covered below.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-173"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-173">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Tej Ram Sharma, 1978, "Personal and geographical names in the Gupta inscriptions. (1.publ.)", p. 254, Kamarupa consisted of the Western districts of the Brahmaputra valley which being the most powerful state.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-174"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-174">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Suresh Kant Sharma, Usha Sharma – 2005, "Discovery of North-East India: Geography, History, Culture, ... – Volume 3", p. 248, Davaka (Nowgong) and Kamarupa as separate and submissive friendly kingdoms.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-175"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-175">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The eastern border of Kamarupa is given by the temple of the goddess Tamreshvari (Pūrvāte Kāmarūpasya devī Dikkaravasini in <a href="/wiki/Kalika_Purana" title="Kalika Purana">Kalika Purana</a>) near present-day Sadiya. "...the temple of the goddess Tameshwari (Dikkaravasini) is now located at modern Sadiya about 100 miles to the northeast of Sibsagar" (<a href="#CITEREFSircar1990">Sircar 1990</a>, pp. 63–68).</span>
</li>

Ian McGready, New York: Harper Collins, 1995, pp. 198–201. <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-06-270085-5" title="Special:BookSources/0-06-270085-5">0-06-270085-5</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-192"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-192">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Johannes de Kruijf and Ajaya Sahoo (2014), <i>Indian Transnationalism Online: New Perspectives on Diaspora</i>, <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4724-1913-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4724-1913-2">978-1-4724-1913-2</a>, p. 105, Quote: "In other words, according to Adi Shankara's argument, the philosophy of Advaita Vedanta stood over and above all other forms of Hinduism and encapsulated them. This then united Hinduism; [...] Another of Adi Shankara's important undertakings which contributed to the unification of Hinduism was his founding of a number of monastic centers."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-193"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-193">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"Shankara", <i>Student's Encyclopædia Britannica – India</i> (2000), Volume 4, Encyclopædia Britannica (UK) Publishing, <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-85229-760-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-85229-760-5">978-0-85229-760-5</a>, p. 379, Quote: "Shankaracharya, philosopher and theologian, most renowned exponent of the Advaita Vedanta school of philosophy, from whose doctrines the main currents of modern Indian thought are derived.";<br/>David Crystal (2004), The Penguin Encyclopedia, Penguin Books, p. 1353, Quote: "[Shankara] is the most famous exponent of Advaita Vedanta school of Hindu philosophy and the source of the main currents of modern Hindu thought."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-194"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-194">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Christophe Jaffrelot (1998), <i>The Hindu Nationalist Movement in India</i>, Columbia University Press, <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-231-10335-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-231-10335-0">978-0-231-10335-0</a>, p. 2, Quote: "The main current of Hinduism – if not the only one – which became formalized in a way that approximates to an ecclesiastical structure was that of Shankara".</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-SKChattopadhyaya-195"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-SKChattopadhyaya_195-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=IPasbJW-1PwC" rel="nofollow">Shyama Kumar Chattopadhyaya (2000) <i>The Philosophy of Sankar's Advaita Vedanta</i></a>, Sarup &amp; Sons, New Delhi <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/81-7625-222-0" title="Special:BookSources/81-7625-222-0">81-7625-222-0</a>, <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-81-7625-222-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-81-7625-222-5">978-81-7625-222-5</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-eroer1-196"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-eroer1_196-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Edward Roer (Translator), <i><a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3uwDAAAAMAAJ&amp;pg=PA3" rel="nofollow">Shankara's Introduction</a></i>, p. 3, at <a href="/wiki/Google_Books" title="Google Books">Google Books</a> to <i>Brihad Aranyaka Upanishad</i> at pp. 3–4; Quote – "[...] Lokayatikas and Bauddhas who assert that the soul does not exist. There are four sects among the followers of Buddha: 1. Madhyamicas who maintain all is void; 2. Yogacharas, who assert except sensation and intelligence all else is void; 3. Sautranticas, who affirm actual existence of external objects no less than of internal sensations; 4. Vaibhashikas, who agree with later (Sautranticas) except that they contend for immediate apprehension of exterior objects through images or forms represented to the intellect."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-eroer2-197"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-eroer2_197-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Edward Roer (Translator), <i><a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3uwDAAAAMAAJ&amp;pg=PA3" rel="nofollow">Shankara's Introduction</a></i>, p. 3, at <a href="/wiki/Google_Books" title="Google Books">Google Books</a> to <i>Brihad Aranyaka Upanishad</i> at p. 3, <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OCLC_(identifier)" title="OCLC (identifier)">OCLC</a> <a class="external text" href="https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/19373677" rel="nofollow">19373677</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-198"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-198">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">KN Jayatilleke (2010), <i>Early Buddhist Theory of Knowledge</i>, <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-81-208-0619-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-81-208-0619-1">978-81-208-0619-1</a>, pp. 246–249, from note 385 onwards;<br/>Steven Collins (1994), Religion and Practical Reason (Editors: Frank Reynolds, David Tracy), State Univ of New York Press, <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7914-2217-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7914-2217-5">978-0-7914-2217-5</a>, p. 64; Quote: "Central to Buddhist soteriology is the doctrine of not-self (Pali: anattā, Sanskrit: anātman, the opposed doctrine of <a href="/wiki/%C4%80tman_(Hinduism)" title="Ātman (Hinduism)">ātman</a> is central to Brahmanical thought). Put very briefly, this is the [Buddhist] doctrine that human beings have no soul, no self, no unchanging essence.";<br/>Edward Roer (Translator), <i><a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3uwDAAAAMAAJ" rel="nofollow">Shankara's Introduction</a></i> at <a href="/wiki/Google_Books" title="Google Books">Google Books</a><br/>Katie Javanaud (2013), <a class="external text" href="https://philosophynow.org/issues/97/Is_The_Buddhist_No-Self_Doctrine_Compatible_With_Pursuing_Nirvana" rel="nofollow">Is The Buddhist 'No-Self' Doctrine Compatible With Pursuing Nirvana?</a>, Philosophy Now;<br/>John C. Plott et al. (2000), <i>Global History of Philosophy: The Axial Age</i>, Volume 1, Motilal Banarsidass, <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-81-208-0158-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-81-208-0158-5">978-81-208-0158-5</a>, p. 63, Quote: "The Buddhist schools reject any Ātman concept. As we have already observed, this is the basic and ineradicable distinction between Hinduism and Buddhism".</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-201"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-201">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFAvari2007"><a href="/wiki/Burjor_Avari" title="Burjor Avari">Avari, Burjor</a> (2007). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=DmB_AgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PT204" rel="nofollow"><i>India: The Ancient Past. A History of the Indian-Subcontinent from 7000 BC to AD 1200</i></a>. New York: Routledge. pp. 204–205. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-203-08850-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-203-08850-0"><bdi>978-0-203-08850-0</bdi></a>. <q>Madhyadesha became the ambition of two particular clans among a tribal people in Rajasthan, known as Gurjara and Pratihara. They were both parts of a larger federation of tribes, some of which later came to be known as the Rajputs</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=India%3A+The+Ancient+Past.+A+History+of+the+Indian-Subcontinent+from+7000+BC+to+AD+1200&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pages=204-205&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-203-08850-0&amp;rft.aulast=Avari&amp;rft.aufirst=Burjor&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DDmB_AgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPT204&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>

</li>
<li id="cite_note-aqueduct-263"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-aqueduct_263-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">From the notes of Portuguese Nuniz. Robert Sewell notes that a big dam across was built the Tungabhadra and an aqueduct 15 miles (24 km) long was cut out of rock (<a href="#CITEREFSastri1955">Sastri 1955</a>, p. 243).</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-264"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-264">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><i>Columbia Chronologies of Asian History and Culture</i>, John Stewart Bowman p. 271, (2013), Columbia University Press, New York, <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-231-11004-9" title="Special:BookSources/0-231-11004-9">0-231-11004-9</a></span>

<li id="cite_note-271"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-271">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFWagoner1996">Wagoner, Phillip B. <li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEFritzMichell14-273"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFritzMichell14_273-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFFritzMichell">Fritz &amp; Michell</a>, p. 14.<span class="error harv-error" style="display: none; font-size:100%"> sfn error: no target: CITEREFFritzMichell (<a href="/wiki/Category:Harv_and_Sfn_template_errors" title="Category:Harv and Sfn template errors">help</a>)</span></span>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEKamath2001177–178-274"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKamath2001177–178_274-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFKamath2001">Kamath 2001</a>, pp. 177–178.</span>

<li id="cite_note-275"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-275">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"The austere, grandiose site of Hampi was the last capital of the last great Hindu Kingdom of Vijayanagar. Its fabulously rich princes built <a href="/wiki/Dravidian_architecture" title="Dravidian architecture">Dravidian</a> temples and palaces which won the admiration of travellers between the 14th and 16th centuries. Conquered by the <a href="/wiki/Deccan_Plateau" title="Deccan Plateau">Deccan</a> Muslim confederacy in 1565, the city was pillaged over a period of six months before being abandoned." From the brief description <a class="external text" href="https://whc.unesco.org/en/list/241" rel="nofollow">UNESCO World Heritage List</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-276"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-276">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170517222359/http://www.vijayanagara.org/html/Ele_Stables.html" rel="nofollow">"Vijayanagara Research Project::Elephant Stables"</a>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-XWiACEwPR8C_p.16-349"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-XWiACEwPR8C_p.16_349-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFSailendra_Nath_Sen2010">Sailendra Nath Sen (2010). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=bXWiACEwPR8C&amp;pg=PR22" rel="nofollow"><i>An Advanced History of Modern India</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-355"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-355">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFSingh1981">Singh, Gulcharan (July 1981). "Maharaja Ranjit Singh and the Principles of War". <i>USI Journal</i>. <b>111</b> (465): 184–192.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=USI+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=Maharaja+Ranjit+Singh+and+the+Principles+of+War&amp;rft.volume=111&amp;rft.issue=465&amp;rft.pages=184-192&amp;rft.date=1981-07&amp;rft.aulast=Singh&amp;rft.aufirst=Gulcharan&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-Grewal-356"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Grewal_356-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFGrewal1990"><a href="/wiki/J._S._Grewal" title="J. S. Grewal">Grewal, J.S.</a> (1990). <i>The Sikhs of the Punjab</i>. The New Cambridge History of India. Vol. II.3. Cambridge University Press. pp. 101, 103–104. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-26884-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-26884-4"><bdi>978-0-521-26884-4</bdi></a>. <q>Aggrandisement which made him the master of an empire ... the British recognized Ranjit Singh as the sole sovereign ruler of the Punjab and left him free to ... oust the Afghans from Multan and Kashmir ... Peshawar was taken over ... The real strength of Ranjit Singh's army lay in its infantry and artillery ... these new wings played an increasingly decisive role ... possessed 200 guns. Horse artillery was added in the 1820s ... nearly half of his army in terms of numbers consisted of men and officers trained on European lines ... In the expansion of Ranjit Singh's dominions ... vassalage proved to be nearly as important as the westernized wings of his army.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Sikhs+of+the+Punjab&amp;rft.series=The+New+Cambridge+History+of+India&amp;rft.pages=101%2C+103-104&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1990&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-521-26884-4&amp;rft.aulast=Grewal&amp;rft.aufirst=J.S.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-Schmidt2015-365"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Schmidt2015_365-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFKarl_J._Schmidt2015">Karl J. <li id="cite_note-Elbl2012p12-366"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Elbl2012p12_366-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFGlenn_Ames2012">Glenn Ames (2012).  Ivana Elbl (ed.). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=hld-AwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA12" rel="nofollow"><i>Portugal and its Empire, 1250–1800 (Collected Essays in Memory of Glenn J. Ames).: Portuguese Studies Review, Vol. 17, No. 1</i></a>. Trent University Press. pp. 12–15 with footnotes, context: 11–32.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Portugal+and+its+Empire%2C+1250%E2%80%931800+%28Collected+Essays+in+Memory+of+Glenn+J.+Ames%29.%3A+Portuguese+Studies+Review%2C+Vol.+17%2C+No.+1&amp;rft.pages=12-15+with+footnotes%2C+context%3A+11-32&amp;rft.pub=Trent+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.au=Glenn+Ames&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dhld-AwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA12&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-391"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-391">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFNitish_Sengupta2001"><a href="/wiki/Nitish_Sengupta" title="Nitish Sengupta">Nitish Sengupta</a> (2001). <i>History of the Bengali-speaking People</i>. UBS Publishers' Distributors. pp. 210–213. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-81-7476-355-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-81-7476-355-6"><bdi>978-81-7476-355-6</bdi></a>. <q>Producing in about three quarters of a century so many creative stalwarts in literature, art, music, social and religious reform and also trading and industry ... The Bengal Renaissance can be said to have started with Raja Ram Mohan Roy (1775–1833) and ended with Rabindranath Tagore (1861–1941) ... On the whole, it remained an elitist movement restricted to Hindu <i>bhadralok</i> (gentry) and <i>zamindars</i>.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=History+of+the+Bengali-speaking+People&amp;rft.pages=210-213&amp;rft.pub=UBS+Publishers%27+Distributors&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.isbn=978-81-7476-355-6&amp;rft.au=Nitish+Sengupta&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-396"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-396">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFDatta2000">Datta, Rajat (2000). <a class="external text" href="https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/44927255" rel="nofollow"><i>Society, economy, and the market : commercialization in rural Bengal, c. 1760-1800</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-Chandra2016p128-423"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Chandra2016p128_423-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Chandra2016p128_423-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFChandraMukherjeeMukherjeeMahajan2016"><a href="/wiki/Bipan_Chandra" title="Bipan Chandra">Chandra, Bipan</a>; <a href="/wiki/Mridula_Mukherjee" title="Mridula Mukherjee">Mukherjee, Mridula</a>; Mukherjee, Aditya; Mahajan, Sucheta; <a href="/wiki/K._N._Panikkar" title="K. N. Panikkar">Panikkar, K.N.</a> (2016) [First published 1987]. <i>India's Struggle for Independence</i> (Revised and updated ed.). Penguin Books. p. 128. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-14-010781-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-14-010781-4"><bdi>978-0-14-010781-4</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=India%27s+Struggle+for+Independence&amp;rft.pages=128&amp;rft.edition=Revised+and+updated&amp;rft.pub=Penguin+Books&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-14-010781-4&amp;rft.aulast=Chandra&amp;rft.aufirst=Bipan&amp;rft.au=Mukherjee%2C+Mridula&amp;rft.au=Mukherjee%2C+Aditya&amp;rft.au=Mahajan%2C+Sucheta&amp;rft.au=Panikkar%2C+K.N.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-425"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-425">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation magazine cs1" id="CITEREFBond1963">Bond, Brian (October 1963). "Amritsar 1919". <i>History Today</i>. Vol. 13, no. 10. pp. 666–676.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=History+Today&amp;rft.atitle=Amritsar+1919&amp;rft.volume=13&amp;rft.issue=10&amp;rft.pages=666-676&amp;rft.date=1963-10&amp;rft.aulast=Bond&amp;rft.aufirst=Brian&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-QasmiRobb2017-426"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-QasmiRobb2017_426-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFQasmiRobb2017">Qasmi, Ali Usman; Robb, Megan Eaton (2017). <i>Muslims against the Muslim League: Critiques of the Idea of Pakistan</i>. Cambridge University Press. p. 2. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-108-62123-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-108-62123-6"><bdi>978-1-108-62123-6</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Muslims+against+the+Muslim+League%3A+Critiques+of+the+Idea+of+Pakistan&amp;rft.pages=2&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2017&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-108-62123-6&amp;rft.aulast=Qasmi&amp;rft.aufirst=Ali+Usman&amp;rft.au=Robb%2C+Megan+Eaton&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Haq1970-427"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Haq1970_427-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFHaq1970">Haq, Mushir U. (1970). <i>Muslim politics in modern India, 1857–1947</i>. Meenakshi Prakashan. p. 114. <q>This was also reflected in one of the resolutions of the Azad Muslim Conference, an organization which attempted to be representative of all the various nationalist Muslim parties and groups in India.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Muslim+politics+in+modern+India%2C+1857%E2%80%931947&amp;rft.pages=114&amp;rft.pub=Meenakshi+Prakashan&amp;rft.date=1970&amp;rft.aulast=Haq&amp;rft.aufirst=Mushir+U.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Ahmed2016-428"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Ahmed2016_428-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Ahmed2016_428-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFAhmed2016">Ahmed, Ishtiaq (27 May 2016). <a class="external text" href="https://www.thefridaytimes.com/tft/the-dissenters/" rel="nofollow">"The dissenters"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Friday_Times" title="The Friday Times">The Friday Times</a></i>. <q>However, the book is a tribute to the role of one Muslim leader who steadfastly opposed the Partition of India: the Sindhi leader Allah Bakhsh Soomro. Allah Bakhsh belonged to a landed family. He founded the Sindh People's Party in 1934, which later came to be known as ‘Ittehad’ or ‘Unity Party’. ... Allah Bakhsh was totally opposed to the Muslim League's demand for the creation of Pakistan through a division of India on a religious basis. Consequently, he established the Azad Muslim Conference. In its Delhi session held during April 27–30, 1940 some 1400 delegates took part. They belonged mainly to the lower castes and working class. The famous scholar of Indian Islam, Wilfred Cantwell Smith, feels that the delegates represented a ‘majority of India's Muslims’. Among those who attended the conference were representatives of many Islamic theologians and women also took part in the deliberations ... Shamsul Islam argues that the All-India Muslim League at times used intimidation and coercion to silence any opposition among Muslims to its demand for Partition. He calls such tactics of the Muslim League as a ‘Reign of Terror’. He gives examples from all over India including the NWFP where the Khudai Khidmatgars remain opposed to the Partition of India.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Friday+Times&amp;rft.atitle=The+dissenters&amp;rft.date=2016-05-27&amp;rft.aulast=Ahmed&amp;rft.aufirst=Ishtiaq&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.thefridaytimes.com%2Ftft%2Fthe-dissenters%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Ali2017-429"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Ali2017_429-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Ali2017_429-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Ali2017_429-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFAli2017">Ali, Afsar (17 July 2017). <a class="external text" href="http://www.milligazette.com/news/15756-partition-of-india-and-patriotism-of-indian-muslims" rel="nofollow">"Partition of India and Patriotism of Indian Muslims"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Milli_Gazette" title="The Milli Gazette">The Milli Gazette</a></i>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Milli+Gazette&amp;rft.atitle=Partition+of+India+and+Patriotism+of+Indian+Muslims&amp;rft.date=2017-07-17&amp;rft.aulast=Ali&amp;rft.aufirst=Afsar&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.milligazette.com%2Fnews%2F15756-partition-of-india-and-patriotism-of-indian-muslims&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Great_Speeches-430"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Great_Speeches_430-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/series/greatspeeches" rel="nofollow">"Great speeches of the 20th century"</a>. <i>The Guardian</i>. 8 February 2008.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Guardian&amp;rft.atitle=Great+speeches+of+the+20th+century&amp;rft.date=2008-02-08&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.theguardian.com%2Ftheguardian%2Fseries%2Fgreatspeeches&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-431"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-431">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Philip Ziegler, <i>Mountbatten</i>(1985) p. 401.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-symonds-432"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-symonds_432-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-symonds_432-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFSymonds1950"><a href="/wiki/Richard_Symonds_(academic)" title="Richard Symonds (academic)">Symonds, Richard</a> (1950). <i>The Making of Pakistan</i>. London: Faber and Faber. p. 74. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OCLC_(identifier)" title="OCLC (identifier)">OCLC</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/oclc/1462689" rel="nofollow">1462689</a>. <q>At the lowest estimate, half a million people perished and twelve millions became homeless.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Making+of+Pakistan&amp;rft.place=London&amp;rft.pages=74&amp;rft.pub=Faber+and+Faber&amp;rft.date=1950&amp;rft_id=info%3Aoclcnum%2F1462689&amp;rft.aulast=Symonds&amp;rft.aufirst=Richard&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Abid2014-433"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Abid2014_433-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFAbid2014">Abid, Abdul Majeed (29 December 2014). <a class="external text" href="https://nation.com.pk/29-Dec-2014/the-forgotten-massacre" rel="nofollow">"The forgotten massacre"</a>. <i>The Nation</i>. <q>On the same dates [4 and 5 March 1947], Muslim League-led mobs fell with determination and full preparations on the helpless Hindus and Sikhs scattered in the villages of Multan, Rawalpindi, Campbellpur, Jhelum and Sargodha. The murderous mobs were well supplied with arms, such as daggers, swords, spears and fire-arms. (A former civil servant mentioned in his autobiography that weapon supplies had been sent from NWFP and money was supplied by Delhi-based politicians.)</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Nation&amp;rft.atitle=The+forgotten+massacre&amp;rft.date=2014-12-29&amp;rft.aulast=Abid&amp;rft.aufirst=Abdul+Majeed&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fnation.com.pk%2F29-Dec-2014%2Fthe-forgotten-massacre&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Raghavan2013-434"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Raghavan2013_434-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFSrinath_Raghavan2013">Srinath Raghavan (12 November 2013). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=2S-wAQAAQBAJ" rel="nofollow"><i>1971</i></a>. Harvard University Press. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-674-73129-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-674-73129-5"><bdi>978-0-674-73129-5</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=1971&amp;rft.pub=Harvard+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2013-11-12&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-674-73129-5&amp;rft.au=Srinath+Raghavan&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D2S-wAQAAQBAJ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-442"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-442">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFBagchi1993">Bagchi, Amiya Kumar (January 1993). "Writing Indian History in the Marxist Mode in a Post-Soviet World". <i>Indian Historical Review</i>. <b>20</b> (1/2): 229–244.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Historical+Review&amp;rft.atitle=Writing+Indian+History+in+the+Marxist+Mode+in+a+Post-Soviet+World&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1%2F2&amp;rft.pages=229-244&amp;rft.date=1993-01&amp;rft.aulast=Bagchi&amp;rft.aufirst=Amiya+Kumar&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-443"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-443">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFPrakash1994">Prakash, Gyan (December 1994). <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Historiography_2">Historiography</span></h3>
<ul><li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBannerjee1921">Bannerjee, Gauranganath (1921). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/stream/indiaasknowntoan00banerich#page/n3/mode/2up" rel="nofollow"><i>India as known to the ancient world</i></a>. London: Humphrey Milford, Oxford University Press.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=India+as+known+to+the+ancient+world&amp;rft.place=London&amp;rft.pub=Humphrey+Milford%2C+Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1921&amp;rft.aulast=Bannerjee&amp;rft.aufirst=Gauranganath&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fstream%2Findiaasknowntoan00banerich%23page%2Fn3%2Fmode%2F2up&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFBayly1985">Bayly, C.A. (November 1985). "State and Economy in India over Seven Hundred Years". <i>The Economic History Review</i>. <b>38</b> (4): 583–596. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1111%2Fj.1468-0289.1985.tb00391.x" rel="nofollow">10.1111/j.1468-0289.1985.tb00391.x</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/JSTOR_(identifier)" title="JSTOR (identifier)">JSTOR</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.jstor.org/stable/2597191" rel="nofollow">2597191</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Economic+History+Review&amp;rft.atitle=State+and+Economy+in+India+over+Seven+Hundred+Years&amp;rft.volume=38&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.pages=583-596&amp;rft.date=1985-11&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1111%2Fj.1468-0289.1985.tb00391.x&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.jstor.org%2Fstable%2F2597191%23id-name%3DJSTOR&amp;rft.aulast=Bayly&amp;rft.aufirst=C.A.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></li>
<li>Bose, Mihir. "India's Missing Historians: Mihir Bose Discusses the Paradox That India, a Land of History, Has a Surprisingly Weak Tradition of Historiography", <i>History Today</i> 57#9 (2007) pp. 34–. <a class="external text" href="https://www.questia.com/PM.qst?a=o&amp;d=5023376478" rel="nofollow">online</a></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFElliotDowson1867">Elliot, Henry Miers; Dowson, John (1867). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20090825184925/http://persian.packhum.org/persian/main?url=pf%3Ffile%3D80201010%26ct%3D0" rel="nofollow"><i>The History of India, as told by its own historians. The Muhammadan Period</i></a>. London: Trübner and Co. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://persian.packhum.org/persian/main?url=pf%3Ffile%3D80201010%26ct%3D0" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on 25 August 2009.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+History+of+India%2C+as+told+by+its+own+historians.+The+Muhammadan+Period&amp;rft.pub=London%3A+Tr%C3%BCbner+and+Co.&amp;rft.date=1867&amp;rft.aulast=Elliot&amp;rft.aufirst=Henry+Miers&amp;rft.au=Dowson%2C+John&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fpersian.packhum.org%2Fpersian%2Fmain%3Furl%3Dpf%253Ffile%253D80201010%2526ct%253D0&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFKahn2011">Kahn, Yasmin (2011). "Remembering and Forgetting: South Asia and the Second World War".  In Martin Gegner; Bart Ziino (eds.). <i>The Heritage of War</i>. Routledge. pp. 177–193.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Remembering+and+Forgetting%3A+South+Asia+and+the+Second+World+War&amp;rft.btitle=The+Heritage+of+War&amp;rft.pages=177-193&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.aulast=Kahn&amp;rft.aufirst=Yasmin&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFJain2011">Jain, M. (2011). "4". <i>The India They Saw: Foreign Accounts</i>. <a href="/wiki/Delhi" title="Delhi">Delhi</a>: Ocean Books.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=4&amp;rft.btitle=The+India+They+Saw%3A+Foreign+Accounts&amp;rft.pub=Delhi%3A+Ocean+Books&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.aulast=Jain&amp;rft.aufirst=M.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFLal2003">Lal, Vinay (2003). <i>The History of History: Politics and Scholarship in Modern India</i>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+History+of+History%3A+Politics+and+Scholarship+in+Modern+India&amp;rft.date=2003&amp;rft.aulast=Lal&amp;rft.aufirst=Vinay&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFPalit2008">Palit, Chittabrata (2008). <i>Indian Historiography</i>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Indian+Historiography&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.aulast=Palit&amp;rft.aufirst=Chittabrata&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></li>

(2004). <i>A Textbook of Historiography, 500 B.C. to A.D. 2000</i>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+Textbook+of+Historiography%2C+500+B.C.+to+A.D.+2000&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.aulast=Sreedharan&amp;rft.aufirst=E.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span></li>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Primary">Primary</span></h3>
<ul><li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://dsal.uchicago.edu/reference/gazetteer/" rel="nofollow"><i>The Imperial Gazetteer of India</i></a>. 1908–1931.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Imperial+Gazetteer+of+India&amp;rft.date=1908%2F1931&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fdsal.uchicago.edu%2Freference%2Fgazetteer%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHistory+of+India"></span> Highly detailed description of all of India in 1901.</li></ul>
